questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition seen in the image?

choices.text: The causative agent is a diplobacillus
Blepharitis is usually not associated with this condition
The mode of spread is from the nasal cavity to eyes
1% tetracycline ointment is used in the treatment

questions.solution:
The condition seen in the given image is angular conjunctivitis. Blepharitis is an associated feature in chronic angular conjunctivitis.

The following findings in the given image are indicative of angular conjunctivitis

  • Reddening of the conjunctiva limited exclusively to the intermarginal strip (especially at the canthus)
  • Excoriation of the skin at the inner and outer palpebral angles

Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic infection caused by Moraxella lacunata, a gram-negative diplobacillus. The bacilli produce a proteolytic fragment which macerates the conjunctival epithelium. The nasal cavity is usually a source of infection, spread through contaminated hands and handkerchiefs.

Distinct clinical features of angular conjunctivitis are as follows:

  • Collection of dirty white foamy discharge at the angles of the eye
  • Conjunctival congestion limited to the intermarginal strip
  • Excoriation of the nearby skin at palpebral angles
  • Associated with blepharitis in chronic infection
  • Shallow marginal corneal ulcers and hypopyon (rare presentation)

Treatment includes application of the tetracycline ointment 2 to 3 times a day for 7 to 14 days.

Pathogens causing different types of conjunctivitis

Acute conjunctivitis (resolving in less than 4 weeks) Hyperacute conjunctivitis (symptoms develop within 24 hours; aggressive course) Chronic conjunctivitis (of greater than 4 weeks duration)

Staphylococcus aureus

Streptococcus pneumoniae

Haemophilus influenzae

Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Neisseria meningitidis

Staphylococcus aureus

Moraxella lacunata

Enteric bacteria

questions.text:
Match the following

Column A

 

  1. Image A
  2. Image B
  3. Image C
  4. Image D

 

Column B

1. Verbrugge forceps

2. Citelli's forceps

3. Asch's forceps

4. Tilly's forceps
questions.solution:
The correct match is 

 

Image A - 3. Asch's forceps
Image B - 1. Verbrugge forceps
Image C - 2. Citelli's forceps
Image D - 4. Tilly's forceps

 
Asch's forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum

Verbrugge forceps consist of a ratcheted clamp with a curved distal end. It is used for holding the bone and plate

Citelli's forceps is used for punching bones and other tissues

Tilly's forceps is used for insertion or removal of nasal packing or dressings

questions.text:
Assertion: Ingestion of high oral doses of fructose can result in osmotic diarrhea
Reason: Fructose is absorbed via passive carrier-mediated diffusion

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Ingestion of high oral doses of fructose can result in osmotic diarrhea because fructose is absorbed via passive carrier-mediated diffusion, and on the ingestion of high oral doses, the transport protein gets saturated and results in the fructose remaining intraluminally which culminated in diarrhea.

So, Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

 

Additionally, the loading of the liver with fructose may potentiate Hypertriacylglycerolemia, Hypercholesterolemia, & Hyperuricemia

questions.text:
Assertion: Direct puncture of a hydatid cyst close to the abdominal wall must be avoided during PAIR.
Reason: Normal liver parenchyma must be present between the puncture point and the surface of the cyst for the prevention of anaphylactic reactions & recurrences.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Direct puncture of a hydatid cyst close to the abdominal wall must be avoided during PAIR because normal liver parenchyma must be present between the puncture point and the surface of the cyst for the prevention of anaphylactic reactions & recurrences. 

 

Normal liver parenchyma must be present between the puncture point and the surface of the cyst to avoid leakage of cyst fluid so as to ensure the prevention of anaphylactic reactions and to avoid the protoscolex spillage so as to ensure prevention of recurrences. Hence, the direct puncture of a cyst close to the abdominal wall must be avoided.

 

So, 

Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: Which of the following techniques separates proteins on the basis of their stokes radii?
questions.solution:
Gel filtration chromatography, also known as size exclusion chromatography separates proteins on the basis of their stokes radii.

Stokes radius is a measure of the effective volume a protein occupies in a free solution. It accounts for both the mass and the shape of the protein. Proteins with large and small stokes radii are applied to the top of a gel filtration column. On entering the column, the small proteins enter pores in the stationary phase matrix (included proteins). During the mobile phase flowing down the column, the large molecules lag behind, which get excluded (excluded proteins). Proteins thus emerge from a gel filtration column in descending order of their stokes radii.

Ion exchange chromatography separates proteins in inverse order of the strength of their interactions with the stationary phase and is based on charge-charge interactions. Proteins with a net positive charge at a given pH will tightly adhere to negatively charged beads called cation exchangers. Proteins with a net negative charge will adhere to positively charged beads called anion exchangers. Nonadherent proteins flow through the matrix and are washed away. HbA1c (Glycated hemoglobin) is best measured using ion exchange chromatography.

Affinity chromatography is based on the high selectivity displayed by most proteins for their ligands. The high selectivity of affinity chromatography is caused by allowing the desired molecule to interact with the stationary phase and remain bound within the column in order to facilitate its separation from the undesired material, which will not interact and elute first.

Hydrophobic interaction Chromatography separates proteins based on their tendency to associate with a stationary phase matrix coated with hydrophobic groups. Proteins with exposed hydrophobic surfaces adhere to the matrix via hydrophobic bonds that are enhanced by employing a mobile phase of high ionic strength.

Related Pearl: Types of Chromatography

Chromatography types Property used for separation
Paper chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Thin layer chromatography Based on polarity, Least polar moves faster
Ion exchange chromatography Based on charge – charge interaction
Size exclusion chromatography Based on descending order of Stokes radius which is a function of molecular mass and shape
Affinity chromatography Based on specific ligand binding behaviour
Hydrophobic interaction chromatography Based on hydrophobic interaction

questions.text: Based on mechanism of action and effects, which of the following pairs is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is reserpine - inhibits prolactin release. Reserpine is a dopamine depletor. Use of reserpine results in low levels of dopamine (Prolactin inhibitory factor), and hence loss of inhibition of prolactin release. Hence, prolactin levels rise.

Chlorpromazine, metoclopramide and reserpine are enhancers of prolactin secretion.

Note: Drugs that inhibit prolactin release are bromocriptine and cabergoline.

questions.text: A young male presented with fever and lymphadenopathy in the cervical and inguinal region. The histology of the lymph node showed RS cells with vague nodule formation in the background of T-reactive lymphocytes. What is the clinical staging according to Ann-Arbor staging?
questions.solution:
Involvement of lymph nodes on both sides of diaphragm with fever is stage III (B) of Ann-Arbor staging.

Clinical staging of both Hodgkin and Non Hodgkin Lymphoma is done by Ann Arbor staging.

Related Pearl: Ann Arbor Staging for Hodgkin and NonHodgkin Lymphoma

Stage Distribution of disease
I

Involvement of a single lymph node region (I)

or 

a single extra lymphatic organ or site (IE)
II

Involvement of two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm alone (II)

or

localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site (IIE)
III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm without (III) or with (IIIE) localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site
IV

Diffuse involvement of one or more extra lymphatic organs or sites with or without lymphatic involvement 

All stages are further divided on the basis of the absence (A) or presence (B) of fever, night sweats and/or unexplained weight loss >10% of body weight.

questions.text: A study conducted in a government school found that the mean weight of children aged 4-6 years is 17 kg and the standard deviation is 3 kg. A child whose z-score is +1.0 would weigh how much?
questions.solution:
A child whose z score is +1.0 will weigh 20 kg.

z = (X- µ)/σ, where X is the element’s value, µ is the mean, and σ is the standard deviation. In this case, the z score = 1, µ=17 and σ = 3. We need to find X. Applying these in the formula, we get: 

1=(X-17)/3

3=x-17

x=3+17=20.

The z score is the location of an element in the normal distribution and is denoted by how many standard deviations (SD) it lies above or below the mean of that distribution. So, if a value is 1 SD above the mean, the z score will be +1.0. So, an alternative method to arrive at the answer, in this case, is: A z score of +1 means the value is 1 SD above the mean = 17+3 = 20 kg.

Other Options:

Option A: A child weighing 23 kg will have a z score of +2.0.

Option B: A child weighing 11 kg will have a z score of -2.0.

Option D: A child weighing 14 kg will have a z score of -1.0.

Related Pearl: Z Scores

  • Z score indicates the position of any element in a distribution in terms of how many standard deviations it lies from the mean of the distribution.
  • It is also called the standard score.
  • If it lies above the mean, its z score will be positive and if it lies below it, the z score will be negative.
  • For example, if an element lies 1.5 standard deviations below the mean, its z score will be -1.5 and if it lies 0.5 standard deviations above the mean, its z score will be +0.5.
  • The formula for calculating z scores is z = (X- µ)/σ, where x is the element’s value, µ is the mean and σ is the standard deviation. From this, we can also calculate the actual value of the element.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following physeal injuries as per the Salter-Harris Classification, starting with the type 1

1. Fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis - contains Thurston holland fragment

2. Fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis

3. Transverse fracture through the growth plate

4. Compression fracture of the growth plate
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is:

3. Transverse fracture through the growth plate- Type 1

1. Fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis - contains Thurston holland fragment - Type 2

2. Fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis - Type 4

4. Compression fracture of the growth plate - Type 5

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text:
Which of the following are contents of the triangle shown in the image?
  1. The long thoracic nerve of bell
  2. Suprascapular nerve
  3. Nerve to subclavius
  4. The second part of the subclavian artery 
  5. Internal Jugular Vein
questions.solution:
The highlighted triangle is the supraclavicular (subclavian) triangle. The lower part of the external (not internal) jugular vein and the third (not second) part of the subclavian artery are the contents of the triangle.

 


The supraclavicular triangle is the lower and smaller division of the posterior triangle of the neck.

Boundaries :
Superiorly - The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle
Inferiorly - The clavicle
Anteriorly - The posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle

Contents:

  • Nerves - trunks of the brachial plexus, nerve to serratus anterior (long thoracic nerve of bell), suprascapular nerve, nerve to subclavius.
  • Vessels - the third part of the subclavian artery and vein, suprascapular artery and vein, the origin of the transverse cervical artery, the lower part of the external jugular vein
  • Lymph nodes

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text:
Match the following

Column A

  1. Barton's Fracture
  2. Colle's Fracture
  3. Monteggia's Fracture
  4. Galleazi's Fracture

 

Column B

A

B

C

D
questions.solution:
The correct match is 

 

  1. Barton's Fracture - D
  2. Colle's Fracture - A
  3. Monteggia's Fracture - C
  4. Galleazi's Fracture - B

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic kidney disease and creatinine of 4.1mg/dl,  presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his great toe for the past 3 hours. On examination, his big toe of the right foot is red and tender. Joint aspiration shows no white cells but shows needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals. What is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient with a swollen, painful big toe and needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals on synovial tap has acute gout. Due to coexisting chronic kidney disease, the drug of choice in him is intra-articular steroids like triamcinolone or methylprednisolone.

The drug of choice is an acute attack of gout is NSAIDs (Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) like indomethacin or the drug colchicine, but they are poorly tolerated and should not be used in elderly patients with chronic kidney disease.

Drugs used in the management of gout can be classified as:

Drugs that relieve inflammation and pain- These drugs are useful in the management of acute attacks of gout. They are:

  • NSAIDs- They mainly exert their antiinflammatory action by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzyme (COX). This enzyme converts arachidonic acid to prostanoids, thromboxane A2, and other prostaglandins. 
  • Colchicine- It arrests the cell division in G1 by interfering with microtubule and spindle formation. This results in decreased neutrophil recruitment, decreased neutrophil motility, and decreased release of chemotactic factors. 
  • Glucocorticoids- These drugs bind to the nuclear receptors and decrease the transcription of genes for COX-2, inducible NOS (NOS2), inflammatory cytokines, collagenase, etc, that are responsible for inflammation.

Drugs that inhibit urate formation- These drugs inhibit urate formation by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase. Eg. allopurinol and febuxostat

Uricosuric drugs- These drugs increase the excretion of uric acid. Important ones are:

  • Probenecid- it inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid by inhibiting organic acid transporter (OATs), principally URAT-1.
  • Benzbromarone- It increases uric acid secretion by reversibly inhibiting urate–anion exchanger in the proximal tubule
  • Lesinurad- It inhibits the URAT-1 and OAT-4 transporters, thereby reducing renal uric acid reabsorption.

Pegloticase and rasburicase catalyze the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin. This product is soluble and inactive. 

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Finding

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother because she has not started menstruating. Her mother and older sister started menstruating at the age of 16 yrs. She is a healthy girl and lies along the 50th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. She has scant axillary and pubic hair and breasts are Tanner stage 3. Pelvic examination is normal and she says she is not sexually active. She has an old sonographic report of abdomen and pelvis that was normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
All women with amenorrhoea,whether primary or secondary, should undergo beta-HCG testing to rule out pregnancy. Only after this, other investigations, if needed, should be done.

Note: All reproductive-aged women with amenorrhea are assumed pregnant until proven otherwise. Thus, a urinary or serum β -hCG level is always obtained

questions.text:
Mark the following statements true or false
  1. Complete transection above the pons with vagi intact would result in the continuation of regular breathing
  2. Section at the mid pontine level with vagi intact would result in apneusis
  3. Transection midway between pons and medulla with intact vagi causes irregular but rhythmic respiration
  4. Transection midway between pons and medulla with cut vagi causes irregular but rhythmic respiration
  5. Complete transection below medulla causes cessation of spontaneous respiration irrespective of vagi status
questions.solution:
• Complete transection above the pons with vagi intact would result in the continuation of regular breathing - True
  • Section at the mid pontine level with vagi intact would result in apneusis - False. A section at the mid pontine level with vagi intact would result in the continuation of regular breathing and apneusis would result only when the vagi are cut.
  • Transection midway between pons and medulla with intact vagi causes irregular but rhythmic respiration - True
  • Transection midway between pons and medulla with cut vagi causes irregular but rhythmic respiration - True
  • Complete transection below medulla causes cessation of spontaneous respiration irrespective of vagi status - True

 

Related Pearl: Effects of Various Lesions and Brainstem Transections

Level of transection

Vagi intact

Vagi cut

A

Complete transection above pons

Regular breathing continues

Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases

B

Mid-pontine level section

Regular breathing continues

Apneusis develops

C

Transection midway between pons and medulla

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

D

Complete transection below medulla

Spontaneous respiration ceases

questions.text:
The replication cycle of a virus is shown below. Which of the following drugs is used in the treatment of infection by this virus &
1. Prevents uncoating,  
2. Prevent the release of progeny viruses respectively?
questions.solution:
The replicative cycle shown here is that of the influenza virus.

The drug which prevents uncoating is amantadine (and rimantadine) and the drug which inhibits the release of virus progeny (by inhibiting neuraminidase) is zanamivir (and oseltamivir and peramivir).

Note: Maraviroc (a CCR-5 receptor inhibitor) and lopinavir (a protease inhibitor) are used as antiretrovirals, not anti-influenza drugs.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia, with a leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The flow cytometry of cells is as given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given pattern is suggestive of B-CLL.

Interpreting flow cytometry graph:

See the markers on X-axis and Y-axis. Divide the graph into 4 quadrants.

1)In the first graph, X-axis shows CD5 and Y-axis shows CD19. The particular cell population in question is positive for CD19 and CD5.

2)In the second graph, it is shown the cells are negative for CD10 and positive for CD19.

3)The third graph shows CD 23 is positive. CD20 is dimly expressed.

4)FMC-7 is negative. CD20 is dimly expressed.

 

It is understood from the cytometry analysis that the cells are positive for CD5, CD19, CD23, CD20.  All these suggest the diagnosis of B-CLL.

 

 

Other options:

  • Mantle cell lymphoma can be diagnosed by its characteristic immunophenotype: CD19+, CD20+, CD21+, CD22+, CD23(-), CD 5+.
  • DLBCL and Follicular lymphoma are positive for CD10.

Comparison between Mantle Cell Lymphoma and Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (CLL/SLL):

CD5 Positive Positive
CD23 Negative Positive
Cyclin D1 Positive Negative
FMC7 Positive Negative
CD10, BCL6 Negative Negative

questions.text: What is the stain used in the given preparation for demonstrating H. pylori?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori).

Helicobacter pylori is a gram-negative rod and contains flagella. It is a risk factor for peptic ulcer disease, mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma, and gastric adenocarcinoma. It causes gastric injury by releasing various virulence factors like γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), cytotoxin-associated gene A (cagA) product, virulence components vacuolating toxin (vacA), and lipopolysaccharides.

Important tests for the detection of H.Pylori are:

  • Rapid urease test
  • Histology
  • Culture
  • Serology
  • Urea breath test
  • Stool antigen test

Other options:

Masson trichrome stain demonstrating pulmonary hypertensive arteriopathy is shown in the image below:

 

Von Kossa stain demonstrating calcium and iron-containing Michaelis-Gutman bodies (MG bodies) in malakoplakia is shown in the image given below:

 

Alcian blue staining of mucin in Barret's mucosa is shown in the image given below:

questions.text: A 25-year-old man feels embarrassed to talk with his peers because of the persistence of a high-pitched childhood voice. At times, he has noticed that on pressing the thyroid prominence, he was able to produce an adult-type voice. Which of the following thyroplasty procedure would benefit this patient?

choices.text: Shortening or relaxation of vocal cord
Lengthening or tightening of vocal cord

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of puberphonia, also known as mutational falsetto voice. A type III thyroplasty causing shortening or relaxation of the vocal cord would benefit this patient.

When larynx matures at puberty, the voice becomes low-pitched in males. Puberphonia (mutational falsetto voice) is a condition in which the transition from high-pitched childhood voice to adult male voice fails to occur. The vocal cords are stretched and pose high tension.

Pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and a low tone voice can be produced. This is called Gutzmann’s pressure test.

In type III thyroplasty, the vocal cord is shortened and hence the tension is reduced. This can revert from a childhood voice to an adult one.

Type of thyroplasty Procedure done
Type I Medial displacement of vocal cord
Type II Lateral displacement of vocal cord
Type III Shortening (relaxation) of vocal cord
Type IV Lengthening (tightening) of vocal cord

questions.text:
Assertion: Inoculation of C. perfringens in egg yolk agar causes opalescence.
Reason: C. perfringens produces Perfringiolysin.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Inoculation of C. perfringens in egg yolk agar causes opalescence because of the lecithinase activity of alpha-toxin. Perfringiolysin is theta toxin, otherwise called as oxygen labile hemolysin. It contributes to tissue destruction by the bacteria. 

 

So, Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.

questions.text:
The actions of the muscle attached to the area marked by the red arrow are:

1. Depression of mandible
2. Protrusion of mandible
3. Side to side movement of the jaw
4. Elevation of mandible
5. Retraction of mandible
questions.solution:
The pterygoid fovea of the mandible is indicated by the red arrow. The parts of the mandible are shown in the image below.

The marked area on the given image of the mandible is the pterygoid fovea, where the lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted. The action of this muscle is depression, protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the jaw.

The lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted into the articular disc and capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

The muscles of mastication are:

  • Lateral pterygoid muscle:

    • Origin - Upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate
    • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule, and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint
    • Nerve supply - Nerve to lateral pterygoid, a branch of the mandibular nerve

  • Medial pterygoid muscle:

    • Origin - Deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. Superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and pyramidal process of palatine bone
    • Insertion- It is inserted into the medial surface of the ramus, near the angle of the mandible
    • Nerve supply - Nerve to medial pterygoid, a branch of the mandibular nerve

 

Masseter muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of the zygomatic bone and zygomatic arch.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the lateral surface of the ramus of the mandible and coronoid process
  • Nerve supply - Masseteric nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve

Temporalis muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from the temporal fossa and deep surface of the temporal fascia.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the coronoid process and to the anterior border of the ramus of the mandible up to the third molar tooth
  • Nerve supply - Anterior, middle, and posterior deep temporal nerves, branches of the mandibular nerve

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Histopathology showed the following appearance. Which of the following is true about this tumour?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows Indian file appearance which is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast. Mutation in CDH-1 gene is associated with lobular carcinoma.

Lobular Carcinoma:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Multicentric
  • Pathogenesis: Mutation in CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance.
  • Desmoplasia is minimal or absent
  • They are Luminal-A type
  • Excellent prognosis

Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also pose a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Molecular classification of breast cancer

(most common, best prognosis)

Her2- -ve

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

Defining Features

questions.text: A couple comes to the gynecology OPD for evaluation of infertility. The husband has a complex medical history. He had acute lymphoblastic leukemia at the age of 3 years and received chemotherapy. He also had mumps at this time and measles at 4 years. He also has a history of unprotected sex with multiple partners and has been treated for gonorrhea and chlamydia in the past. During adolescence, he was started on risperidone for mania, which he continues to take.   Which of the following history would indicate a pre-testicular cause of male infertility?
questions.solution:
Antipsychotics cause hyperprolactinemia and infertility. This is a pre-testicular cause of infertility.

Mumps causing orchitis (Option A), and chemotherapy (Option C) affect the testis directly and are testicular causes of infertility. History of gonorrhea (Option B) can cause testicular and post-testicular infertility. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Male Infertility

Pre-testicular causes:

Endocrine cause

  • Gonadotropin deficiency
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperprolactinemia

Psychosexual

  • Impotence
  • Erectile dysfunction

Drugs

  • Antihypertensives
  • Antipsychotics

Genetics

  • 47XXY
  • Y chromosome deletions

Testicular causes:

  • Immotile cilia syndrome
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Orchitis (mumps, Tb, gonorrhoea, traumatic)
  • Toxins(Drugs,radiation)
  • Primary testicular failure
  • Sertoli cell-only syndrome
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

Post-testicular causes:

Obstruction of efferent duct 

Congenital

  • Absence of Vas deferens
  • Youngs syndrome

Acquired (Inflammatory block)

  • Tuberculosis
  • Gonorrhea

Surgical

  • Vasectomy

Others

  • Ejaculatory failure
  • Bladder neck surgery
  • Retrograde ejaculation

questions.text: A 75-year-old man who worked in an asbestos factory for more than 20 years presented with hemoptysis. A mass was seen in the apical region of the right lung in X-ray. Histopathological examination from the mass showed cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. Which of the following immunohistochemical markers differentiates the lesion from adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Calretinin positivity is seen in mesothelioma (not adenocarcinoma). The smaller image in the top right left corner of the given histology slide shows IHC staining positive for calretinin.

The given clinical history and investigations suggest the diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma.

Points in favour:

  • Exposure of asbestos for more than 20 years (most specific neoplasm associated with asbestosis is mesothelioma).
  • Male candidate (strong male predilection 3:1)
  • Mass in the right apical region of the lung (affected lung becomes ensheathed by a thick layer of soft, gelatinous, greyish, pink tumour tissue)

Malignant mesothelioma is a rare malignant tumour of the pleura, associated with heavy asbestos exposure. The lifetime risk of developing mesothelioma in heavily exposed individuals is as high as 7% to 10%.

Grossly, it appears as a diffuse lesion arising either from the visceral or parietal pleura. The affected lung becomes ensheathed by a thick layer of soft, gelatinous, greyish pink tumour tissue.

Microscopically, they are of three types: epithelioid (60%), sarcomatoid (20%), and mixed (20%).

Electron microscopy in mesothelioma will show numerous long, slender microvilli and abundant tonofilaments but absent microvillous rootlets and lamellar bodies.

Immunohistochemistry in Lung cancers:

  • Primary lung adenocarcinoma (Napsin-A positive, Thyroid Transcription Factor (TTF-1) positive)
  • Primary lung squamous cell carcinoma (Napsin-A negative, TTF-1 negative)
  • Primary Small Cell Lung Cancers (Napsin-A negative, TTF-1 positive)
  • Nonsquamous NSCLC, SCLC, and mesothelioma may stain positive for CK7 and negative for CK20
  • Squamous cell lung cancer often will be both CK7 and CK20 negative
  • p63 is a useful marker for the detection of Non-Small Cell Lung Cancers with squamous differentiation when used in cytologic pulmonary samples
  • CK5/6, calretinin, and Wilms tumor gene-1 (WT-1), all of which show positivity in mesothelioma

Related Pearl: Differentiation of Mesothelioma from Adenocarcinoma

Adenocarcinoma

Negative

Negative

questions.text: A patient complains of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever and profuse ear discharge. Clinical examination reveals mastoid tenderness and perforation of the tympanic membrane. If this infection were to burst out through the medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid, which of the following conditions would ensue?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever, profuse ear discharge, mastoid tenderness, and perforation of the tympanic membrane is suggestive of acute mastoiditis, which has most likely occurred as a complication of acute infection of the middle ear. If this infection is to burst out through the medial side of the tip of the mastoid, it results in the formation of Bezold abscess.

Acute mastoiditis is used to refer to an acute infection that spreads from the mucosa, lining the mastoid air cells, to involve the bony walls of the mastoid air cell system.

The image below shows a picture of acute mastoiditis:

Blood leukocytes and ESR is raised. CT scan of the temporal bone shows clouding of air cells due to the collection of exudate in them. In later stages, a cavity may be seen in the mastoid. Treatment is done by administration of intravenous antibiotics and if indicated, surgical procedures such as myringotomy and cortical mastoidectomy.

Abscesses in Relation to mastoid infection are:

  • Bezold abscess lies deep to the sternocleidomastoid and presents as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw and is seen in the upper part of the posterior triangle or the parapharyngeal space

The images below show a picture of Bezold abscess:

 

Other abscesses in relation to mastoid infection:

  • Post auricular abscess - it is the most common abscess that forms over the mastoid. In infants and children, this presents over the MacEwen’s triangle.
  • Zygomatic abscess - infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma
  • Luc abscess (meatal abscess) -  the pus breaks through the bony wall between the mastoid antrum and external auditory meatus
  • Citelli’s abscess - the abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone

questions.text: A researcher is studying the difference in the incidence of asthma in children who are exposed to second-hand smoke and those who are not. If he wishes to express the additional incidence of asthma in the exposed children as a percentage, which of the following should he use?
questions.solution:
The researcher may use attributable risk to express the increased incidence of asthma in the exposed children.

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It is often expressed as a percentage. The terms "risk difference" or "cumulative incidence difference" refers to attributable risk.

Other Options:

Option B: Relative risk (RR) is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.

Option C: Population-attributable risk is the incidence of the disease (or death) in the total population minus the incidence of disease (or death) among those who were not exposed to the suspected causal factor. Population attributable risk is measured by multiplying attributable risk with the population prevalence of exposure.

Option D: Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome in case-control studies.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: A minor surgery was planned for a 60 year-old-man. His preoperative serological tests showed Anti-HBsAg positive. All other serological markers were negative. What is the probable treatment required?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, anti-HBsAg alone is positive, which is seen in immunized individuals. The patient does not require any treatment.

The presence of anti-HBs can imply recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection, as well as successful vaccination against hepatitis B. In a patient who is fully immunized against hepatitis B:

  • Anti-HBs- positive
  • HBsAg- negative
  • Anti-HBc- negative

Antiviral drugs such as tenofovir and entecavir can be initiated when there is HBsAg positivity with evidence of cirrhosis, abnormal ALT (Alanine transaminase), and HBV DNA titer >20,000 IU/mL.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

questions.text:
Which cyclin-CDK (cyclin-dependent kinase) combination is essential for the G2 to M phase transition of cell cycle?

G2 - Gap 2
M - Mitotic
questions.solution:
Cyclin B-CDK1 combination is essential for the G2 to M phase transition.

Cell cycle progression is driven by the formation of complexes of proteins called cyclins and associated enzymes known as cyclin-dependent kinases. Cyclins are synthesized only during the cell cycle to regulate the progression of the cell across the phases of the cell cycle, while cyclin-dependent kinases are constitutively present irrespective of the cell cycle.

Cyclins D, E, A, and B appear sequentially during the cell cycle and bind to one or more CDKs.

  1. G1-S transition: Cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6, and cyclin E-CDK2
  2. S-phase: Cyclin A-CDK1 and cyclin A-CDK2
  3. G2-M transition: Cyclin B-CDK1

CDK inhibitors (CDKIs) enforce the cell cycle checkpoints. There are several families of CDKIs:

  • CDKIs that broadly inhibit multiple CDKs: p21, p27, p57
  • CDKIs that inhibit CDK4 and CDK6: p15, p16, p18, and p19

Related Pearl: Cell Cycle Regulators and Associated Cancers

Cell cycle regulator

Proto-oncogene

Mode of activation in tumor

Associated tumor

Cyclins

CCND1 (Cyclin D1)

Translocation

Amplification

Mantle cell lymphoma, multiple myeloma

Breast and esophageal cancers

Cyclin-dependent kinase

CDK4

Amplification or point mutation

Glioblastoma, melanoma, sarcoma

questions.text:
Assertion: Fluid-fluid sign in MRI is not specific for Aneurysmal Bone cyst.
Reason: Fluid-fluid sign can also be seen in GCT and Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Fluid-fluid sign in MRI, though characteristically is seen in the Aneurysmal Bone cyst, is not specific for it because it can also be seen in other conditions including GCT and Telangiectatic Osteosarcoma.

 

Other conditions that show the fluid-fluid sign in MRI:

  • simple bone cysts
  • giant cell tumours
  • chondroblastoma
  • telangiectatic osteosarcomas

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with complaints of defective night vision in both the eyes for the past 5 years. She also adds that her hearing ability is worsening day by day. The audiogram shows the sensorineural type of hearing loss in both her ears. Given below is her fundus picture. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The fundus picture has the bony spicule pattern of pigmentation of the retinal periphery, as seen in retinitis pigmentosa. This when combined with sensorineural type of hearing loss as given in the clinical scenario is suggestive of Usher syndrome.

Systemic associations with pigmentary retinal dystrophy:

Usher syndrome (Most common) Sensorineural deafness + RP
Bardet–Biedl syndrome (Previously called Lawrence–Moon–Biedl–Bartum Syndrome)  Polydactyly, obesity, mental handicap, and kidney disease + RP
Kearn–Sayre syndrome Ocular myopathy and heart disease + RP
Refsum Syndrome Varied skin as well as neurological and visceral features + RP
Bassen–Kornzweig syndrome Abetalipoprotenemia and acanthocytosis + RP
Neuropathy, ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa (NARP) Neuropathy and Ataxia + RP

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female patient diagnosed with migraine visited her doctor and noticed a new drug, rimegepant, on one of the migraine pamphlets. Which of the following information would have been correctly mentioned in the pamphlet?
  1. Orally administered
  2. CGRP Receptor Agonist
  3. Used for treatment of an acute attack of migraine
  4. Can also be used for migraine prophylaxis
  5. Major side effect associated is nausea
questions.solution:
Rimegepant is a recently approved orally-administered CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) receptor antagonist used in the treatment of an acute attack of migraine with or without aura. It is not effective for migraine prophylaxis.

The major side effect associated with the drug is nausea. Because it is metabolized by CYP3A4, concomitant administration with CYP3A4 inducers/inhibitors is avoided. It is also avoided in Child-Pugh C Cirrhosis as it is hepatically metabolized. 

Other CGRP Receptor Antagonists

  • Rimegepant
  • Ubrogepant
  • Erenumab

Rimegepant and ubrogepant are used only for the treatment of an acute attack of migraine while erenumab is only indicated for prophylaxis of migraine in adults.

CGRP Antagonists (Anti-CGRP Ligand Monoclonal Antibody): (Used for migraine prophylaxis)

  1. Eptinezumab
  2. Galcanezumab (Also used for the treatment of episodic cluster headache)
  3. Fremanezumab

Related Pearl: FDA approved drugs in 2019

Drug

Description, mechanism of action and usage

I. Autonomic nervous system

1. Prabotulinum toxin A -xvfs

It is a botulinum toxin type A, which is produced from the fermentation of Clostridium botulinum.

It blocks the neuromuscular transmission by inhibiting the release of acetylcholine.

It is indicated for the temporary improvement in the appearance of moderate to severe glabellar lines associated with corrugator and/or procerus muscle activity in adult patients.

2. Solriamfetol

It is a dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (DNRI).

Used to treat excessive daytime sleepiness in patients with narcolepsy or obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).

II. Central nervous system

1. Brexanolone

It is a neuroactive steroid gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) A receptor positive modulator, which is chemically identical to endogenous allopregnanolone.

Used to treat postpartum depression (PPD) in adult women.

2. Lumateperone tosylate

It is an atypical antipsychotic indicated for the treatment of schizophrenia.

3. Lemborexant

It is an Orexin receptor antagonist used in the treatment of insomnia.

4. Siponimod

It is a sphingosine1-phosphate receptor modulator.

It binds to S1P receptors 1 and 5, and blocks the capacity of lymphocytes to egress from lymph nodes, thereby, reducing the number of lymphocytes in peripheral blood and may involve reduction of lymphocyte migration into the central nervous system.


It is indicated for the treatment of relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis (MS).

5. Istradefylline

It is an adenosine receptor antagonist, which has a xanthine derivative structure. 


It is indicated as adjunctive treatment to levodopa/carbidopa in adult patients with Parkinson’s disease (PD) experiencing “off” episodes.

6. Cenobamate

It is a carbamate derivative used in the treatment of partial-onset seizures in adult patients.

7. Ubrogepant

It is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist. 

Used for acute treatment of migraine with or without aura.

III. Cardiovascular system

1. Caplacizumab -yhdp

It is a von Willebrand factor (vWF)-directed antibody fragment. 

It targets the A1 domain of vWF, and inhibits the interaction between vWF and platelets, thereby reducing both vWF-mediated platelet adhesion and platelet consumption.

It is indicated for the treatment of adult patients with acquired thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (aTTP), in combination with plasma exchange and immunosuppressive therapy.

2. Tafamidis meglumine

It is a selective stabilizer of transthyretin (TTR).

It binds to the TTR at the thyroxine-binding sites, thereby stabilizing the tetramer and slowing dissociation into monomers, which is the rate-limiting step in amyloidogenic process.

Used for the treatment of the cardiomyopathy of wild type or hereditary transthyretin-mediated amyloidosis (ATTR-CM) in adults to reduce cardiovascular-related mortality or hospitalization.

3. Ferric maltol

It is an orally administered, iron replacement product containing 30 mg of iron in a stable ferric state and 201.5 mg of maltol in the form of trimaltol ligand.

Used for the treatment of iron deficiency anemia.

4. Luspatercept – aamt

It is an erythroid maturation agent. 

It binds several endogenous TGF-β superfamily ligands, thereby diminishing Smad2/3 signaling and thereby promoting maturation and differentiation of erythroid precursors.

It is indicated for the treatment of anemia in adult patients with beta thalassemia who require regular red blood cell (RBC) transfusions.

5. Crizanlizumab-tmca

It is a selectin blocker humanized IgG2 kappa monoclonal antibody that binds to P-selectin and blocks interactions with its ligands including P-selectin glycoprotein ligand 1.

It is indicated to reduce the frequency of vasoocclusive crises in patients with sickle cell disease.

6. Voxelotor

It is a hemoglobin S polymerization inhibitor.

It binds to HbS and increases the affinity of Hb for oxygen and thereby dose-dependent inhibition of HbS polymerization. 

Used to treat sickle cell disease. 

IV. Respiratory system

Combination of elexacaftor/ ivacaftor/ tezacaftor

It is a combination of ivacaftor, a CFTR potentiator, tezacaftor, and elexacaftor indicated for the treatment of cystic fibrosis (CF) in patients aged 12 years and older who have at least one F508 del mutation in the CFTR gene.

V. Gastrointestinal system

Tenapanor

It is a sodium/hydrogen exchanger 3 (NHE3) inhibitor.

It causes local inhibition of NHE3, which is an antiporter expressed on the apical surface of the small intestine and colon primarily responsible for the absorption of dietary sodium. As a result, it reduces the sodium absorption from these sites, and thereby causes an increase in water secretion into the lumen. 

Used to treat irritable bowel syndrome with constipation (IBS-C).

VI. Endocrine system

Romosozumab- aqqg

It is a humanized monoclonal antibody (IgG2) produced in a mammalian cell line (Chinese Hamster Ovary) by recombinant DNA technology

It binds to and inhibits the action of sclerostin(a regulatory protein in bone metabolism), and thereby increases bone formation and reduces bone resorption.

Used to treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women at high risk of fracture. 

VII. Autacoids

1. Pitolisant

It is an antagonist/inverse agonist of the histamine-3 (H3) receptor. 

Used to treat excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) in adult patients with narcolepsy.

2. Lasmiditan

It is a serotonin (5-HT) 1F receptor agonist.

It is used for the acute treatment of migraine with or without aura in adults. 

VIII. Antimicrobials

1. Triclabendazole

It is an antihelminthic drug that acts against the fasciola species.

Used to treat fascioliasis in patients 6 years of age and older.

2. Combination of imipenem, cilastatin, and relebactam

It is a combination of imipenem, a penem antibacterial, cilastatin, a renal dehydropeptidase inhibitor, and relebactam, a beta­ lactamase inhibitor.

It is approved for use in the treatment of complicated urinary tract infections and complicated abdominal infections caused by susceptible gram-negative bacteria.

3. Cefiderocol

It is a cephalosporin antibacterial drug with activity against Gram-negative aerobic bacteria. 

It exerts bactericidal action by inhibiting cell wall biosynthesis through binding to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs).

It is indicated for the treatment of patients with complicated urinary tract infections who have limited or no alternative treatment options.

4. Pretomanid

It is an oral nitroimidazooxazine antimycobacterial agent.

It is used in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid for the treatment of adults with pulmonary extensively drug-resistant (XDR), treatment-intolerant or nonresponsive multidrug-resistant (MDR) tuberculosis (TB). 

5. Lefamulin

It is a semi-synthetic pleuromutiilin antibacterial agent.

It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by interacting with the A- and P-sites of the peptidyl transferase center (PTC) in domain V of the 23s rRNA of the 50S subunit. 

In vitro, it is bactericidal against S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae and M. pneumoniae (including macrolide-resistant strains), and bacteriostatic against S. aureus and S. pyogenes.

Used in the treatment of community-acquired bacterial pneumonia (CABP). 

IX. Anticancer drugs

1. Erdafitinib

It is a kinase inhibitor.

Used for the treatment of locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma, that has:

  •  susceptible FGFR3 or FGFR2 genetic alterations and
  • progressed during or following at least one line of prior platinum-containing chemotherapy including within 12 months of neoadjuvant or adjuvant platinum-containing chemotherapy.

2. Enfortumab vedotin-ejfv

It is a Nectin-4-directed antibody and microtubule inhibitor conjugate.

It is  indicated for the treatment of adult patients with locally advanced or metastatic urothelial cancer who have:

  • previously received a programmed death receptor-1 (PD-1) or programmed death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) inhibitor, and 
  • a platinum-containing chemotherapy in the neoadjuvant/adjuvant, locally advanced or metastatic setting.

3. Darolutamide

It is an androgen receptor (AR) inhibitor.

It acts by competitively inhibiting of androgen binding, AR nuclear translocation, and AR-mediated transcription.

Indicated for the treatment of patients with non-metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.

4. Alpelisib

It is a kinase inhibitor acting against phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K), mainly PI3Kα.

It is used in combination with fulvestrant for the treatment of breast cancer.

5. Fam-trastuzumab deruxtecan-nxki

It is a HER2-directed antibody and topoisomerase inhibitor conjugate.

It is used in the treatment of adult patients with unresectable or metastatic HER2-positive breast cancer who have received two or more prior anti-HER2-based regimens in the metastatic setting. 

6. Selinexor

It is a nuclear export inhibitor.

It blocks exportin 1 (XPO1), and thereby reversibly inhibits nuclear export of tumor suppressor proteins (TSPs), and oncoproteins, such as c‐myc and cyclin D1. This leads to accumulation of these substances causing cell cycle arrest, and apoptosis of cancer cells. 

It is used to treat  patients with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM)

7. Polatuzumab vedotin-piiq

It is a CD79b-directed antibody–drug conjugate. It consists of three components: 

  • IgG1 monoclonal antibody
  • Anti-mitotic agent called MMAE (monomethyl auristatin E), and
  • A protein cleavable linker called mc-vc-PAB

The IgG1 component binds to the binds to CD79b, a B-cell specific surface protein and gets internalized into the cell. The lysosomal enzymes then cleaves the linker mc-vc-PAB, causing release of MMAE. The MMAE then binds to the microtubules and kills dividing cells by inhibiting cell division and inducing apoptosis.

It is used in combination with bendamustine and rituximab product for the treatment of  relapsed or refractory diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. 

8. Zanubrutinib

It is kinase inhibitor acting against Bruton’s tyrosine kinase (BTK).

BTK is a signaling molecule on B-cell, and plays a role in B-cell proliferation, trafficking, chemotaxis, and adhesion. Inhibition of BTK activity leads to inhibited malignant B-cell proliferation and reduced tumor growth.

It is used for the treatment of adult patients with mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) who have received at least one prior therapy.

9. Fedratinib

It is a kinase inhibitor that acts against wild type and mutationally activated Janus Associated Kinase 2 (JAK2) and FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 (FLT3). 


It is used to treat intermediate-2 or high-risk primary or secondary (post-polycythemia vera or post-essential thrombocythemia) myelofibrosis (MF).

10. Pexidartinib

It is a kinase inhibitor that mainly targets the following:

  • Colony stimulating factor 1 receptor (CSF1R)
  • KIT proto-oncogene receptor tyrosine kinase (KIT), and
  • FMS-like tyrosine kinase 3 (FLT3) harboring an internal tandem duplication (ITD) mutation.

Used for the treatment of symptomatic tenosynovial giant cell tumor (TGCT) associated with severe morbidity or functional limitations and not amenable to improvement with surgery.

11. Entrectinib

It is a kinase inhibitor that acts against tropomyosin receptor tyrosine kinases (TRK), proto-oncogene tyrosine-protein kinase (ROS1), and anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK).

It is used in the treatment of:

  • Adult patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) whose tumors are ROS1-positive.
  • Adult and pediatric patients 12 years of age and older with solid tumors.

X. Dermatological Drugs

1. Risankizumab-rzaa

It is a humanized immunoglobulin G1 (IgG1) monoclonal antibody.

It binds to the P19 subunit of IL-23 cytokine and inhibits its interaction with IL-23 receptor. IL-23 is involved in inflammatory and immune responses.

It is indicated for the treatment of moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis in adults who are candidates for systemic therapy or phototherapy.

2. Trifarotene

It is a retinoid used for the topical treatment of acne vulgaris in patients 9 years of age and older. 

3. Afamelanotide

It is a melanocortin receptor agonist and binds predominantly to MC1-R.

It is used to increase pain-free light exposure in adult patients with a history of phototoxic reactions from erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP).

4. Givosiran

It is a double-stranded small interfering RNA (siRNA) that acts against the aminolevulinate synthase 1 (ALAS1) mRNA in hepatocytes. 

The siRNA is covalently bound to N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues, which enables the delivery of siRNA to hepatocytes. The siRNA through RNA interference causes degradation of ALAS1 mRNA and reduces its levels in the liver, thereby reducing the circulating levels of neurotoxic intermediates aminolevulinic acid (ALA) and porphobilinogen (PBG).

It is used for the treatment of adults with acute hepatic porphyria (AHP). 

XI. Dyes and radioactive agents

1. Brilliant Blue G Ophthalmic Solution

It is an ophthalmic solution containing brilliant blue G (BBG) dye that selectively stains the internal limiting membrane (ILM), which makes it easier to visualize the membrane for removal.

2. Air polymer-type A

Air polymer-type A intrauterine foam, is an ultrasound contrast agent.

It is formed by mixing the clear Gel with air and sterile purified water, creating an echogenic contrast agent. When visualized with ultrasound, the foam appears echogenic or bright within the fallopian tubes and peritoneal cavity.

It is indicated for sono hysterosalpingography to assess fallopian tube patency in women with known or suspected infertility.

3. Fluorodopa F-18

It is a radioactive diagnostic agent used in PET imaging to visualize dopaminergic nerve terminals in the striatum for the evaluation of adult patients with suspected Parkinsonian syndromes (PS).

4. Ga-68-DOTATOC

It is a radioactive diagnostic agent that consists of Gallium-68 and octreotide. It specifically binds to somatostatin receptors of subtype 2 (sstr2).

It is indicated for localization of somatostatin receptor-positive neuroendocrine tumors (NETs).

XII. Other drugs

1. Upadacitinib

It is a is a Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitor.

It is used in the treatment of patients with moderately to severely active rheumatoid arthritis who have had an inadequate response or intolerance to methotrexate.

2. Golodirsen

It is an antisense oligonucleotide that binds to exon 53 of dystrophin pre-mRNA.

It is used in the treatment of patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) who have a confirmed mutation of the DMD gene that is amenable to exon 53 skipping. 

3. Brolucizumab–dbll

It is a recombinant human vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitor.

It binds to VEGF-A and inhibits the interaction with VEGFR-1 and VEGFR-2 and thereby suppresses endothelial cell proliferation, neovascularization, and vascular permeability.

Used for the treatment of Neovascular (Wet) Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD)

4. Bremelanotide

 

  

It is a melanocortin receptor agonist.

It is used in the treatment of generalized hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD), which is not due to existing medical or psychiatric conditions, relationship issues, or drug abuse.

questions.text: A patient presents with an amoebic liver abscess. He does not have any diarrhea or blood in his stool. His only complaint is vague abdominal pain. On examination of stool, cysts of Entamoeba histolytica are present. How would you treat this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with an amoebic liver abscess and cysts in stool needs treatment with metronidazole (or tinidazole) + a luminal amoebicide like paromomycin, diloxanide furoate, or iodoquinone.

As metronidazole is so well absorbed in the gut, the levels may not be therapeutic in the colonic lumen. The drug is also less effective against cysts. Therefore, patients with amoebic colitis or amoebic liver abscess should receive a luminal agent in addition.

Note: Albendazole is an antihelmintic drug, used to treat hydatid cyst, roundworms, hookworm, etc.

questions.text: What is the type of joint found in the manubriosternum?
questions.solution:
The Manubriosternal joint is a secondary cartilaginous joint. 

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

  • Synarthrosis - structures are connected by a fibrous band of tissue. Example: 1st sternocostal joint
  • Synchondrosis/primary cartilaginous joints. Example: costochondral joints
  • Symphysis/secondary cartilaginous joints. Example: Manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints 
  • Synovial joints - the presence of these helps the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:
    • Interchondral joint
    • Sternocostal joint
    • Costovertebral joint
    • Costotransverse joint

Secondary cartilaginous joints are characterized by the presence of a fibrocartilaginous disc that connects the articular surfaces, which are covered by a thin layer of hyaline cartilage. These joints are considered permanent. Examples of secondary cartilaginous joints include the symphysis pubis, the manubriosternal joint, and the intervertebral joints between the vertebral bodies.

Synchondrosis refers to the primary cartilaginous joints in which the advancing areas of ossification are separated by hyaline cartilage. They are temporary joints and are associated with growth. Hyaline cartilage has the ability to ossify with age, thus making these joints undergo synostosis once the growth is complete. An example of this type of joint is the epiphyseal plate. 

Synarthrosis - structures are connected by a fibrous band of tissue. E.g, 1st sternocostal joint

Syndesmosis refers to a type of joint where bones are connected by true fibrous tissue. In some cases, this connection is established through an interosseous ligament, as seen in the tibiofibular syndesmosis and radioulnar syndesmosis. In other instances, the connection is formed by a dense fibrous membrane, particularly in the posterior region of the sacroiliac joint.

questions.text: A child was born with membranes around the body and had ectropion and eclabium. He is brought to the OPD with lesions covering his face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture shows a neonate encased in a shiny, parchment-like membrane (collodion baby) suggestive of a disorder belonging to the autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum.

Ichthyosis vulgaris is not a part of this disease spectrum. It does not present at birth and is therefore an unlikely diagnosis.

Ichthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant condition caused due to a mutation in the filaggrin gene (FLG). It develops in the first few months of life. Patients exhibit accentuated palmar and plantar creases and have dry scaly skin. The scales appear light grey and cover the extensor surfaces of the limbs and the trunk. It usually spares the groin and larger flexures. Immunohistochemistry reveals an absent or markedly reduced filaggrin signal.

Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum includes the following:

  • Harlequin ichthyosis (HI)
  • Bathing suit ichthyosis (BSI)
  • Lamellar ichthyosis (LI)
  • Congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE)
  • Self- improving congenital ichthyosis (SICI)
  • Transient manifestations, such as collodion baby.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient with flaccid bullae over his face and erosions over his oral mucosa. An immunofluorescence study of his lesions revealed the following picture. Which of the following is false regarding the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The immunofluorescence pattern shown above the characteristic f fish-net appearance, suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. Nikolsky’s sign is positive, not negative, in these patients. 

This fish-net appearance of pemphigus vulgaris is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3 more than Dsg1), which are present inter-cellularly. Direct immunofluorescence of skin sample with anti-IgG shows intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis, in a  characteristic fishnet/chickenwire appearance.

Pemphigus is a group of chronic immunobullous disorders, that are characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins expressed in the skin and mucous tissue.

Desmosomal proteins like desmogleins 1 and 3 help in cell-cell adhesion and form the structure of the desmosome. In the epithelium, desmoglein 1 is mostly seen in all layers, while desmoglein 3 is more in the lower layers. In the oral mucosa, desmoglein 3 is seen in all layers and desmoglein 1 is present at low levels. The target antigens and the antibodies involved in the common variants of pemphigus are:

Type of pemphigus Target antigens Antibody isotype  On direct immunofluorescence
Pemphigus
vulgaris		 - Desmoglein 3 more than desmoglein 1
- Desmocollins		 - IgG
- C3		 - Intercellular
Pemphigus
vegetans		 - Desmoglein 3 more than desmoglein 1
- Desmocollins		 - IgG
- C3		 - Intercellular
Pemphigus
foliaceous

- Desmoglein 1 more than desmoglein 3
- Desmocollins

  - IgG
- C3		 - Intercellular
Paraneoplastic
pemphigus 

Multiple:
- Desmogleins
- Desmoplakin
- Envoplakin
- Periplakin

 - IgG - Intercellular
- Subepidermal 

Clinical features of pemphigus vulgaris are:

  • Oral lesions: Ill‐defined, irregular, slow to heal, erosions extending peripherally along with shedding of the epithelium.

The image given below shows oral lesions seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

  • Mucosal lesions: Occur in conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, oesophagus, urethra, vulva or cervix
  • Cutaneous lesions:
    • Occur in the scalp, face, neck, upper chest and back.
    • Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid, contents may become turbid
    • Either arise on normal skin or an erythematous base
    • Rupture of blisters producing painful erosions
    • Healing occurs without scarring
    • Pigmentary change may occur in resolving lesions.
  • Nail dystrophies, acute paronychia and subungual hematomas are common
  • Phenotypic and immunological conversion from pemphigus vulgaris to foliaceous or vice versa may occur, occasionally.
  • Effect on pregnancy: Deteriorate in pregnancy and the puerperium, with severe pemphigus associated with fetal prematurity and death.

The features associated with the common variants of pemphigus are:

Type of pemphigus Cutaneous distribution Mucosal involvement Lesions
Pemphigus
vulgaris		 - Scalp, face, chest, upper trunk
- May be generalised

- Oro‐pharynx, conjunctiva, genital

 

- Flaccid blisters
- Erosions
- Flexural vegetations
Pemphigus
vegetans		 - Flexural aspects

- Oro‐pharynx, conjunctiva, genital

- Vegetating plaques
- Vesicles
- Pustules
- Erosions
Pemphigus
foliaceous		 - Scalp, face, chest, upper back, seborrheic areas
- May be generalised 		 - None  - Scaly papules
- Crusted erosions
- Erythroderma 
Paraneoplastic
pemphigus 		 - Upper body
- Palmoplantar 		 - Severe mucositis - Polymorphous bullae
- Erosions
- Target lesions

 

The image given below shows the lesions seen in pemphigus foliaceous.

The image below shows the lesions seen in pemphigus vegetans.

Acantholysis and cell apoptosis are the key pathological processes in pemphigus. Histological changes include:

  • Intercellular oedema with loss of intercellular attachments in the basal layer is the earliest change
  • Suprabasal epidermal cells separate from the basal cells to form clefts and blisters.
  • Basal cells remain attached to the basement membrane, in a ‘row of tombstones’ on the floor of the blister.
  • Blister cavities contain rounded‐up acantholytic cells, also seen in Tzank smears.

The image given below shows the row of tombstone appearance seen in pemphigus.

The image given below shows the round acantholytic cells seen in pemphigus, on a Tzanch smear.

Nikolsky's sign is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing an erosion, seen in acantholytic diseases like pemphigus.

Systemic corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for controlling the disease, improving the quality of life and reducing disease activity. Other steroid-sparing drugs that are used to reduce the dose of steroids include:

  • Azathioprine
  • Mycophenolate mofetil
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Rituximab

Other patterns seen on Direct Immunofluorescence in Vesiculobullous disorders are:

Linear Pattern (shore-line fluorescence pattern): 

  • Due to linear IgG and C3 deposits along the DermoEpidermal Junctions (DEJ): Bullous Pemphigoid, Cicatricial Pemphigoid, Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.
  • Due to linear deposits of IgA at DEJ: Linear IgA dermatosis

Focal granular deposits of IgA at papillary tips seen in dermatitis herpetiformis

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient who underwent an HSCT 2 weeks back has now presented with an infection. Which of the following is the least likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
JC virus is associated with late infections that present > 6months after an HSCT, and they are very rare. So, for this patient who is suffering from an early infection post-HSCT, it is the least likely to be the etiological agent.

 

The likely list of etiological agents for an early infection post HSCT includes:

  • Skin and mucous membranes infection by HSV
  • Gastrointestinal tract infection by clostridium difficile
  • Lung infection by Aerobic bacteria (gram-negative/positive), Candida, Aspergillus, other molds, HSV
  • Disseminated Aerobic bacteria (gram-negative/positive)

 

Common Sources of infection after hematopoietic Stem cell Transplantation

 

PERIOD AFTER TRANSPLANTATION

MIDDLE (1-4 MONTHS)

LATE (>6 MONTHS)

VZV, HPV (warts)

Pneumocystis, Nocardia, S. pneumoniae

Gastrointestinal tract

CMV, adenovirus

EBV, CMV

HHV-6, Toxoplasma
