CMV, HHV-6

CMV, HHV-6

CMV- cytomegalovirus

EBV - Epstein-Barr virus

HHV-6 - human herpesvirus type 6

HPV - human papillomavirus

HSV - herpes simplex virus

VZV - varicella-zoster virus.

questions.text: You are a doctor posted in the emergency medicine department. There is an intubated patient who had been in a road traffic accident. Your PG examines him and tells you that the Glasgow coma scale (GCS) is 4 NT. Which of the following can the patient have?

choices.text: Eye opening to painful stimulus and withdrawal to pain
Eye opening to pressure and extension of limbs
Localizes pain and no eye opening
Eye opening to sound and flexion of limbs

questions.solution:
A patient who has eye opening to pressure (2) and extension of limbs (2) will have a GCS of 4. Because he is intubated, verbal response is not testable.

Option A: Eye opening to painful stimulus (2) and withdrawal to pain (4) gives a GCS of 6.

Option C: Localizes pain (5) and no eye opening (1) gives a GCS of 6.

Option D: Eye opening to sound (3) and flexion of limbs (4) gives a GCS of 7.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following snakes produce neurotoxic venom?
questions.solution:
Cobra and Krait produce neurotoxic venom.

Patients present with vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, heaviness of the eyelids, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, hyperacusis, dizziness, and ‘gooseflesh’. Paralysis first presents with ptosis followed by external ophthalmoplegia. Later, paralysis of the muscles of the face, palate, jaws, tongue, and neck can occur. Respiratory failure can occur due to airway obstruction at this stage or later due to paralysis of the intercostal muscles and diaphragm. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of snake venom

Snake Toxicity Main features

Viperidae

  • Pit viper
  • Saw-scaled viper
 Vasculotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Severe
    • Edema and necrosis
  • Anticoagulant effect: widespread bleeding

Elapidae

  • Cobra
  • Krait
 Neurotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Mild
  • Neurotoxicity leads to muscle paralysis

Hydrophidae (sea snakes) are now considered a subfamily of Elapidae

 Myotoxic Generalized rhabdomyolysis

Saw scaled viper:

Green pit viper:

Common krait:

King cobra:

Sea snake:

Related Pearl: Difference between Poisonous and Non- Poisonous Snakes

 

Poisonous snake

Non poisonous snake

Belly scales

Large and it covers the entire belly

Small and do not cover the entire belly

Head scales

Small

Large

Fang

Long and canalised

Short and solid

Tail

Compressed

Not markedly compressed

Habits

Nocturnal

Not so

Bite

Two fang marks

A number of small teeth marks in a row

Related Pearl: Identification of Poisonous Snakes

Snake Identification
 Common Cobra  Hooded with spectacle mark
King cobra Hooded without spectacle mark
Common krait Single/double white bands on body
Russell viper
Three rows of diamond shape black/brown spots.

questions.text: A senior resident in the hospital is performing the following clinical examination as shown in the image below. Which of the following structures will not be visible to him?
questions.solution:
The senior resident would not be visualizing the arytenoids as he is performing a posterior rhinoscopy indicated by the post-nasal mirror that he is holding.

The posterior rhinoscopy mirror (St. Clair Thompson mirror) has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.

The structures seen in the posterior rhinoscopy are:

  • Adenoids
  • Posterior ends of nasal turbinates
  • Opening of the Eustachian tube
  • The posterior border of the nasal septum
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller
  • Torus tubarius
  • The upper surface of the soft palate

The images below show the posterior rhinoscopy mirror and structures seen in the posterior rhinoscopy: 

Indirect laryngoscopy is done using a laryngeal mirror. It is straight without any bends with a mirror at the end.

Structures seen during indirect laryngoscopy (in order): 

  • Oropharynx: Base of the tongue, lingual tonsils, valleculae, medial and lateral glossoepiglottic folds.
  • Laryngopharynx: Both piriform fossae, post cricoid region, posterior wall of laryngopharynx.
  • Larynx: Epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, arytenoids, cuneiform and corniculate cartilages, glossoepiglottic folds, pharyngoepiglottic folds, aryepiglottic fold, true and false vocal cords, anterior commissure, posterior commissure, subglottis and rings of the trachea.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant with dysmorphic facies was brought to the clinic with complaints of recurrent bacterial infections of the skin, mouth, and respiratory tract. Interestingly, the baby has a Bombay blood group. Which of the following is likely to be associated with the underlying condition in this infant?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation points towards a diagnosis of leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD)- type 2, which results from defective fucose incorporation. Craniofacial dysmorphism and the Bombay blood group are features unique to LAD-2.

LAD-2 is also known as the congenital disorder of glycosylation II-C. This abnormality prevents the incorporation of fucose into various cell surface glycoproteins, including the carbohydrate structure Sialyl Lewis X, which is critical for the rolling and adhesion of neutrophils to vascular endothelium.

Other options:

Option A- Defective β2 integrin occurs in LAD-1 in which steady adhesion of leukocyte to endothelial surfaces is defective. Some of the characteristics seen in LAD-1 are delayed separation of the umbilical cord, recurrent pyogenic infections with onset in the first week of life, infections caused by Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, absent pus formation, and periodontitis. 

Option C- Defective kindlin-3 gene, which affects integrin activation cascade, is seen in LAD-3. LAD-3 is characterized by a Glanzmann thrombasthenia-like bleeding disorder, delayed separation of the umbilical cord, and skin and soft tissue infections similar to those seen in LAD-1.

Option D- Defective lysosomal traffic regulator (LYST) gene in chromosome 1 is associated with Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS). Patients have light skin and silvery hair. They frequently complain about recurrent infections, photosensitivity, photophobia, infections, and neuropathy. 

Note:

Both LAD and CHS are autosomal recessive disorders. 

Related Pearl: Defects in Leukocyte Function

Disease

Defect

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1

Mutations in β chain of CD11/CD18 integrins

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 2

Mutations in fucosyltransferase

Chediak–Higashi syndrome

Decreased leukocyte functions because of mutations affecting protein involved in lysosomal membrane traffic (LYST)

Chronic granulomatous disease

Defect in gene encoding phagocyte oxidase

Myeloperoxidase deficiency

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system

questions.text: A physician is studying parameter x. She checks the parameter x of all patients using an automated apparatus and compares them to manual checking (considered by her as the gold standard). For patient A, she finds that the automated apparatus and manual checking give very different values. However, on checking 5 times with the automated apparatus, all 5 values obtained are similar to each other. What can be concluded about the automated apparatus?
questions.solution:
The automated apparatus has low validity (accuracy) but high precision.

Validity (accuracy) refers to what extent the test accurately measures which it sets out to measure. It refers to the closeness with which measured values agree with "true" values. The values obtained by the automated apparatus are very different from the true values, reducing the validity of the automated apparatus readings.

Precision (reliability or reproducibility) is a measure of repeatability of a test. That is, the test must give consistent results when repeated more than once on the same individual or material, under the same conditions. The 5 values obtained by the automated apparatus are close to each other, making it precise.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

questions.text: There is a small school in a village, which has students from class 1-10. The classrooms are overcrowded and the area around the school is not clean. To ensure there is no breakout of tuberculosis, which of the following methods should the school adopt as primary prevention?

choices.text: Start ATT for those that are smear positive

questions.solution:
Reducing overcrowding in classrooms is a primary prevention method. Primary prevention is action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes/reduces the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Ex: Improving standard of living, vaccination, etc.

Other Options:

Option A: Starting ATT for those that are smear-positive would be secondary prophylaxis 

Option C: Educating children is a primordial prevention method. It aims to prevent  development of risk factors.

Option D: Screening symptomatic children with Mantoux is a secondary prevention method.

questions.text: The health survey and development committee started which of these?
questions.solution:
The health survey and development committee (or Bhore committee) started the 3 million plan. The 3 million plan (a long term plan) was aimed to set up primary health units with 75-bedded hospitals for each 10,000 to 20,000 population and secondary units with 650-bedded hospitals, again regionalized around district hospitals with 2,500 beds.

Other Options:

Option A: The village health guide scheme was proposed by Shrivastav committee.

Option B: The integration of health services was proposed by Jungalwallah committee.

Option C: The multipurpose worker scheme was by Kartar Singh committee.

questions.text: A 53-year-old female patient, who is a known case of chronic suppurative otitis media with cholesteatoma underwent a modified radical mastoidectomy with columella tympanoplasty. As per the Wullstein's classification, what type of tympanoplasty is performed on her?
questions.solution:
The columella tympanoplasty is type 3 as per the Wullstein's classification of tympanoplasty.

While performing this procedure, the diseased ear would have already lost the malleus and incus, and hence the graft is placed over the stapes superstructure. Therefore, it is also called myringostapediopexy.

Related Pearl: Zollner and Wullstein’s classification/ Types of tympanoplasty

Type Findings Procedure
Graft placed over
Type I (or) Myringoplasty All ossicles are intact Over/ under remnant TM over the handle of malleus
Type II Malleus eroded Over the remnant malleus/ incus
Type III (or) Columella (or) Myringostapediopexy Malleus & incus absent Over stapes superstructure
Type IV (or) Cavum minor All ossicles eroded Over ET and the round window, leaving mobile footplate exposed
Type V (or) Fenestration surgery Fixed footplate An opening made in the lateral semicircular canal (an alternative pathway)
Type VI (or) Sono-Inversion --- The round window is left exposed and receives sound and the oval window is covered (reversed pathway)

Type III is called columella because it resembles the middle ear of birds. They have a single ossicle. Type VI is not part of the original Zollner-Wullstein classification. It is a recent addition.

Image showing different types of tympanoplasty:

SCC: Semicircular canal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of necroptosis?

choices.text: Begins similar to the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis
Causes recruitment of  RIP1 and RIP3 resulting in caspase activation
Terminal events include permeabilization of lysosomal membranes
Occurs during the formation of mammalian growth plate

questions.solution:
The genetic program that drives necroptosis does not result in caspase activation and hence, it is also sometimes referred to as caspase-independent programmed cell death.

Necroptosis:

This form of cell death is a hybrid that shares aspects of both necrosis and apoptosis.

It resembles necrosis morphologically and biochemically. Both are characterized by loss of ATP, swelling of the cell and organelles, generation of ROS, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and ultimately rupture of the plasma membrane.

It is triggered by genetically programmed signal transduction events that culminate in cell death.  In this respect, it resembles programmed cell death which is the hallmark of apoptosis. But in sharp contrast to apoptosis, it doesn't result in caspase activation.

  • Necroptosis begins similar to the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis. It starts with the ligation of TNFR1( Binding of TNF to TNFR1). Ligation of Fas can also trigger necroptosis.
  • Ligation of TNFR1 recruits RIP1 and R1P3 (receptor-associated kinases 1 and 3) into a multiprotein complex that also contains caspase 8.
  • Caspases are not activated and as in necrosis, the terminal events include permeabilization of lysosomal membranes, generation of ROS, damage to the mitochondria, and reduction of ATP levels.

Necroptosis is being recognized as an important death pathway both in physiologic and pathologic conditions. It occurs during the formation of the mammalian growth plate. It is also seen in steatohepatitis and pancreatitis.

Note: Necroptosis starts like apoptosis and ends like necrosis.

questions.text:
During the clinical examination of a patient, you notice this clinical finding shown in the image. Which of the following conditions should you suspect in this patient?

 

  1. Phenylketonuria
  2. Hashimoto thyroiditis
  3. Polycystic ovary syndrome
  4. Gastric cancer
  5. Breast cancer
questions.solution:
The image shows velvety dark patches in axilla suggestive of acanthosis nigricans. Acanthosis nigricans may be associated with all of the above-mentioned conditions.

 

Acanthosis nigricans is a dermatosis that manifests as asymptomatic and symmetrical darkening of the skin. It is seen in the skin of intertriginous areas, in particular the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck.

Disorders associated with acanthosis nigricans:

  • Acromegaly and gigantism
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Diabetes
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Systemic sclerosis
  • Wilson syndrome
  • Gastric cancer
  • Gallbladder and bile duct cancer
  • Bladder cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Gynecological cancer

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true or false with respect to the development of the interatrial septum:
  1. The septum secundum develops to the left side of the septum primum
  2. The floor of the fossa ovalis represents the septum primum
  3. The limbus fossa ovalis represents the septum secundum
  4. The ostium secundum is located on the lower part of septum primum
  5. Ostium secundum formation occurs via necrosis
questions.solution:
The septum secundum develops to the left side of the septum primum - False

The septum secundum develops to the right side of the septum primum

The floor of the fossa ovalis represents the septum primum - True

The limbus fossa ovalis represents the septum secundum - True

The ostium secundum is located on the lower part of septum primum - False

The foramen secundum (ostium secundum) is present at the upper part of the septum primum

Ostium secundum formation occurs via necrosis - False

Septum primum perforates by apoptosis, not necrosis, to form ostium secundum 

Related Pearl: Development of Interatrial septum

  • The Inter-atrial septum develops from Septum Primum and Septum Secundum
  • The septum primum begins to develop at 28 days. It is a thin, crescentic fold of endocardium that arises craniodorsally and grows down to the AV cushions, leaving an ostium primum below its free edge.
  • Septum primum fuses with the AV cushions at approximately 35 days, obliterating the ostium primum.
  • The ostium secundum is an opening in the upper part of the septum primum. It forms at about 33 days, i.e., before the ostium primum closes.
  • The septum secundum is a thick muscular septum that arises to the right of the septum primum. It grows from the roof of the atrium but does not reach the AV cushion. The gap between the two septa is known as foramen ovale.
  • After birth, the foramen ovale is obliterated by the fusion of the septum primum with the septum secundum.
  • In terms of adult anatomy, the annulus ovalis/limbus of fossa ovalis is the lower free edge of the septum secundum, while the floor of fossa ovalis represents the septum primum.

questions.text: A 36-year-old nulliparous woman presents with menorrhagia for 3 months. The first day of her last menstrual period (LMP) was 3 weeks ago. She undergoes a Pap smear which shows atypical glandular cells of unknown significance. How would you proceed with further management?

choices.text: Schedule an endometrial and cervical sampling

questions.solution:
The pap smear shows atypical glandular cells in a woman aged ≥35 years should proceed with an endometrial and cervical sampling.

Atypical glandular cells on a Pap smear usually signify underlying cervical or endometrial neoplasia. The glandular abnormality is evaluated by doing a colposcopy and endocervical curettage. Endometrial biopsy is also needed in the following cases to be certain that the endometrial cells originated in the endometrium:

  • Female patients ≥ 35 years.
  • Female patients < 35 years, and a risk factor for endometrial diseases like abnormal uterine bleeding(AUB) or anovulation.

Other options:

Options A & D: Since the atypical glandular cells are seen on a pap smear, we need to sample the endometrium and cervix to see from where the cells have originated. Colposcopy will help in locating abnormal areas and accurately obtaining a directed biopsy from the suspicious areas on the cervix. Hence, only an endometrial biopsy or only colposcopy(Option D) is not sufficient.

Option B: Loop electrosurgical excision procedure is an acceptable option for patients who have moderately severe to severe dysplasias. As the pap smear shows atypical glandular cells, colposcopy with endocervical curettage and endometrial sampling is required before an excisional procedure is considered. 

 

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a relapsing Multiple Sclerosis was prescribed a recently marketed drug called ozanimod. Which of the following statements is false regarding this drug?

choices.text: It is a  sphingosine 1-phosphate receptor modulator
It is contraindicated in relapsing remitting Multiple Sclerosis

questions.solution:
Ozanimod is in fact indicated for the treatment of relapsing-remitting Multiple Sclerosis

Ozanimod is a sphingosine 1-phosphate receptor modulator indicated for the treatment of relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis (MS), and also clinically isolated syndrome, relapsing-remitting disease, and active secondary progressive disease, in adults.

The route of administration of ozanimod is oral. It is contraindicated to be used in those that have had a recent MI/stroke/TIA and also those with decompensated heart failure, or uncorrected rhythm abnormalities. 

The common side effects encountered include increased risk of infection, hypertension, orthostatic hypotension, and increased transaminase levels.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. She also complains of blurry vision and headache. On examination, erythema, edema, and a few black, necrotic areas are seen. The diagnosis is made and treatment is started immediately, with the first line drug indicated. Which of the following adverse effects is not classically seen due to the drug used?
questions.solution:
This diabetic patient with nasal discharge, eye pain and necrotic areas most likely has mucormycosis. The drug of choice is amphotericin B. The adverse effects of amphotericin B include: An acute febrile reaction (fever, chills, rash), nephrotoxicity, normocytic anemia, and hypokalemia.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: A patient with a complex psychiatric history is on a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. She visits her primary care physician with increasing depression. The physician adds a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Which of the following is she most likely to develop?

choices.text: Fever, rigidity, dilated pupils, and hyperreflexia
Fever, dystonia, rigidity and normal pupils
Fever, normotonia, dilated pupils and normal reflexes
Fever, rigidity, normal pupils and reduced bowel sounds

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of fever, rigidity, hyperreflexia, and dilated pupils are seen in the patient who is on a MAO inhibitor +  SSRI. It is due to the development of serotonin syndrome.

Serotonin syndrome occurs due to the concurrent administration of an SSRI with an MAO-inhibitor, L-tryptophan, or lithium, raising plasma serotonin concentrations to toxic levels. This serious and possibly fatal syndrome with the symptoms 

  • diarrhea, diaphoresis, flushing, mydriasis, salivation
  • restlessness
  • extreme agitation, hyperreflexia, and rapid fluctuations in vitals
  • myoclonus, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, rigidity; and eventually
  • delirium, status epilepticus, cardiovascular collapse, and death. 

Treatment involves removing the offending agent and supportive care. 

Related Pearl: Psychiatric emergency: Fever with altered mental status

questions.text: In which of the following patients is it least advisable for the following airway maneuver to be performed?

choices.text: A 44 year old patient that suddenly collapsed in his chair and is now unresponsive
A 9 year old child that suddenly collapsed during jogging and is now unresponsive
A 23 year old patient that fell from height and is now unresponsive
A 62 year old diabetic patient that collapse in the ward and is now unresponsive

questions.solution:
The airway manoeuvre shown is the head tilt and the chin lift. This should not be performed in those with a suspected cervical spine injury. It is prudent to exclude the manoeuvre from the medical plan of a patient who has suffered a cervical spine injury after a fall from a height. 

Basic life support (BLS) involves early recognition and management of emergencies such as heart attack, stroke, and foreign body airway obstruction. The sequence of BLS is circulation (chest compression), airway, and breathing.

The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. In such cases a head tilt, chin lift manouver may be performed. One hand (palm) is placed on the patient’s forehead, applying pressure to tilt the head back. Simultaneously, the chin is lifted with the forefinger and index finger of the opposite hand. This causes cervical flexion with an atlantooccipital extension (sniffing position). This lifts the tongue from the back of the throat. Head-tilt chin-lift should not be performed in a patient with suspected cervical injury.

A jaw thrust can be performed in a patient with cervical injury, but caution must be exercised to not hyperextend the neck. Both hands of the clinician are placed on either side of the patient’s head, and the angles of the jaw are grasped and lifted. It

questions.text:
Assertion: Hitzelberger sign is seen in large Acoustic Neuromas
Reason: Posterior wall of auditory canal also receives sensory fibers of CN VII through auricular branch of vagus.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Numbness of the posterosuperior meatal wall is known as the Hitzelberger sign. It is seen in acoustic neuroma as sensory fibers of the VII nerve will be affected. The posterior wall of the auditory canal receives sensory fibers of CN VII (through the auricular branch of the vagus) which is the reason for the manifestation.

So,

Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presents with complaints of unilateral blurring of vision and photophobia. On fundoscopic examination, the following picture is seen. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The characteristic “headlight in the fog” appearance is suggestive of Toxoplasmosis. It is called so because of the white inflammatory retinal nidus appearing as a headlight when viewed through an inflamed vitreous that resembles a fog.

Ocular toxoplasmosis

  • Toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular protozoan.
  • The cat is the definitive host, with intermediate hosts including mice, livestock, birds, and humans.
  • Ocular features
    • Toxoplasmosis constitutes 20–60% of all cases of posterior uveitis in immunocompetent individuals.
    • Reactivation at previously inactive cyst-containing scars is the rule in the immunocompetent.
    • A single inflammatory focus of fluffy white retinitis or retinochoroiditis associated with a pigmented scar ("satellite lesion") is typical.
    • "Headlight in the fog" is the classic description of a white retinal inflammatory nidus viewed through vitritis.
    • "Spill-over" anterior uveitis is common.
  • Treatment
    • Prednisolone (1 mg/kg) is given initially and tapered according to clinical response
    • Pyrimethamine is a folic acid antagonist, is administered as a loading dose of 75–100 mg for 1–2 days followed by 25–50 mg daily for 4 weeks in combination with oral folinic (not folic) acid 5 mg three times a week to retard thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and folate deficiency.
    • Sulfadiazine 1 g four times daily for 3–4 weeks is usually given in combination with pyrimethamine.
    • Intravitreal therapy with clindamycin (1 mg) and dexamethasone (400 μg) may be as effective as triple therapy in reactivated infection.

questions.text: A dead body was found in a forest. The postmortem change shown in the image below was prominently seen in the body. Which of the following features will not be present in the body at this time?

choices.text: A reddish frothy fluid coming out of nostrils and mouth

questions.solution:
The appearance shown in the image is marbling. Prominent marbling is seen in 36-48 hours after death. By this time, rigor mortis disappears.

Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours. It then passes off by 18-36 hours. 

Other changes which are seen in 36-48 hours after death:

  • Well distended abdomen
  • Features become bloated and distorted due to the accumulation of gases of decomposition
  • Breast, scrotum, and penis markedly distended
  • A reddish, frothy fluid may get forced out from the nostrils and mouth as the lungs are forced upwards due to the pressure of gases in the abdomen.
  • Appearance of maggots

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman at 14 weeks of gestation presents with vaginal discharge. She has no other complaints. On examination, greenish frothy discharge is present. No laboratory facilities are available. How would you proceed with management?

choices.text: Local treatment with clotrimazole vaginal pessary
Give oral secnidazole to the patient
Treat the patient and her husband with acyclovir

questions.solution:
The patient should be administered a single dose of secnidazole 2g orally as she has trichomonas vaginitis in her second trimester of pregnancy.

 

This patient in her second trimester of pregnancy has greenish, frothy vaginal discharge that is suggestive of trichomoniasis. However, since laboratory tests are not available, they cannot be confirmed. Using the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections, she should be treated with oral secnidazole.

An alternate option is to use Tab. Tinidazole 500 mg orally twice daily for 5 days.

Metronidazole pessary is preferred in the first trimester of pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text:
Assertion: Manroe chart is used for the absolute neutrophil count in very low birth weight neonates
Reason: Mouzinho chart is used for the absolute neutrophil count in term neonates

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Mouzinho chart is used for the absolute neutrophil count in very low birth weight neonates.

Manroe chart is used for the absolute neutrophil count in term neonates, not the other way round, as mentioned in the question. 

 

So,

Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.text: A 64-year-old hypothyroid female patient was examined for complaints of difficulty in breathing. The senior resident applied Gentle pressure on the lateral lobes of the thyroid which resulted in the patient developing stridor. This test performed by the senior resident is known as:
questions.solution:
This is called Kocher’s Test

Kocher’s Test: Done when one suspects pressure on the trachea. Gentle pressure on the lateral lobes of the thyroid causes stridor due to a narrow trachea. This test is positive in Multinodular Goitre and carcinoma infiltrating into the trachea.

Pizzilo’s Method: It is used to make the inspection of the thyroid gland easier, especially useful in obese short-necked individuals. The patient is asked to place the hands behind the neck and the patient is asked to push her head against the clasped hands on the occiput. 


Lahey's Method: Examiner stands in front of the patient and the lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the right lobe medially by the left hand and the left lobe is palpated with the right hand of the examiner.

The patient is asked to swallow while palpating the gland with the thumb. This gives a clear indication regarding the slight enlargement of the thyroid gland or small nodules. This is known as Crile’s Method.

questions.text:
Theme and focus: Causes of neurological signs

Lead in the question: For each of the following case scenarios, pick the appropriate cause from the list.

    1. Middle cerebral artery infarction
    2. Anterior cerebral artery infarction
    3. Posterior cerebral artery infarction
    4. Vertebrobasilar ischemia
    5. Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord
    6. Syringomyelia
    7. Cord compression
    8. Tabes dorsalis
questions.solution:
Case 1: Tabes dorsalis is a manifestation of syphilis, which occurs 10-35 years after primary infection. It occurs due to the degeneration of dorsal columns and nerve roots. The signs and symptoms include:

  • Impairment of proprioception and vibration sense
  • Argyll Robertson pupils
  • Muscular hypotonia Hyporeflexia
  • Hyporeflexia

Case 2: Abulia (lack of initiative), contralateral lower limb paresis, and urinary incontinence are all associated with carotid system and are seen in anterior cerebral artery infarction.

Case 3: The above clinical features are suggestive of sub-acute degeneration of the spinal cord. The condition is associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.

Related Pearl: Difference between various causes of ataxia

questions.text: A 28-year-old severely agitated male is brought to the emergency with a possible drug overdose.  On examination, he is diaphoretic, tachycardic, and tachypneic. His BP is 170/96 mmHg and his temperature is 101F. Seeing the constellation of symptoms, the senior resident orders a rapid urine screening test that checks for benzoylecgonine. Which of the following substances overdose does the senior resident suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The probable drug overdose that should be suspected in this patient is cocaine. Rapid urine screening tests for benzoylecgonine is a highly specific test used for cocaine overdose screening.

 

The clinical features of agitation, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and tachypnea, raised BP, and fever are all in favor of the diagnosis of a cocaine overdose in this patient. 

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance
Withdrawal symptoms
Intoxication features
Alcohol
Tremors, delirium, seizures
Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech
BZD
Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.
Opioid/ Heroin
Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.
Nicotine/ Tobacco
Increased appetite
Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.
Cocaine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.
LSD/ Haluccinogen
Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.
Phencyclidine (PCP)
Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with pain over his neck. History reveals he was involved in a road traffic accident yesterday but had not sought any medical help. Examination reveals neck muscle tenderness but no neurological signs or movement restriction. Further radiological investigations show no fracture or dislocation. What would be the grade of injury of this patient according to the severity grading system proposed by the Quebec Task Force on whiplash-associated disorders?
questions.solution:
The presence of muscle tenderness, along with the absence of other musculoskeletal or neurological signs, and the investigations revealing no fracture or dislocation point towards the patient having a grade 1 injury.

 

Quebec Task Force on whiplash-associated disorders - Grading of whiplash-associated injuries

 

Grade 0

No neck symptoms or signs

Grade 1

Neck pain, stiffness, and tenderness. No physical signs
Grade 2

Neck symptoms and musculoskeletal signs
Grade 3

Neck symptoms and neurological signs
Grade 4

Neck symptoms and fracture or dislocation

questions.text: A 37-year-old primi mother presents at 42+1 weeks of gestation saying she still hasn’t got labour pain. Which of the following is unlikely to be a cause of this?
questions.solution:
Twin gestation presents with preterm labour, not post-term like this lady.

Causes of post-term pregnancy:

  • Wrong dates (Most common)
  • Maternal age >35 years
  • Primipara
  • Sedentary lifestyle
  • Fetal anencephaly 
  • BMI > 25
  • History of post-term pregnancy with the patient's mother 
  • X-linked placental sulfatase deficiency

Of these factors, nulliparity and increased BMI are significantly associated with post-term pregnancy.

Note: In anencephaly, the fetal hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis is abnormal, there is diminished cortisol response and hence, labour doesn’t start.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs are to be avoided in a G6PD deficient patient?
  1. Primaquine
  2. Dapsone
  3. Phenytoin
  4. Colchicine
  5. Isoniazid
questions.solution:
Primaquine & Dapsone should be avoided in patients with G6PD deficiency. 

Phenytoin, isoniazid and colchicine are safe to use in G6PD deficient individuals as well. 

Drugs to avoid in G6PD Deficiency

  1. Sulfonamides - EX:- Sulfamethoxazole
  2. Antibacterials - Nitrofurantoin, Nalidixic acid, Dapsone, Mafenide cream
  3. Antimalarials - Primaquine, Pamaquine
  4. Analgesics - Phenacetin, Acetanilin, phenazopyridine
  5. Miscellaneous - Quinine, Flutamide, Methylene Blue, Rasburicase

questions.text: A 45-year-old old man presented with abdominal pain and slate grey pigmentation in his face and neck. On examination, he was found to have hepatomegaly. The liver biopsy section shows golden-yellow granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes and special staining with Prussian blue is as seen below.  Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Pancreas may show diffuse interstitial fibrosis and parenchymal atrophy leading to diabetes mellitus
Dilated cardiomyopathy due to hemosiderin granules within myocardial fibers
Disabling polyarthritis due to deposition of hemosiderin

questions.solution:
The image shows the Prussian blue-stained section of liver tissue showing extensive hemosiderin deposition stained blue. Parenchymal architecture is normal. The most likely diagnosis is hereditary hemochromatosis. Disabling polyarthritis in hemochromatosis is due to the deposition of Calcium pyrophosphate which damages the articular cartilage, referred to as Pseudogout.

Hemochromatosis is caused by excessive iron absorption, most of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas, followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs. When hemochromatosis results from an inherited disorder, it is referred to as hereditary hemochromatosis. The adult form of hemochromatosis is almost always caused by mutations of HFE located on the short arm of chromosome 6. 

Symptoms usually appear in the fourth to fifth decades of life in men and later in women. The principal manifestations of classic hemochromatosis include hepatomegaly, abdominal pain, abnormal skin pigmentation (particularly in sun-exposed areas), deranged glucose homeostasis, or diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of pancreatic islets, cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias, cardiomyopathy), and atypical arthritis.

In some patients, the presenting complaint is hypogonadism. The testes may be small and atrophic, secondary to a derangement in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis resulting in reduced gonadotropin and testosterone levels. 

A significant cause of death is hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: An HIV patient presented to the OPD with intractable diarrhea. On stool examination, the following red-stained oocysts against a blue background is observed and a diagnosis of Cryptosporidium parvum is made. Which feature of this parasite will help differentiate it from other coccidian parasites?

choices.text: It has feco-oral route of transmission
It causes disease in immunocompromised patients
Oocysts passed in the feces are immediately infectious

questions.solution:
Oocysts passed in the feces are immediately infectious in the case of cryptosporidium parvum, as they are sporulated oocysts.

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of coccidian parasitic infections which include Cryptosporidium, Cyclospora and Isospora. The image shows a blue background and small, red, spherical oocysts suggest modified acid-fast stain positive Cryptosporidium parvum.

Comparison of coccidian parasites

Similar features:

  • They cause diarrhea in an immunocompromised host
  • They are spread through oocystes by feco-oral transmission
  • They stain positive by Kinyoun's modified acid fast staining
  • They exhibit asexual mode of multiplication in intestine through sporozoites

Differentiating features:

Properties  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Isospora
Oocyst 4-6 μm, round contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round contains 2 sporocysts each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval contains two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection Uniformly acid-fast Variably acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

Treatment is with fluid replacement and supportive management. Cyclospora and Isospora can be successfully treated with cotrimoxazole. There is no definitive treatment for Cryptosporidium although nitazoxanide or paromomycin may be partially effective.

Note: In other coccidian parasites namely, cyclospora and isospora, unsporulated oocysts are passed in the stool. Unsporulated oocysts take days or weeks to become infectious. Also, because of this, person-to-person feco-oral transmission is unlikely to occur.

Modified acid-fast staining (like Kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis.

Kinyoun stain positive images of Isospora showing pink colored, acid fast oocyst:

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following cases as per wound class starting with the clean wound
  1. Perforated diverticulitis
  2. Enterotomy during bowel obstruction
  3. Elective Cholecystectomy
  4. Elective hernia repair
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 

4. Elective hernia repair

3. Elective Cholecystectomy

2. Enterotomy during bowel obstruction

1. Perforated diverticulitis

 

 

 

 

Wound Class, representative procedures and expected infection rates

WOUND CLASS

EXAMPLES OF CASES

EXPECTED INFECTION RATES

Clean (class I)

Hernia Repair,

Breast biopsy

1-2%

Clean / contaminated (class II)

Cholecystectomy, elective GI surgery (not colon)

2.1-9.5%

Clean / contaminated (class II)

Colorectal surgery

4-14%

Contaminated (class III)

Penetrating abdominal trauma, large tissue injury, enterotomy during bowel obstruction

3.4-13.2%

Dirty (class IV)

Perforated diverticulitis, necrotizing soft tissue infections

3.1-12.8%

Related Pearl: Surgical wound classifications as defined by ACS NSOP

  • Clean: Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered
  • Clean/Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination
  • Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks insterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered
  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

questions.text: A lactating mother was advised for an interruption in breastfeeding for 12-24 hours following the intake of a drug that she was prescribed by her family physician. Which of the following drugs is it likely to be?
questions.solution:
Interruption of breast-feeding for 12–24 h after a single 2-g dose of metronidazole is recommended due to the limited human data and potential toxicity even in divided doses. 

Cephalexin, clindamycin, and tetracyclines are compatible with breastfeeding. 

Drugs compatible with breastfeeding include:

  • Cephalosporins (including cephalexin, cefuroxime, cefixime, cefpodoxime, cefotaxime, ceftriaxone)
  • Clindamycin
  • Erythromycin
  • Penicillins (including amoxicillin, ampicillin, cloxacillin)
  • Amikacin
  • Gentamycin
  • Streptomycin
  • Tetracyclines

questions.text: A young man, during a property dispute, attacked his brother with an axe. His brother sustained a 14x7 cm laceration in the left thigh and fracture of the left femur shaft. The man who attacked is punishable under which of the following section of IPC?
questions.solution:
He should be punished under Section 326.

Section 326 - Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapon(imprisonment upto 10 years with fine).

Section 320 of IPC states that the following kinds of hurt only are designated as “grievous”:
  • Clause 1 — Emasculation.
  • Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye. 
  • Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  • Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
  • Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
  • Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
  • Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  • Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 20 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

Other options:

  • Section 320 - defines grievous hurt
  • Section 319 defines hurt (not grievous hurt).
  • Sec 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt (imprisonment upto 7 years with fine)

questions.text:
Match the following

Column A

  1. Clopidogrel
  2. Ticagrelor
  3. Tirofiban
  4. Vorapaxar 

 

Column B

  1. Thrombin (PAR-1) receptor antagonist

  3. Reversible P2Y12 inhibitors
  4. Irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors

The correct match is:

  1. Clopidogrel - Irreversible P2Y12 inhibitors
  2. Ticagrelor - Reversible P2Y12 inhibitors

questions.text: The structure marked by the red arrow arises from
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the musculocutaneous nerve. Its root value is C5, C6, C7 and it arises from the lateral cord.
The structure can be identified as a musculocutaneous nerve as it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in its course and also supplies the biceps brachii.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

Branches: 

 Parts 

Branches
Roots

Upper trunk

Nerve to Subclavius (C5, C6).

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7)

Lateral root of median nerve (C5-C7)

Medial pectoral (C8,T1)

Note : However Ulnar Nerve near its origin, often receives a communicating branch from the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord and carrying fibers from C7.

questions.text: An ICU patient with a central venous catheter developed sepsis. A bacterial skin commensal was found to be grown in the blood culture. Which of the following laboratory results is appropriate for the organism found in the blood culture?

choices.text: Catalase negative, coagulase negative, optochin sensitive
Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin resistant
Catalase positive, coagulase negative, novobiocin sensitive
Catalase negative, coagulase positive, bacitracin resistant

questions.solution:
Skin commensal responsible for catheter-related bloodstream infections are coagulase-negative Staphylococcus namely Staphylococcus epidermidis.

Staphylococcus epidermidis is catalase-positive, coagulase-negative, and novobiocin sensitive.

Novobiocin sensitivity distinguishes S. epidermidis from S.saprophyticus.

Related Pearl: List of intrinsic drug resistance in bacteria

 

Organism Intrinsic Drug Resistance

questions.text:
During the rounds in the NICU, you notice a lack of respiratory movements in a neonate. You would classify this as apnoea if:

A. It lasts > 20 seconds

B. Associated with cyanosis

C. Associated with bradycardia

D. Associated with Hypotonia

E. Associated with Hypertonia

choices.text: A, B and D are correct
A, C and E are correct
A, B and C  are correct
B, C and D are correct

questions.solution:
Apnea is defined as the cessation of breathing for longer than 20 sec, or for a shorter duration in the presence of bradycardia or change in skin color (pallor or cyanosis).

Apnea is a pathological cessation of breathing that results in hemodynamic disturbances and merits treatment.

In contrast, Periodic breathing is a normal event in preterm infants, that reflects the respiratory control system immaturity and does not merit any treatment. 30-45% of preterm neonates exhibit periodic breathing pattern characterized by three or more respiratory pauses of greater than 3 seconds duration.

Note:

Significant bradycardia is defined as heart rate <80 bpm and

Significant desaturation is defined as oxygen saturation <80-85%.

questions.text: A 35-year-old sexually active man presents with urethral discharge for 1 week. Giemsa stain of the causative organism in cell culture is given below. Which of the following is false about the causative agent?

choices.text: The reticulate body is the infectious form
Outer membrane proteins are the species-specific antigens

questions.solution:
The elementary body is the infectious form.

The given clinical presentation and Giemsa stain suggest chlamydia trachomatis genital infection. The elementary body is the infectious form of chlamydia, whereas the reticulate body is the reproductive form.

Chlamydia trachomatis:

  • Gram-negative bacteria
  • Obligate intracellular
  • Outer membrane proteins are the species-specific antigens
  • There are at least 15 serovars of chlamydia trachomatis
    • The trachoma biovars include A, B, C.
    • Genital tract biovars D to K.
    • Lymphogranuloma biovars include L1, L2, L3.
  • McCoy cell line is used to isolate chlamydia
  • Investigation of choice is Nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT)

questions.text: A 74-year-old male presents to the ER with fever, cough, and breathlessness. Examination reveals nonpurulent conjunctivitis, and diffuse pharyngeal erythema. Pulmonary auscultation reveals scattered rales and wheeze.  Blood investigations reveal leukopenia and further workup confirms the diagnosis. The physician puts him on intranasal zanamivir BD for 5 days.  Which of the following is the most common extrapulmonary manifestation of the underlying condition that this patient has?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is that of a patient suffering from Influenza and the most common extrapulmonary manifestation that occurs is myositis. 

Points in favor of a diagnosis of Influenza:

  • Fever, cough, and breathlessness
  • Nonpurulent conjunctivitis, and diffuse pharyngeal erythema.
  • Scattered rales and wheeze.
  • Leukopenia
  • Treatment with intranasal zanamivir BD for 5 days.

Myositis is characterized by severe muscle pain, and the muscles are tender to touch. Labs reveal elevated creatinine phosphokinase levels and a myoglobinuria that may lead to renal failure also. Interestingly, myositis is seen more often in the case of influenza B.

Myocarditis and pericarditis are less frequently associated and have been reported only in selected epidemics, but an excess cardiovascular hospitalization is often seen associated with an influenza epidemic. Post-infectious acute demyelination encephalomyelitis can follow an influenza infection.

questions.text:
Match the following

Column A

  1. Modified Bell's Staging
  2. Sarnat and Sarnat staging
  3. Expanded New Ballard Score
  4. Silverman Anderson Score

 

Column B

A. Newborn respiratory distress

B. Gestational Age assessment

C. Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy

D. Necrotizing Enterocolitis
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  1. Modified Bell's Staging - Necrotizing Enterocolitis
  2. Sarnat and Sarnat staging - Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy
  3. Expanded New Ballard Score - Gestational Age assessment
  4. Silverman Anderson Score - Newborn respiratory distress

 

 

 

Modified Bell's Staging Criteria for Necrotizing Enterocolitis

Stage   Intestinal signs Radiological signs Systemic signs
IA   Mild abdominal distention, emesis, and guaiac-positive stool. Normal or intestinal dilatation, mild ileus Temperature instability, apnea, bradycardia, and lethargy
IB   Bright red blood from the rectum Same as IA  
IIA Mildly ill Absent bowel sounds Pneumatosis intestinalis  
IIB Moderately ill  IIA + definite abdominal tenderness  IIA + portal venous gas, with or without ascites Metabolic acidosis and thrombocytopenia 
IIIA Severely ill, bowel
intact		  IIB + signs of generalized peritonitis  IIB + definite ascites Hypotension, bradycardia, disseminated intravascular coagulation and neutropenia.
IIIB Severely ill, bowel
perforated		  Same as III A  IIB +pneumoperitoneum  Same as III A

NEC stage I is suspected NEC; stage II is proven NEC, and stage III is advanced NEC.

 

Sarnat Staging of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE): 

Signs Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3
Level of consciousness Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose
Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid
Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate
Tendon reflex/clonus Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent
Myoclonus Present Present Absent
Moro reflex Strong Weak Absent
Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal,poor light reflex
Seizures None Common Decerebration
EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to seizure activity Burst suppression to isoelectric
Duration <24 hour if progresses; otherwise, may remain normal 24 hours to 14 days Days to weeks
Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits    

 

The expanded new Ballard score is used to assess the physical and neuromuscular maturity of the newborn and thereby calculate the gestational age.

  • There are six criteria each to assess physical maturity and neuromuscular maturity.
  • The physical maturity and neurologic maturity scores are added to calculate the gestational age.
  • It can be used to calculate gestational age from 20 to 44 weeks.

 

SILVERMAN ANDERSON SCORE for Respiratory distress in newborn:

Score

(Chest movement)

(Intercostal retraction)

 Grunt
0 Synchronized none none none none

questions.text: A statistician is working with a gynecologist on a study about “Awareness regarding Pap smear.” They administer a questionnaire with 50 questions to 200 women, and each correct response gets 1 point. They find that the data are positively skewed. Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively, of the same?
questions.solution:
In a positively skewed data set, mean>median>mode. Hence, here, the mean, median, and mode must be 25, 23, and 20, respectively. None of the other options is consistent with mean > median > mode.

The observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency is known as the mode. If there are two values that occur with the same greatest frequency, the distribution is bimodal. If there are more than two such values, the distribution becomes multimodal. 

When all the values are listed in order, the value that divides the distribution in half is known as the median. When there is an even number of values, the median is obtained by calculating the mean of the two middle scores.

The mean (average) is obtained by summing up all the values and dividing the obtained sum by the total number of values in the distribution.

Skewed distributions are the ones that have asymmetric frequency distributions. They can be identified as positive (right) or negative (left) according to the location of the tail of the curve. A positively skewed data set contains a large number of low scores but a small number of very high scores. It is demonstrated in the graph below:

 

Other options:

Option A: In a negatively skewed distribution, mean<median<mode.

Option C: In a normal distribution, mean=median=mode.

Option D: The set of values is not representative of either a normal or a skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with neurofibromatosis 1 (NF 1) brings her 9-year-old daughter to the pediatrician. She wants to know if the girl has NF 1. The presence of which of the following features would confirm NF 1 in the daughter?

choices.text: One iris hamartoma in the left eye

questions.solution:
The presence of one plexiform neurofibroma would confirm NF 1 in the daughter.

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) or von Recklinghausen's disease is an autosomal disease. NF1 is the most common of all neurofibromatosis. It is caused by a loss of function mutation, on the neurofibromin (NF1) gene. 

To diagnose neurofibromatosis 1, two or more of the following clinical manifestations should be present:

  • Six or more café-au-lait macules: > 5 mm in diameter in prepubertal and > 15 mm in diameter in postpubertal individuals
  • Axillary or inguinal freckling
  • Two or more iris Lisch nodules (hamartomas of iris)
  • Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma
  • A distinctive osseous lesion such as sphenoidal and tibial bone dysplasia
  • Optic gliomas
  • A 1st-degree relative with NF-1

The FDA has recently approved a new drug selumetinib, mitogen-activated protein kinase 1 & 2 inhibitors for the treatment of NF1 in pediatric patients who are 2 years or older with symptomatic, inoperable plexiform neurofibromatosis. It can help reduce tumor progression. 

Related Pearl: Chromosomal abnormalities and syndromes associated with brain tumors

malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, optic nerve gliomas,

hamartomatous lesions, pheochromocytomas.

Bilateral eighth nerve schwannomas, multiple meningiomas,

ependymomas of the spinal cord

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with severe abdominal pain which occurs around half an hour after taking food. He reports weight loss over the last 2 months. The patient is a known diabetic and smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. Which of the following investigations will be the most helpful in establishing the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given history of abdominal pain occurring half an hour after food with associated weight loss, in a diabetic patient who is a current smoker, points to a diagnosis of chronic mesenteric ischemia. The best investigation to establish this diagnosis is CT angiography.

Chronic mesenteric ischemia occurs due to atherosclerosis of superior mesenteric artery and coeliac trunk. Patients present with recurrent episodes of acute, dull abdominal pain 30 minutes to 1 hour following food intake. This pain is termed as intestinal angina. Often the patients report chronic diarrhea and weight loss due to malabsorption.

CT angiography remains the best investigation to assess the degree of atherosclerotic blockade of the vessel. Duplex ultrasound has also been shown to have good sensitivity and specificity as a screening investigation. Treatment is by angioplasty of the affected vessel. Bypass surgery is done if a longer vessel length is involved or if there is severe calcification.

questions.text: A group of people went for a picnic. All of them developed severe gastroenteritis within 40 minutes of eating  canned-tuna fish. They also had flushing, urticaria, palpitations, headache, dizziness, and sweating. Few of them developed bronchospasm, respiratory distress, and vasodilatory shock. Which of the following can be the aetiology of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestations and history suggest scombroid poisoning. It occurs after the ingestion of canned or smoked fish with high histamine levels due to improper storage. This is due to contamination with enteric gram-negative bacteria like Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Histamine produced due to decarboxylation of histidine in the muscles of the fish is responsible for the condition.

Symptoms are that of histamine poisoning. Symptoms usually begin within 10-90 minutes. Histamine does not change the smell or appearance of the affected fish.

Treatment involves antihistamines and supportive care.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male patient who had a myocardial infarction has a characteristic finding of Beau's line. Which of the following images accurately depict that finding?
questions.solution:
Image B shows Beau’s line, which are transverse grooves that are present on the nail and may be full or partial thickness through the nail. Transverse grooves may occur due to trauma, inflammation or neurological event, reflecting an acute systemic event (like MI, measles, mumps or pneumonia)

Other options :

  • Image A - Terry's Nails
  • Image C - Mees Lines
  • Image D - Lindsay's Nails

 

Terry's nails are a type of apparent leukonychia of nearly the entire nail, obliteration of the lunula, and a narrow band of normal, pink nail bed at the distal border.

Leukonychia striata also called as Mees lines or Aldrich–Mees lines which appear after an episode of poisoning with arsenic, thallium, or other heavy metals, and can also appear if the subject is suffering from renal failure.

Lindsay's nails, also known as Half and half nails show the proximal portion of the nail white and the distal half red, pink, or brown, with a sharp line of demarcation between the two halves. It is a rare but special clinical finding seen in chronic renal failure with a prevalence of 15-50%. It can also be seen in yellow nail syndrome, Crohn's disease, Kawasaki's disease, Behcet's disease, cirrhosis, hyperthyroidism, zinc deficiency, citrullinemia, pellagra, HIV infection, and even in healthy persons.

Related Pearl: Nail findings and associated systemic conditions

  • Lung cancer
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
  • Complicated tuberculosis
  • Suppurative lung disease (lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis)

questions.text: A young woman is being evaluated for anemia. The oral and eye examination findings are shown below. Which of the following investigations will be useful in diagnosing the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with its image showing cheilosis, angular stomatitis, a magenta-colored tongue, and corneal vascularisation, points to the diagnosis of riboflavin deficiency. RBC glutathione reductase activity will be useful in diagnosing this condition.

Riboflavin provides the reactive moieties of the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD). The main dietary sources of riboflavin are milk and dairy products.

The following signs and symptoms characterize the deficiency state of riboflavin:

  • Cheilosis- pallor in the angle of the mouth and fissuring of the lips, which extends radially to the skin.
  • Glossitis- the tongue becomes smooth, and there is a loss of papillae (magenta-colored tongue).
  • Eyes- keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation.
  • Other features- seborrheic dermatitis and anemia.

Note: Because of its intense yellow color, riboflavin is widely used as a food additive.

Other options:

Option A: RBC transketolase assay diagnoses vitamin B1/ thiamine deficiency. Thiamine deficiency mainly manifests as peripheral neuritis, beriberi, and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis.

Option B: The serum methyl malonate level is used to diagnose vitamin B12/ methylcobalamin deficiency. Patients typically present with anemia, peripheral neuropathy, and signs and symptoms of subacute combined degeneration, manifesting as loss of vibration and proprioception and absent deep tendon reflexes.

Option C: The RBC transaminase assay assesses glutamate levels inside RBCs. Human erythrocytes require a continual supply of glutamate to support glutathione synthesis, but this is not routinely tested.
