questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of alcohol abuse causes reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor?
questions.solution:
Naltrexone causes reduced reward response to drinking and reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor.

Before prescribing: Evaluate for possible current opioid use; consider a urine toxicology screen for opioids, including synthetic opioids. Obtain liver function tests and follow up periodically.

Acamprosate, naltrexone, and disulfiram are used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

Other options:

Option A: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine used in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal.

Option B: Acamprosate affects glutamate and GABA neurotransmitter systems, but its alcohol-related action is unclear.

Option D: Disulfiram inhibits the intermediate metabolism of alcohol which causes a build-up of acetaldehyde and a reaction of flushing, sweating, nausea, and tachycardia if a patient drinks alcohol.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the structure shown in the image below?
  1. Palatoglossus
  2. Genioglossus
  3. Hyoglossus
  4. Styloglossus
  5. Intrinsic Muscles of the tongue
questions.solution:
The structure can be identified as the hypoglossal nerve as it courses lateral to the internal and external carotid artery, facial artery. The nerve then ascends along the lateral surface of the hyoglossus muscle.


The hypoglossal nerve supplies all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except palatoglossus, which is supplied by the vago accessory nerve.

questions.text:
Assertion: During the resuscitation of a newborn with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated.

Reason: Bag and mask ventilation cause distension of the stomach.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

In fact, if the infant is known or suspected to have a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, a vented orogastric tube connected to continuous suction should be placed immediately after delivery to prevent bowel distension and further lung compression.

A key principle of successful delivery room resuscitation and stabilization in a neonate with congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the avoidance of high airway pressures.

So, both assertion and reasons are independently true/correct statements and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)
 

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the medicine OPD with cough and hemoptysis. The sputum culture done on the culture media is shown below. What is the usual method of sterilization used for this medium?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Lowenstein-Jensen medium. The medium is sterilized by inspissation.

Inspissation is used for the sterilization of heat-labile culture media containing eggs or serum. This method of sterilization involves heating at 80–85 °C for 30 minutes on 3 consecutive days. Another medium for which this method is used is Loeffler's serum.

Lowenstein–Jensen medium is commonly used, egg-based, selective culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Loeffler's serum slope is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Other Options:

Option B: Pasteurization - Milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes (the holder method) or at 72°C for 15–20 seconds (the flash process), followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower. 

Option C: Autoclaving is a method of sterilization by moist heat.

Option D: Hot air oven is a method of sterilization by dry heat.

Moist heat causes coagulation and denaturation of proteins, while dry heat causes oxidation and charring of proteins. Hence not preferred for egg-containing culture media like the Lowenstein-Jensen medium.

Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery
70% ethanol Disinfectant skin prior to venepuncture or immunisation
Thiomersal Preservative in vaccine

questions.text:
Which of the following are valid indications for transfusion FFP in a newborn?
  1. Enhancement of wound healing
  2. DIC
  3. Vitamin K deficiency associated bleeding
  4. Simple volume replacement
  5. Routine prevention of IVH
questions.solution:
DIC & Vitamin K deficiency associated bleeding are valid indications for FFP transfusion in a neonate.

 

Valid indications for FFP transfusion in a neonate are:

  1. DIC
  2. Vitamin K deficiency associated bleeding
  3. Neonates with clinically significant bleeding
  4. Prior to invasive procedures with a risk of significant bleeding when there is an abnormal coagulation profile
  5. Afibrinogenemia
  6. Von-Willebrand factor deficiency
  7. Congenital antithrombin III deficiency
  8. Protein C and Protein S deficiency when specific factor replacement is not available.

 

 

FFP should not be used for

  1. Simple volume replacement/expansion
  2. Enhancement of wound healing
  3. Routine IVH prevention 
  4. Correction of coagulation profile abnormalities when there is no evidence of bleeding

questions.text: Among the following women with bleeding per vaginum (PV) who are being evaluated, which would be diagnosed as secondary PPH?

choices.text: A 32 year old woman at 40 weeks gestation with spotting PV
A 26 year old woman who delivered twins vaginally 6 hours ago
A 29 year old woman who delivered a preterm baby 1 week ago
A 36 year old woman at 32 weeks gestation bleeding PV and pain

questions.solution:
Secondary PPH occurs beyond 24 hours and within puerperium. The only patient who fits this is patient C, who delivered a preterm baby 1 week ago and now has bleeding PV.

Causes of secondary PPH include: Retained bits of membranes, infection, endometritis, etc.

Other Options:

Options A and D: These women have antepartum haemorrhage. (APH): Bleeding after 28 weeks but before birth of the baby.

Option B: This woman has primary PPH: Bleeding within 24 hours following birth of the baby.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements true or false
  1. Dobutamine shows both α and β receptor agonism
  2. Yohimbine shows selective α2 receptor antagonism
  3. Tamsulosin and Alfuzosin show selective α1 receptor antagonism
  4. Oxymetazoline is a nonselective alpha-antagonist
  5. Albuterol is a selective β1 agonist
questions.solution:
• Dobutamine shows both α and β receptor agonism - True
  • Yohimbine shows selective α2 receptor antagonism - True
  • Tamsulosin and Alfuzosin show selective α1 receptor antagonism - True
  • Oxymetazoline is a nonselective alpha-antagonist - False. Oxymetazoline is a nonselective α receptor agonist
  • Albuterol is a selective β1 agonist - False. Albuterol is selective β2 agonist.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: A population of 1000 children under 10 years living in town X is studied. 200 children have been diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia and are treated. 5 years later, 180 children are alive and doing well. What is the survival rate?
questions.solution:
Survival rate in this case is 90%. Survival rate is defined as the proportion of survivors in a group, (e.g. of patients) studied and followed over a period (e.g. a 5-year period).

The formula of survival rate is given as follows: Total number of patients alive after 5 years/Total number of patients diagnosed or treated x 100

Here, 180 patients were alive at the end of 5 years, making the survival rate: 180/200 x 100 = 90%.

The survival rate is a method of describing prognosis in certain disease conditions. It can be used as a yardstick for the assessment of standards of therapy. Survival rates have received special attention in cancer studies.

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence
  • Notification rates
  • Attendance rates at OPD
  • Admission, discharge & re-admission rates
  • Duration of stay in hospital
  • Spells of sickness or absence from work or school

questions.text: The 8-year-old child with delayed development was referred for evaluation of recurrent infections. History is notable for the presence of congenital heart defects. Further examination reveals the presence of a cleft palate and workup reveals the presence of hypocalcemia.  Which component of the immune system is likely to be affected in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with developmental delay, recurrent infections with a history of congenital heart disease and examination revealing cleft palate and hypocalcemia point towards the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. Cell-mediated immunity is affected.

DiGeorge syndrome is a complex embryopathy with an autosomal dominant inheritance that is caused by microdeletions in the long arm of chromosome 22, leading to multiple developmental defects.

Children with DiGeorge syndrome have thymic hypoplasia resulting in T-cell immunodeficiency. The disease may range from mildly increased susceptibility to infections to a severe disease requiring a thymic or hematopoietic stem cell transplant. Patients are generally able to cope with extracellular bacterial infections because their innate and T cell-independent antibody responses are intact, but they cannot effectively eliminate intracellular pathogens such as viruses, intracellular bacteria, and fungi.

The clinical features of this syndrome include:

  • Congenital heart disease- aortic arch anomalies
  • Abnormalities of the palate like cleft palate.
  • Facial dysmorphisms such as hypertelorism, antimongoloid slant, low set ears, micrognathia, short philtrum, and bifid uvula.
  • Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T cell immunity. 
  • Parathyroid hypoplasia resulting in hypocalcemia (tetany).

Interestingly individuals with DiGeorge syndrome are at high risk for psychotic illnesses such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorders.

Diagnosis is established only by the detection of deletion in long-arm chromosome 22 by fluorescent in-situ hybridisation(FISH).

 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: You come across a report of a 48-year-old male patient and notice a peculiar pattern that both the AFP as well as the CEA are elevated. Which of the following conditions can this patient be having, that might have caused the patient's peculiar report?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis can be associated with a rise in AFP as well as CEA. 

 The rise in α Fetoprotein can be associated with

  • Neoplastic conditions like
    • Hepatocellular carcinoma
    • Gonadal germ cell tumor
  • Nonneoplastic conditions like
    • Cirrhosis
    • Hepatitis

The rise in Carcinoembryonic antigen can be associated with

  • Neoplastic conditions like
    • Adenocarcinomas of the colon, pancreas, lung, breast, ovary
  • Nonneoplastic conditions like
    • Pancreatitis
    • Hepatitis
    • Inflammatory bowel disease
    • Smoking

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with an unclear medical history presented with swelling around the left ankle joint and a left foot ulcer. He complains of instability of movement which is associated with minimal or no pain. Interestingly, the examination reveals, movements beyond normal limits and a loose bag of bones feel. X-Ray reveals obvious bone destruction and the presence of irregular calcified masses. The most probable cause of the underlying joint pathology in this patient is ______________
questions.solution:
The clinical picture indicates a neuropathic cause like Charcot arthropathy, which is most commonly caused by diabetes.

Points in favor of a diagnosis of Charcot arthropathy:

  • Swelling of ankle joint being associated with foot ulcer (?diabetic foot ulcer)
  • Instability of movement
  • Movements beyond normal limits and a loose bag of bones feel
  • X-ray that shows obvious bone destruction and the presence of irregular calcified masses

Diabetes is the most common cause of Charcot arthropathy, while tertiary syphilis was one of the common causes previously. Charcot's arthropathy can also be caused by the following: 

  • leprosy
  • dialysis
  • chronic alcoholism
  • spinal cord injury
  • syringomyelia
  • meningomyelocele

questions.text: A 49-year-old male is being evaluated for multiple lesions found in his spine. Which of the following conditions is least likely?
questions.solution:
Histiocytosis would be the least likely among the given list as the patient is 49 years old.

Histiocytosis would be considered in the differential diagnosis if the patient was less than 30 years old. Histiocytosis usually presents as a diaphyseal lesion common in ages 5-30.

Differential Diagnosis for Lesions of the Spine

Older than 40 Years Younger than 30 Years

■ Metastases

■ Multiple myeloma

■ Hemangioma

■ Chordoma (in sacrum)

 

Vertebral body

■ Histiocytosis

■ Hemangioma

 

Posterior elements

■ Osteoid osteoma

■ Osteoblastoma

■ Aneurysmal bone cyst

questions.text:
Mark the following statements true or false regarding anorexia nervosa
  1. The patient has a delayed release of insulin 
  2. The patient has an extremely low level of TSH
  3. Anorexia is associated with depression in >50%
  4. Loss of appetite is usually rare until late in the disorder
  5. Prerenal azotemia may be associated with Anorexia nervosa
questions.solution:
The patient has a delayed release of insulin - True

The patients with Anorexia nervosa have a delayed release of insulin and a decreased level of C Peptide. 

The patient has an extremely low level of TSH - False

The TSH levels in patients of Anorexia Nervosa is normal. Interestingly, the T4 and T3 may be slightly reduced and and the reverse T3 is slightly increased.  

Anorexia is associated with depression in >50% - True

Anorexia is associated with depression in about 65%, with social phobia in 35% and OCD in about 25%.

Loss of appetite is usually rare until late in the disorder - True

The term anorexia is a misnomer because the loss of appetite is usually rare until late in the disorder. In fact, the patient is constantly thinking about food and maybe collecting recipes, preparing elaborate meals for others, etc. 

Prerenal azotemia may be associated with Anorexia nervosa - True

 

 

The various systemic findings associated with anorexia nervosa are:

Anorexia Nervosa

Vital signs

Bradycardia, hypertension with marked orthostatic changes, hypothermia, poikilothermia

General

Muscle atrophy, loss of body fat

Central nervous system

Generalized brain atrophy with enlarged ventricles, decreased cortical mass, seizures, abnormal electroencephalogram

Cardiovascular

Peripheral (starvation) edema, decreased cardiac diameter, narrowed left ventricular wall, decreased response to exercise demand, superior mesenteric artery syndrome

Renal

Prerenal azotemia

Hematologic

Anemia of starvation, leukopenia, hypocellular bone marrow

Gastrointestinal

Delayed gastric emptying, gastric dilation, decreased intestinal lipase and lactase

Metabolic

Hypercholesterolemia, nonsymptomatic hypoglycemia, elevated liver enzymes, decreased bone mineral density

Endocrine

Low luteinizing hormone, low follicle-stimulating hormone, low estrogen or testosterone, low/normal thyroxine, low triiodothyronine, increased reverse triiodothyronine, elevated cortisol, elevated growth hormone, partial diabetes insipidus, increased prolactin

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to your OPD with severe constipation. After ruling out pathological causes, which of the following is the safest to prescribe?
questions.solution:
Lactulose is safe to use in pregnant women with constipation.

Constipation in pregnancy:

Constipation is a common occurrence in pregnancy because of dietary alterations, anatomic impingement of a large uterus on the rectosigmoid, fluid shifts, decreased exercise levels, and reduced mobility. Pregnancy and pregnancy-related constipation increases the risk for developing haemorrhoids.

Treatment options include

  • Dietary changes - increased water intake, increased fibre in diet
  • Gentle exercises
  • Laxatives - Lactulose, an osmotic purgative, and Ispaghula, a bulk forming agent, are safe to use in pregnancy. 

Senna, bisacodyl, docusates and saline laxatives’ safety is unknown and hence it is better to avoid them.

Note:

Laxatives are drugs that promote bowel evacuation.

Classification of Laxatives:

  • Bulk-forming agents 
    • Dietary fibre: Bran
    • Psyllium, Ispaghula, Methylcellulose
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: Phenolphthalein, Bisacodyl, Sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: Senna, Cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: Prucalopride
    • PG analogue: Lubiprostone
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulphate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulphate, phosphate
    • Sodium potassium tartrate
    • Lactulose
    • Lactitol

questions.text: Which of the following features are characteristic of a patient suffering from McArdle’s disease?

choices.text: Exercise-induced muscle cramps and weakness, Growth retardation, Hemolytic anemia

Exercise-induced cramps, Renal failure due to rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria, Second wind phenomenon
Muscle weakness, Fasting hypoglycemia, Hepatomegaly due to accumulation of branched-chain polysaccharide, Growth retardation

Exercise-induced cramps, Renal failure due to rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria, Second wind phenomenon are the features that are characteristic of McArdles Disease

questions.text: The most common gene mutation in autosomal recessive hereditary spherocytosis is:
questions.solution:
Most common gene mutation in autosomal recessive HS: Spectrin

Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by inherited defects in the proteins stabilizing the red cell membrane.

Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane.

This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The non-deformable spherocytes are trapped in the splenic cords and phagocytosed by macrophages.

Note:

  • Most common mode of inheritance of HS: Autosomal dominant
  • Most common gene mutation in autosomal dominant HS: Ankyrin > Band 3
  • Most common gene mutation in autosomal recessive HS: Spectrin
  • Most severe form of HS: Spectrin (recessive)

RBC Membrane-Cytoskeleton disorders:

 
Chromosomal Location Protein Produced Disease (Inheritance)
1q -alpha Spectrin HS (recessive)
    HE (dominant)
14q -beta Spectrin HE (dominant)
8p Ankyrin HS (dominant) (accounts for the majority of HS-65%)
17q Band 3 (anion exchange protein) HS (dominant)
    Southeast Asia ovalocytosis (dominant)
    Stomatocytosis
1p Band 4.1 HE (dominant)
15q Band 4.2 HS (recessive)
Abbreviations: HE, hereditary elliptocytosis; HS, hereditary spherocytosis

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complained of difficulty in the vision of her left eye for the past 1year. There were multiple episodes of pain in the same eye for many years even before she started experiencing this visual difficulty. IOP of the left eye is measured to be 40 mm Hg. Which of the following type of optic atrophy is expected in her?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of an advanced glaucoma in her left eye. The cavernous optic atrophy is classically seen in patients with an advanced glaucoma.

Related Pearl: Classification of optic atrophy

  • Simple optic atrophy: (Primary) Image below
    • Pathology lies in portion of optic nerve behind lamina cribrosa.
    • Causes are multiple sclerosis, neurosyphilis, and traumatic optic neuropathy.
    • Well defined disc margin and chalky white in color.

Post-neuritic optic atrophy: (Secondary)

  • Occurs after disc edema.
  • Causes are Papillitis and papilledema
  • Blurred disc margin and dirty white in color
  • Consecutive optic atrophy
    • Extensive pathology of retina.
    • Causes are retinitis pigmentosa and any cause of diffuse chorioretinitis
    • Well defined disc margin and pale waxy disc.
  • Glaucomatous optic atrophy/Cavernous optic atrophy:
    • 100% cupping
    • Bayonetting of vessels
    • Laminar dot sign

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with seizures. Her parents said this started 15 minutes back and has been continuous. Initial resuscitative measures are taken, and she is given lorazepam. However, her seizures didn’t subside. Which antiepileptic drug is indicated now?
questions.solution:
This patient with seizures for more than 15 minutes has status epilepticus. The treatment algorithm is shown below. According to this, this patient, who did not respond to lorazepam needs phenytoin.

Note: Status epilepticus is defined as continuous seizures or repetitive seizures with impaired consciousness in the interictal period.

The duration of seizure activity to meet the definition of status epilepticus has traditionally been specified as 15–30 min. However, a more practical definition is to consider status epilepticus as a situation in which the duration of seizures prompts the acute use of anticonvulsant therapy, i.e., more than 5 minutes.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the pathway that an electron takes in the Electron Transport Chain starting from NADH.

1.ATP synthase           

2.Cytochrome C Oxidoreductase           

3.Succinate dehydrogenase           

4.NADH dehydrogenase           

5.Cytochrome C oxidase
questions.solution:
Electrons travel via NADH dehydrogenase(Complex 1)-->Cytochrome C oxidoreductase(Complex III)-->Cytochrome C oxidase(complex IV)-->ATP synthase(complex V)

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient is diagnosed with dengue fever. He developed a saddleback fever. Which of the following is an accurate description of this fever pattern?

choices.text: Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is <0.6 °C
Acute fever followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then, the fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days
Fever lasts for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days
Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is >0.6 °C

questions.solution:
In the saddleback type fever, which is seen in dengue, acute fever followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then, the fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days.

Pel-Ebstein fever is a fever lasting for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days. (option C)

Continuous fever is characterised by the temperature remaining elevated, without touching the baseline, and the fluctuation not exceeding 0.6°C. This type of fever is seen in cases of lobar pneumonia, infective endocarditis, enteric fever, etc.(option A)

Remittent fever is characterised by temperature fluctuations exceeding 0.6°C, but without touching the baseline. (option D)

Relapsing fever is characterized by several days of fever, followed by several days of an afebrile period, after which the cycle repeats (e.g. Borrelia infection and rat-bite fever)

Tertian fever occurs on the first and third days. (e.g. infection with Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, and Plasmodium falciparum)

Quartan fever occurs on the first and fourth days. (e.g. Plasmodium malariae infection)

questions.text:
Assertion: Large family of Oxidoreductases using NAD(P)+/ NAD(P)H have evolved by using a Rossman fold domain
Reason: LDH is an Oxidoreductase that has a Rossmann fold domain in its C terminal.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Lactate dehydrogenase(LDH) shares a common N-terminal (Not C terminal) NAD(P)+-binding domain known as the Rossmann fold.

A large family of oxidoreductases that utilize NAD(P)+/ NAD(P)H for the oxidation and reduction of a wide range of metabolites have evolved by fusing a segment of DNA coding for a Rossmann fold domain to that coding for a variety of C-terminal domains.

Examples of such enzymes include:

  • formate dehydrogenase
  • alcohol dehydrogenase
  • glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase
  • malate dehydrogenase
  • quinone oxidoreductase
  • 6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase
  • d-glycerate dehydrogenase

Note: A domain is a section of the protein structure sufficient to perform a particular chemical or physical tasks such as binding of a substrate or other ligand.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements true or false regarding compartment syndrome:
  1. Absence of distal pulses is an early sign in compartment syndrome
  2. Compartment syndrome is never associated with open injuries
  3. Compartment pressure >25mm Hg is an immediate indication for fasciotomy
  4. Fasciotomy in compartment syndrome is best done using a transverse incision of skin fat and fascia
  5. In crush injuries with delayed presentation, urgent fasciotomy should be done always
questions.solution:
• Absence of distal pulses is an early sign in compartment syndrome - False
  • Compartment syndrome is never associated with open injuries - False
  • Compartment pressure >25mm Hg is an immediate indication for fasciotomy - False
  • Fasciotomy in compartment syndrome is best done using a transverse incision of skin fat and fascia - False
  • In crush injuries with delayed presentation, urgent fasciotomy should be done always - False

 

Compartment syndromes is characterized by severe pain, stretch pain, distal sensory disturbance, and, finally, by the absence of pulses distally, which is usually a late sign.

It can occur with an open injury if the wound does not extend into the affected compartment.

Compartment pressures constantly greater than 30 mmHg or the presence of the above clinical signs are indications for fasciotomy.

Fasciotomy is done using a Longitudinal incision of skin, fat, and fascia. 

In crush injuries that present several days later, a fasciotomy can be dangerous because dead muscle produces myoglobin which, if suddenly released into the blood stream causes myoglobinuria with glomerular blockage and renal failure. Therefore, for such injuries, it may be safer to amputate the limb once viable and non-viable tissues have been demarcated.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true or false with respect to the DeLancey three-level system of support of genital tract
  1. Uterosacral and the cardinal ligaments form the level II Delancey support
  2. Damage to level 1 support structures can cause uterine descent, enterocele, vault descent.
  3. Damage to pubocervical fascia and rectovaginal fascia can cause cystocele and/or rectocele.
  4. Urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum may result from damage to the level III support
  5. Clinically unrecognized damages in these supports can be detected better by CT than by MRI.
questions.solution:
• Uterosacral and the cardinal ligaments form the level II Delancey support - False
  • Damage to level 1 support structures can cause uterine descent, enterocele, vault descent - True
  • Damage to pubocervical fascia and rectovaginal fascia can cause cystocele and/or rectocele - True
  • Urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum may result from damage to the level III support - True
  • Clinically unrecognized damages in these supports can be detected better by CT than by MRI - False

 

Uterosacral and the cardinal ligaments form the level I(not level II) Delancey support. 

Clinically unrecognized damages in these supports can be detected better by MRI than by CT as these are soft tissue structures. 

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient with a known history of rheumatic heart disease, you notice a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex,  radiating to the axilla and back. Which of the following changes in the Murmur would you expect to see if the patient is made to squat from a standing position?

choices.text: Variable change depending on age of patient

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a patient with a known history of rheumatic heart disease, having a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex, radiating to the axilla and back indicates a probable diagnosis of Mitral Regurgitation. 

On squatting from a standing position, systemic vascular resistance, blood pressure, and cardiac size increase. Thus the intensity of murmur would increase

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text: Which anticoagulant is used for glucose determination of blood sample?
questions.solution:
Sodium fluoride is the anticoagulant used for blood glucose determination.

Fluoride is an inhibitor of the glycolytic enzyme Enolase. It prevents glycolysis in the blood sample.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A young patient presents with a foot drop. The nerve marked in the below image is affected. Identify the nerve.
questions.solution:
The nerve affected in this patient is the common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve). It descends obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa and medial to biceps femoris.

 

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. Patients with common peroneal nerve injury present with foot drop. On examination, there will be weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion of the foot. The sensation on the dorsum of the foot will be diminished.

Other options:

Option B- Sural nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation of the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third in the leg. In the foot, there is diminished sensation over the lateral malleolus and the lateral side of the fifth toe.

Option C- Saphenous nerve is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation in the skin over the patella, medial side of the leg, and medial side of the foot.

Option D- Tibial nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. It is derived from the anterior divisions of L4, L5, S1, S2, and S3. In the popliteal fossa, this nerve is overlapped by two heads of gastrocnemius. Damage to this nerve paralyzes gastrocnemius, plantaris, soleus, and popliteus muscles.

Related Pearl: Sciatic nerve divisions and supply

 
Sciatic nerve divisions and its supply 
Tibial division
Motor: 
semitendinous, semimembranous, long head biceps femoris, gastrocnemius popliteus, plantaris, soleus, tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, abductor hallucis, flexor digit­orum brevis, flexor hallucis brevis, addcutor hallucis, foot interossei, abductor digiti minimi.
 
Sensory: 
none
Peroneal division
Motor:
short head of biceps femoris, foot interossei, Tibialis anterior, Extensor Hallucis longus, Extensor digitorum longus and Peroneus tertius, Peroneus Longus, Peroneus Brevis.
 
Sensory:
articular branch to knee joint
sural nerve branch 
- closeby structure: saphenous vein, achilles tendon
- anastomoses: br. of peroneal nerve
- termination as: lateral dorsal cutaneous nerve

questions.text: Sequential arrange the structures involved in the baroreceptor reflex

choices.text: Stimulation of baroreceptors -> Excitation of caudal ventrolateral medulla -> Excitation of nucleus tractus solitarius -> Release of GABA -> Sympathetic inhibition
Stimulation of baroreceptors -> Excitation of nucleus tractus solitarius -> Excitation of caudal ventrolateral medulla -> Release of GABA -> Parasympathetic inhibition
Stimulation of baroreceptors -> Excitation of caudal ventrolateral medulla -> Excitation of nucleus tractus solitarius -> Release of GABA -> Parasympathetic inhibition
Stimulation of baroreceptors -> Excitation of nucleus tractus solitarius -> Excitation of caudal ventrolateral medulla -> Release of GABA -> Sympathetic inhibition

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the baroreceptor reflex is the Stimulation of baroreceptors -> Excitation of nucleus tractus solitarius -> Excitation of caudal ventrolateral medulla -> Release of GABA -> Sympathetic inhibition.

Note: Increased baroreceptor discharge inhibits sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart. This leads to vasodilation, venodilation, hypotension, bradycardia, and a decrease in cardiac output.

The afferent signals responsible for this reflex are carried by the glossopharyngeal (IX) and vagus nerves (X) as seen in the image below

The following pathway shows the inhibition of rostral ventrolateral medulla, which further causes inhibition of the sympathetic discharge and excitation of the nucleus ambiguous, thereby enhancing the firing of parasympathetic neurons by the baroreceptor reflex.

Related Pearl: Factors Affecting Heart Rate

Heart rate is accelerated by
  • Decreased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Increased activity of atrial stretch receptors
  • Inspiration
  • Excitement
  • Anger
  • Pain
  • Hypoxia
  • Exercise
  • Thyroid hormones
  • Fever

The Heart is slowed by
  • Increased activity of arterial baroreceptors
  • Expiration
  • Grief
  • Stimulation of pain fibers in trigeminal nerve
  • Increased intracranial pressure

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects of theophylline occurs when the serum concentration reaches higher than 35 microgram/ml?
questions.solution:
Arrhythmias and convulsions occur at concentrations of theophylline >35 microgram/ml.

Other Options:

Agitation and hypotension occur at concentrations > 25 microgram/ml, while delirium occurs when levels rise > 30 microgram/ml.

questions.text:
Assertion: β blockers should be continued for 7 days postoperatively in thyrotoxic patients prepared using β blockers.
Reason:  The last dose of carbimazole is given on the evening before surgery in thyrotoxic patients prepared for surgery using it.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
β blockers do not interfere with the synthesis of thyroid hormones, and hormone levels remain high during treatment and for some days after thyroidectomy. It is therefore important, β blockers should be continued for 7 days postoperatively.

 

Carbimazole, which is the drug of choice for preoperative preparation of a thyrotoxic patient, is stopped before the surgery, and the last dose is administered the evening before surgery.

 

So, Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

questions.text:
You are an intern in the gynecology department. You are asked to monitor all the patients requiring hormone replacement therapy (HRT). Which of these four patients would you prescribe HRT to?

TAH: Total abdominal hysterectomy

BSO: Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

choices.text: A 35-year-old woman who has undergone TAH+BSO
A 7-year-old girl who has Turner syndrome
A 47-year-old woman with hot flushes and history of breast cancer
A 60-year-old woman with a history of ischemic heart disease

questions.solution:
The 35-year-old woman who had undergone TAH+BSO (Total abdominal hysterectomy + Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy) is the only one who needs hormone replacement therapy (HRT).

Other Options:

Option B: This girl with Turner syndrome can receive HRT once she reaches adolescence.

Option C: HRT is contraindicated in this woman due to her history of breast cancer.

Option D: HRT is not indicated as a prophylactic measure against coronary artery disease. A woman with previous ischemic heart disease does not benefit from HRT, and its use is not recommended.

However, it may be useful in some cardiovascular diseases.

Indications for HRT:

  • Therapeutic: Symptomatic women who suffer from estrogen deficiency and adolescents with gonadal dysgenesis
  • Prophylactic: High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as cardiovascular disease, osteoporosis, Alzheimer’s disease, and colonic cancer
  • Premature menopause following hysterectomy, tubectomy, radiotherapy, chemotherapy

Contraindications for HRT:

  • History of breast cancer or uterine cancer or family history of cancer
  • Previous history of the thromboembolic episode
  • Liver and gallbladder diseases
  • Uterine fibroids—the fibroids may enlarge in size

questions.text: The most common manifestation that you would expect in a child infected by E. histolytica is:
questions.solution:
Asymptomatic cyst passage is the most common manifestation of E. histolytica.

 

Amebiasis:

  • Caused by Entamoeba histolytica
  • Trophozoites are responsible for tissue invasion and destruction.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Amebic Colitis
    • Colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements (6–8/day).
    • Diarrhea associated with tenesmus, heme-positive stool. Some may have only intermittent diarrhea alternating with constipation.
    • Trophozoites invade the intestinal mucosa, produce flask-shaped ulcers. 
  • Amebic Liver Abscess
    • It occurs in <1% of infected individuals.
    • Fever is the hallmark of amebic liver abscess.
    • It is associated with abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and enlargement and tenderness of the liver.
    • Changes at the base of the right lung, such as elevation of the diaphragm and atelectasis or effusion, may also occur.
    • The most common finding is a single abscess in the right hepatic lobe, detected on ultrasonography, computed tomography, or magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.text:
Assertion: Exercise is a common trigger of asthma, especially in children.
Reason:  Hyperventilation causes decreased osmolality in airway lining fluid and mast cell mediator release

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Exercise is a common trigger of asthma, especially in children.
This is because Hyperventilation causes increased(not decreased) osmolality in the airway lining fluid and mast cell mediator release which culminate in bronchoconstriction.

 

Exercise-induced asthma usually begins after the end of the exercise and spontaneous recovery in about 30 minutes is seen. It is worse in cold, dry climates than in hot, humid conditions. Preventive steps like prior administration of β2-agonists and antileukotrienes can be tried, but the best method is regular treatment with inhaled corticosteroids, which reduces the population of surface mast cells required for this response.

So,

The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement

questions.text: The likely diagnosis based on the serum electrophoresis image is:
questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates a sharp peak ("church spire” or M band) in the gamma globulin region. This is characteristically seen in a patient with multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma involves a malignant proliferation of plasma cells, resulting in excessive production of abnormal immunoglobulins, causing a spike called the M band.

Certain common diseases and their electrophoretic pattern:

Condition  Electrophoretic pattern
Chronic infections Smooth increase in gamma globulins
Multiple myeloma Gamma globulin part is increased (M BAND)
Liver cirrhosis Reduced albumin and compensatory increase in globulin
Primary immune deficiency Gamma globulin reduced
α1 antitrypsin deficiency α1 band is thin and even lost sometimes

questions.text: A professional violin player presents with well-defined plaques on his neck with comedones, lichenification, and pigmentation. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The lesion consistent with the given clinical history is acne mechanica, which is also known as fiddler's neck.

Acne mechanica describes acne that occurs at the site of repeated mechanical trauma and/or frictional obstruction of the pilosebaceous outlet resulting in comedone formation. Examples include fiddler’s neck, which may occur on the neck of violin players, and is characterized by well‐defined plaques with the presence of comedones, lichenification, and pigmentation.

Other Options:

Option B: Acne fulminans or acne maligna is a rare and severe destructive form of acne presenting primarily in adolescent males. It most frequently affects the trunk but can affect the face and presents acutely in association with systemic symptoms.

Option C: Acne conglobata represents a rare and severe form of acne characterized by multiple and extensive inflammatory papules, tender nodules, and abscesses that commonly coalesce to form malodorous draining sinus tracts.

Option D: Acne excoriee is regarded as a self‐inflicted skin condition in which the sufferer compulsively picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face. It is predominantly seen in adolescent girls. 

Other psychiatric disorders associated with acne are

  • A small number of patients with body dysmorphic disorder have acne as their prime symptom. The perceived acne is out of proportion to physical signs.
  • Acne has been reported in anorexia nervosa. Acne itself may be a predisposing factor for anorexia in vulnerable teenage age groups who adopt a diet in an attempt to control their acne. 

Related Pearl: Important Syndromes Related to Acne

Important Syndromes Related to Acne

I. SAPHO syndrome

  1. Synovitis
  2. Acne
  3. Pustulosis
  4. Hyperostosis
  5. Osteitis

II. HAIR-AN syndrome

  1. Hyperandrogenism (HA)
  2. Insulin Resistance (IR)
  3. Acanthosis Nigricans(AN)

III. SAHA syndrome

  1. Seborrhoea
  2. Acne
  3. Hirsutism
  4. Androgenetic alopecia

IV. PAPA syndrome

  1. Pyogenic Arthritis (PA)
  2. Pyoderma gangrenosum (P)
  3. Acne(A)

questions.text: A 47-year-old chronic alcoholic patient is admitted for the treatment of a fractured tibia. On the 3rd day of admission, he develops severe restlessness and becomes agitated. He has visual and tactile hallucinations. On examination, he is disoriented, diaphoretic and has tachycardia and fever. Which of the following would be the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of delirium tremens. Administration of lorazepam would be the appropriate treatment for this patient. 

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It occurs usually within 3-4 days of alcohol withdrawal. Characteristic features are:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation to time and place
  • Poor attention and distractibility
  • Visual hallucination and illusions which are often vivid and very frightening
  • Autonomic disturbances like tachycardia, fever, hypertension, diaphoresis and pupillary dilatation
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia

Benzodiazepines such as lorazepam (intravenously) or chlordiazepoxide (orally every 4 hours) are given. It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Other options: 

Option A: Phenytoin which is a non-benzodiazepine anti convulsant is usually not helpful in the prevention or treatment of alcohol withdrawal delirium or seizures. 

Option B: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic and is usually avoided in patients with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal due to its propensity to reduce the seizure threshold in alcoholics.

Option C: Fomepizole is used in the treatment of ethylene glycol and methanol intoxication. 

Related Pearl: Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome

Manifestation
Symptoms/signs
Onset since last drink (hours)
Tremulousness
Continuous tremor of > 8 Hz (or) Bursts of tremor activity < 8 Hz
6–8
Alcoholic hallucinosis/
Psychotic and perceptual symptoms
Visual, auditory or tactile; intact orientation; stable vital signs. 
8-12
Seizures (rum fits)
Single or multiple generalized tonic-clonic
12–24
Delirium tremens
Confusion, agitation, fever, tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, impaired orientation
< 72

questions.text: What is the correct statement regarding the wound indicated by the red arrow in the given image of the skull?

choices.text: It is an entry wound because the outer table appears bevelled
It is an Exit wound because the inner table appears bevelled
It is an Exit wound because the outer table appears bevelled
It is an entry wound because the inner table appears bevelled

questions.solution:
In the given image, bevelling is seen on the outer table and a punched out hole is seen on the inner table. So, it is an exit wound.

Entry wound: The initial contact of the missile punches a clean hole through the outer table of the skull. Where the bullet emerges internally, the inner table is then unsupported and a cone-shaped plug is detached, forming a crater that is appreciably larger than the external hole.

  • Bevelling: inner table
  • Punched out hole: outer table

Exit wound: If the bullet traverses the cranium and penetrates the opposite side, the same pattern occurs, this time with the small hole on the inner table and the crater on the outside.

  • Bevelling: outer table
  • Punched out hole: inner table

A 'rat-hole' appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun can be seen from 30 cm to 5 meters of range:

  • Circular rat-hole wound without peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in 30cm-1m range.
  • Central rat-hole wound with peripheral satellite pellet holes is seen in 1m-5m range.

Ricochet: This is when the bullet hits an intervening object before hitting the desired target. Due to this, it tumbles towards the target and enters it obliquely, rather than head-on.

Related Pearl: Difference between Wound of Entry and Exit

Characteristics

Wound of entry

Wound of exit

Size

Smaller than the diameter of the bullet.

In close discharge, skin is torn, hence size is increased.

Bigger than the diameter of the bullet.

Margin

Inverted

Everted

Soiling of wound

-ve

+ve

-ve

+ve

-ve

+ve

-ve

More

-ve

Dispersion of pallets (shotgun)

+ve

-ve

Protrusion of fat

-ve

+ve

Bright red (Carboxy Hb)

+ve (Near shot)

-ve

X-ray Metallic Ring

+ve

-ve

Muzzle impression

+ve (contact shot)

-ve

Blast effect

+ve (contact shot)

-ve

questions.text: A 42-year-old male, who is a known case of PVD, comes with complaints of rest pain. Which of the following values of ankle and brachial pressure correspond to the values that can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
An ABPI of <0.5 is associated with rest pain. The ABPI of 0.4, seen in case of option D, Ankle - 48/36mm Hg, Brachial - 120/80mm Hg, will be corresponding to that of rest pain.

ABPI = Systolic Pressure at Ankle/ Systolic Pressure in the arm(Brachial)

=48/120 = 0.4

 

Other options:

A - ABPI =1.25

B - ABPI = 1

C - ABPI = 0.75

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements true or false regarding the procedure shown in the image below:
  1. The procedure is associated with reduced Ghrelin levels
  2. Barrett's esophagus is not a contraindication for the procedure
  3. The procedure reduces the risk of GERD
  4. Late leaks are more commonly associated with this procedure than others
  5. Stenosis/ obstruction following the procedure can be treated with endoscopic dilatation
questions.solution:
The image shows a sleeve gastrectomy procedure. The correct answers are:

 

  • The procedure is associated with reduced Ghrelin levels - True

 Ghrelin levels decrease following gastrectomy procedures, including sleeve gastrectomy as the stomach is the primary source of ghrelin.

 

  • Barrett's esophagus is not a contraindication for the procedure - False

Barret's esophagus is considered a contraindication of the procedure as the potential for future esophageal dysplasia and the need for an available intact stomach for esophageal reconstruction outweigh the potential advantages of the procedure.

 

  • The procedure reduces the risk of GERD - False

Sleeve gastrectomy is associated with increased risk of GERD

 

  • Late leaks are more commonly associated with this procedure than others - True

Unlike other bariatric procedures, sleeve gastrectomy is associated with an increased incidence of late leaks

 

  • Stenosis/ obstruction following the procedure can be treated with endoscopic dilatation - True

Endoscopic dilations are usually successful in treating stenosis after Sleeve gastrectomy.

questions.text:
A young adult male met with a road traffic accident and sustained severe injuries to his head and face. On the third day at the hospital, he started experiencing nasal discharge. Which of the following features suggests that the discharge is cerebrospinal fluid?
  1. Drops of fluid gush down on bending forward.
  2. The secretion is thin and clear.
  3. The secretion can be sniffed back
  4. When collected on a piece of filter paper, shows a double target sign.
  5. β2 transferrin is not present in the secretion.
questions.solution:
The features that are suggestive of cerebrospinal fluid are:

  • Drops of fluid gush down on bending forward.
  • The secretion is thin and clear.
  • When collected on a piece of filter paper, shows a double target sign.

CSF rhinorrhea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid into the nose. It can occur as clear fluid or be mixed with blood, particularly in cases of acute head injuries.

The route by which CSF from the anterior cranial fossa reaches the nose includes the cribriform plate, the roof of ethmoid air cells, or the frontal sinus. In contrast, CSF from the middle cranial fossa follows injuries to the sphenoid sinus. Fractures of the temporal bone can lead to CSF entering the middle ear and escaping through the eustachian tube, resulting in CSF otorhinorrhea.

When CSF rhinorrhea occurs after head trauma, it often contains a mixture of blood, leading to a characteristic appearance known as the double target sign when collected on a piece of filter paper. This sign presents as a central red spot (indicating blood) surrounded by a lighter peripheral halo. Nasal endoscopy can be useful in some cases to locate the site of CSF leakage.

In early cases of post-traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, conservative measures can be employed as initial management. These measures include bed rest, elevating the head of the bed, using stool softeners, and avoiding activities that increase nasal pressure, such as nose blowing, sneezing, and straining. Prophylactic antibiotics may be administered to prevent meningitis. Acetazolamide, a medication that reduces CSF production, can also be employed.

Surgical repair of CSF rhinorrhea can be performed using various approaches, including the neurosurgical intracranial approach, extradural approaches, or the transnasal endoscopic approach. The choice of surgical technique depends on factors such as the location and nature of the CSF leak, as well as the surgeon's expertise.

Features to differentiate between nasal discharge and CSF:

Feature CSF fluid Nasal secretion
History Nasal or sinus surgery, head injury, or intracranial tumor Sneezing, nasal stuffiness, itching in the nose, or lacrimation
Flow of discharge A few drops or a stream of fluid gushes down when bending forward or training and cannot be sniffed back Continuous. No effect on bending forward or straining. Can be sniffed back
Character of discharge Thin, watery, and clear Slimy (mucous) or clear (tears)
Sugar content More than 30 mg/dl Less than 10 mg/dl
Presence of beta-2 transferrin Always present. It is specific to CSF  Always absent

The image below shows the double target sign.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with fatigue and easy bruisability for 3 months. She has a history of taking alternative medicine treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. On examination, her blood pressure is elevated. She has a moon face and buffalo hump, with wasting of limbs. What is the mechanism of action of the hormone that is elevated?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history and clinical examination suggest a diagnosis of exogenous Cushing’s syndrome. The hormone elevated is cortisol (a steroid hormone), which acts by binding to receptors in the cytoplasm.

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the given life cycle:
questions.solution:
The life cycle depicted in the above image is of Dracunculus medinensis (Guinea worm).

Humans are the definitive host. They get infected by drinking unfiltered water containing infected cyclops. Larvae come out once cyclops are killed in the stomach and penetrate the wall of the duodenum. They reach the retroperitoneal and subcutaneous connective tissues and develop into adults.

The fertilized female worm grows and migrates within the connective tissues. It reaches a site where it is likely to come into contact with water like the leg (most common). Here, the gravid female worm secretes a toxin that causes a blister formation. The blister ruptures discharging a milky white fluid containing numerous L1 stage larvae.

The larvae survive for about a week in water. They are swallowed by the intermediate host- freshwater cyclops. The larvae penetrate the gut wall of the cyclops and develop into the infective third-stage larvae. The lifecycle continues when humans drink water containing infective cyclops.

Other options:

Option A: Wuchereria bancrofti passes its life cycle partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female Culex mosquitoes, the intermediate hosts. Its life cycle is shown in the image below:

 

 

Option B: The life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female blackflies, the intermediate host.

 

Option C:  Loa loa completes its life cycle in humans, the definitive host, and in mango flies/day-biting flies of the genus Chrysops, which are the intermediate hosts/vectors.

questions.text: What is the procedure depicted in the given image?

choices.text: Incision and curettage for a chalazion

questions.solution:
The procedure depicted in the given image is the Incision and Curettage (I and C) done for a chalazion.

Points of identification:

  • The lid containing the swelling is everted and a chalazion clamp has been applied to provide a bloodless field for the surgery.
  • The swelling is typically incised in a vertical fashion. This is done so to avoid an injury to the adjacent meibomian gland ducts, which are oriented in a vertical pattern.

The following images show the chalazion clamp and curette used for the above-said procedure.

Chalazion is a chronic inflammatory granuloma of the meibomian gland. It presents as a hard, painless swelling in either lid increasing very gradually in size.

A smaller chalazion can be managed with an intralesional injection of triamcinolone acetonide. If it does not resolve with this, Incision and curettage is done. Larger ones are managed initially with incision and curettage only.

questions.text: A female patient with a history of psychiatric illness presents to the outpatient. She admits to abusing diuretics for the past 2 weeks. On examination, blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. With respect to extracellular fluid volume (ECF), intracellular fluid volume (ICF), and plasma sodium, which of the following changes will this patient have?

choices.text: Increased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium
Decreased ECF, decreased ICF, and increased plasma sodium
Decreased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium
Increased ECF, decreased ICF, and increased plasma sodium

questions.solution:
Diuretic overuse shows decreased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium, leading to hypoosmotic volume contraction.

A similar picture is seen in adrenal insufficiency. Due to a deficiency of aldosterone, there is a decrease in both plasma volume and osmolality.

Other Options:

Option A: This is seen in cases of hypoosmotic volume expansion like in the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) and bronchogenic tumors. 

SIADH is associated with euvolemic hyponatremia. This leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a fluid shift from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx also leads to a decrease in the ICF's osmolarity. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, an increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both compartments.

Option B: This is seen in cases of hyperosmotic volume contraction like in diabetes insipidus and excessive sweating.

Option D: This is seen in cases of hyperosmotic volume expansion like in high NaCl intake. The addition of excess NaCl to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

The illustration given below shows the Darrow-Yannet diagram in various conditions.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with right-sided abdominal pain for the past 3 hours and mild bleeding per vaginum. Her LMP was 5 weeks ago. On examination, tenderness of the right iliac fossa is present. Ultrasound shows a gestational sac in the right fallopian tube. Which of these features, if present, would make you opt for surgical management over methotrexate?

choices.text: A Gestational sac size of 2.9 cm

questions.solution:
A beta HCG of >5000 IU/L would make one opt for surgical management over methotrexate. Although this is not a contraindication to methotrexate use, the chance of successful management is less with higher beta HCG values.

Other factors that would make one opt for surgical management are:

  • Sac >4 cm
  • Fetal heart rate (FHR) present
  • Patient hemodynamically unstable

 

Methotrexate is used in the medical management of ectopic pregnancy. It has certain absolute and relative contraindications. When used in conditions that are relatively contraindicated, the risk of failure is high.      

Absolute contraindications:  

  • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Intrauterine pregnancy
  • Evidence of immunodeficiency
  • Moderate to severe anaemia, leukopenia and thrombocytopenia
  • Active pulmonary disease
  • Active peptic ulcer disease
  • Sensitivity to methotrexate
  • Clinically significant hepatic impairment
  • Clinically significant renal impairment
  • Breastfeeding

Relative contraindications:

  • Embryonic cardiac activity determined by transvaginal ultrasonography
  • High initial HCG concentration
  • Ectopic pregnancy greater than 4cm in size as by TV sonography
  • Refusal to accept a blood transfusion

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations do you expect to see in a patient with ferrochelatase deficiency?

choices.text: Increased urinary ALA and coproporphyrin III
Increased urinary ALA and porphyrobilinogen III (PBG)
Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and fecal coproporphyrin III
Increased fecal and red cell protoporphyrin IX

questions.solution:
Increased fecal and red cell protoporphyrin IX is seen in ferrochelatase deficiency. This leads to Protoporphyria.

Other options:

Option A: Increased urinary ALA and coproporphyrin III are seen in ALA dehydratase deficiency.

Option B: Increased urinary ALA and porphyrobilinogen III (PBG) are seen in uroporphyrinogen I synthase deficiency causing acute intermittent porphyria. This enzyme is also called PBG deaminase or hydroxymethylbilane synthase.

Option C: Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III, and fecal coproporphyrin III is seen in coproporphyrinogen oxidase deficiency causing hereditary coproporphyria.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of a chemical synapse?
questions.solution:
Synaptic delay is seen in chemical synapses, but not in electrical synapses.

The minimum time for transmission across one synapse is 0.5 ms, it is possible to determine whether a given reflex pathway is monosynaptic or polysynaptic (contains more than one synapse) by measuring the synaptic delay.

Other Options:

Options B, C, D: Are features of electrical synapses.

questions.text: A woman presents to the gynaecology OPD with mild itching and pain over the vulva. The presence of which of these features goes against a diagnosis of lichen sclerosis?

choices.text: A cystic lesion over the 8 ‘o’ clock position

questions.solution:
A cystic lesion over the 8 ‘o'clock position suggests Bartholin’s cyst. The other features are seen in lichen sclerosus.

Lichen sclerosus usually presents in postmenopausal women. Multiple etiologies have been suggested (infectious, hormonal, genetic, and autoimmune) and up to 30% are associated with other autoimmune conditions. Symptoms include itching, excoriations and vulval skin thinning and crinkling (Figure of 8 appearance). Later, dyspareunia occurs. Perianal involvement is frequently seen. The typical appearance is: white, atrophic papules may coalesce into plaques and distort normal anatomy. Labia minora regression, clitoral concealment, urethral obstruction, and introital stenosis can develop. A biopsy is needed to exclude malignancy. 

Topical corticosteroids remain the first line of treatment.

questions.text: You are a physician working in the paediatric emergency department. This is the arterial blood gas (ABG) of patient X: pH = 7.5, pCO2 = 25 mm Hg, bicarbonate = 24 mEq/L. Which of the following patients does this ABG belong to?

choices.text: A 3 yr old boy with severe vomiting with blood pressure of 90/50 mm Hg
A 4 yr old girl with breathlessness and respiratory rate of 50 breaths/min
A 5 yr old girl with opioid overdose and respiratory rate of 6 breaths/min
A 6 yr old boy with fatigue and drowsiness and blood glucose of 600 mg/dL

questions.solution:
The ABG shows increased pH with low pCO2 (Respiratory alkalosis due to CO2 washout). Such a picture will be seen in a child with severe tachypnoea.

Other Options:

Option A: In this case, there will be metabolic alkalosis: High pH, high bicarbonate, high pCO2. Note: The blood pressure in this case is normal for a 3 yr old child.

Option C: In this case, there will be CO2 retention and respiratory acidosis: Low pH, high CO2

Option D: In this case, there will be metabolic acidosis: Low pH, low bicarbonate, low pCO2

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: Fibres that carry certain impulses are more susceptible to local anaesthetic than others. Of the given options, the fibres carrying which impulses would be most susceptible to effects of a local anaesthetic?
questions.solution:
Cold is carried by C-fibres, which are small and unmyelinated, making them the most susceptible to effects of a local anaesthetic.

Other Options:

Option B: Pinprick is carried by A-delta, which are slightly larger and myelinated, making them more resistant than C fibres to local anaesthetic.

Option C: Touch is carried by A-beta, which are still larger and myelinated, making them more resistant than C fibres to local anaesthetic.

Option D: Motor fibres are A-alpha, which are the largest and myelinated, making them more resistant than C fibres to local anaesthetic.

Note: Order of sensitivity to local anaesthetic: C>A-delta>A-beta>A-alpha

Order of recovery or regression of blockade: Motor>Touch>Pinprick>Cold (Reverse of susceptibility)

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of drugs act on the same receptor but have opposite effects?
questions.solution:
Diazoxide and nateglinide act on K-ATP channels (potassium-ATP channels) on the beta cells of pancreas. Nateglinide causes these channels to close, while diazoxide keeps them open.

Closure of these channels eventually results in insulin release, hence nateglinide is used in diabetics. Diazoxide is used in insulinomas, because it inhibits insulin release by keeping these channels open.

Other options:

Option A: Octreotide is a synthetic surrogate of somatostatin. They both inhibit growth hormone release. Since octreotide is more potent and with increased duration of action, it is preferred for use in acromegaly and secretory diarrheas.

Option B: Thioridazine and haloperidol are D2 (dopamine) receptor blockers. These are typical antipsychotics and used to treat schizophrenia and similar psychotic conditions.

Option C: Pioglitazone is a PPAR gamma agonist used in diabetes, while gemfibrozil is a PPAR alpha agonist, used in hyperlipidemia. (PPAR: peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor).

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida woman presents at 34 weeks gestation with bleeding per vaginum (PV). She had 3 episodes of spotting during this pregnancy, which resolved on their own. She has no pain. On examination, vitals are stable and the fetus is found to be in transverse lie with a fetal heart rate of 140 beats/min. What is the gold standard investigation to diagnose the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This woman’s history is suggestive of placenta previa, for which the gold standard investigation would be an MRI. The sagittal images of the MRI best demonstrate the relationship of the placenta to the internal cervical os, although it is not required in most instances.

Placenta previa is characterized by abnormal implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. Placenta previa and abruptio placenta together account for 70% of the cases of antepartum hemorrhage.

Other Options:

A transvaginal sonogram (TVS) is more accurate to assess placenta praevia, as the transabdominal sonogram overdiagnoses it.

Note: Transvaginal sonogram (TVS) is the most common investigation, but MRI is the gold standard investigation to diagnose placenta previa since it demonstrates the relationship of the placenta to the internal cervical os.

questions.text: The device shown in the image is _______ and the patient _______ with the machine:
questions.solution:
The image shows incentive spirometer and the patient inhales with the machine.


The patient sits upright and inhales with a slow deep breath after placing his mouth tightly around the mouthpiece.

The incentive spirometer mimics normal sighing. It serves to prevent/reverse atelectasis.

Incentive spirometer is used in post-op patients and in pneumonia patients to ensure sustained maximal inspiration so as to prevent stasis.

The simple float spirometer. It was previously used in spirometry measurements.

The image shows a Electronic Spirometry test being performed. They have better accuracy and efficiency compared to the other previously used types of spirometers.

questions.text: MIDAS syndrome is characterised by all of the following except _________
questions.solution:
MIDAS syndrome (microopthalmia, dermal aplasia, sclerocornea) is not characterized by iritis.

MIDAS syndrome is an X-linked  dominant disorder characterized by :

  • Linear aplastic skin defects in a Blaschko‐line pattern on head and neck
  • Microphthalmia/ anophthalmia
  • Sclerocornea/corneal opacity
  • Cardiac defects
  • Hypoplastic corpus callosum and abnormal myelination
  • Microcephaly
  • Postnatal growth retardation
  • Facial dysmorphism

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the structure marked by the red arrow?

choices.text: Injury causes Loss of sensation of the posterior one third of the tongue
Arises from the posterior trunk of mandibular nerve
It is joined by the chorda tympani branch of facial nerve
It is joined by a branch of inferior alveolar nerve

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the lingual nerve. Injury to the lingual nerve results in loss of sensation to the anterior two thirds of the tongue.

Points of identification: The nerve runs downwards and forwards on the surface of the medial pterygoid muscle.

The lingual nerve arises from the posterior trunk of the mandibular nerve. It is joined by the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve and a branch from the inferior alveolar nerve.

Loss of sensation of the posterior one third of the tongue is due to the injury to glossopharyngeal nerve.

Deviation of the tongue to the affected side is seen in injury to the hypoglossal nerve.

Related Pearl: Sensory Innervation of Tongue

Special sensory

Lingual nerve (CN V)

Chorda tympani (CN VII)

Posterior 1/3rd

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)
