questions.text: A 20-year-old man with chickenpox calls his family doctor and asks how long he should isolate to prevent the infection from spreading to his family. What should the physician tell him?

choices.text: Until he finishes a course of acyclovir
Until all the lesions are crusted

questions.solution:
The physician should tell the man that he must isolate himself from his family until all of his skin lesions are crusted. This will help to prevent the transmission of the virus to his family members. Isolation is an important method to prevent the further spread of chickenpox as the secondary attack rates in household contacts are very high (up to 90%). The individual remains infective from approximately 48 hours before the appearance of the rash, during the time of vesicle formation (4-5 days), and till the point where all the lesions have crusted over. 

Chickenpox is a highly contagious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). It spreads via droplet infection during personal contact and enters through the respiratory system or the conjunctiva. The course of chickenpox can be divided into 2 stages-

  • Pre-eruptive The pre-eruptive stage includes the fever and viral prodrome, which lasts for 2-3 days until the rash begins to appear
  • The eruptive stage begins with the appearance of the rash. It usually appears first on the trunk, followed by the limbs and face. The rash quickly goes through the various stages (pleomorphism)-macule, papule, vesicle, and finally scab. The vesicle stage has classically been said to have a "dew-drop" appearance. Complications such as cerebellar ataxia, pneumonia, and encephalitis are uncommon but can be seen in some adults and immunocompromised patients. 

The usual control methods include notifying regarding a new case, isolation, and disinfection. Antiviral therapy like acyclovir can prevent systemic disease, especially in immunosuppressed patients. Exposed patients who are immunocompromised may receive the varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG), within 72 hours of exposure to a chickenpox patient. The immunoglobulin must be administered immediately as it has no effect once the disease is established. 

Other options:

Option A: Fever and malaise may subside during the eruptive (vesicle formation) stage, but the patient remains contagious at this point.

Option B: It is unnecessary to isolate until all the lesions have disappeared because the patient is not at risk of transmitting the virus once the lesions have crusted.

Option C: Acyclovir is recommended in adults and children if started within 24 hours of disease onset. However, in some patients with mild illness, conservative management is sufficient.  Regardless of the treatment taken, patients are recommended to follow the same isolation guidelines.

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

 

Disease

Duration of Isolation

Chickenpox

Until all lesions are crusted – usually about 6 days after onset of rash.

Measles

From the onset of symptoms (catarrhal stage) to 5 days after the appearance of the rash

Cholera

Until 3 days of tetracycline therapy.

Diphtheria 

Until 48 hours of antibiotics.

Shigellosis and salmonellosis

Until 3 consecutive negative stool cultures.

Hepatitis A

3 weeks.

Influenza

3 days after onset.

Polio

2 weeks in adult; 6 weeks in children.

Tuberculosis (sputum +)

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy.

Herpes zoster

6 days after onset of rash.

Mumps

Until the swelling subsides.

Pertussis

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease. 

Meningococcal meningitis

Until the first 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy.

Streptococcal pharyngitis

Until the first 6 hours of effective antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with the following injury that he sustained on being tackled by an opponent during the course of a football match. As the Casualty medical officer, you would enter the wound description in the case sheet as ____________________
questions.solution:
The given image shows a laceration.

A laceration is a tear or a split in the skin, mucous membrane, muscle, or any internal organ, with a depth spanning more than the covering epithelium of the skin or an organ, and is produced by blunt force.

Features of laceration:

  • Margins are irregular with pieces of tissue attached in between called tissue tags or bridges
  • Bruising is seen around the margin
  • Deeper tissues are unevenly divided with tissue tags
  • Hair bulbs are crushed
  • Depth of the wound contains abundant foreign material such as dust particles, paint material of the vehicle involved, etc
  • In skin lacerations, usually one of the margins overhangs the other, which could help in assessing the direction of the force
  • A laceration, on healing, produces a permanent scar.

Classification of a laceration:

  • Split laceration (incised - like laceration)
    • This occurs when the skin is crushed between two hard objects
    • For example, during a fall, the scalp gets crushed between the skull from inside and hard ground outside. This results in a wound, which usually mimics an incised one unless examined closely.
  • Stretch laceration
    • As the name implies, it occurs due to the over-stretching of the skin, beyond its elasticity.
    • This typically occurs in the setting of a fractured femur, where the fracture fragment may stretch and pierce the skin to project out
  • Avulsed laceration
    • An avulsion is a lesion where the skin only separates by tearing from the underlying tissues or peels off and overhangs the wound
    • This is common in road traffic accidents.

questions.text: What is the correct sequence followed while doing rapid sequence induction?

choices.text: Preoxygenation  -> IV succinylcholine -> Propofol IV -> Intubate
Preoxygenation -> Propofol IV -> Intubate  -> IV succinylcholine
Preoxygenation -> Propofol IV -> IV succinylcholine -> Intubate
IV succinylcholine -> Preoxygenation  -> Propofol IV -> Intubate

questions.solution:
The correct order of rapid sequence induction (RSI) is: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen -> Administer IV induction agent -> IV succinylcholine -> Do not ventilate -> Direct laryngoscopy and intubation -> Confirm endotracheal tube placement -> Remove cricoid pressure.

Note: RSI is done when the patient is at high risk of aspiration.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with a 2 cm thyroid nodule. The histology of the tumour is given below. Most common mutation associated with this tumour is?
questions.solution:
The image shows the histology of papillary carcinoma thyroid as evidenced by the presence of orphan-Annie eye nuclei. BRAF mutation is the most common mutation in papillary thyroid cancer and is associated with lymph node metastases and a higher recurrence rate.

One third to one-half of papillary thyroid carcinomas harbour a gain-of-function mutation in the BRAF gene. The RET mutations are present in approximately 20% to 40% of papillary thyroid cancers.

Microscopic Features of Papillary carcinoma of  thyroid.

  • Complex, branching, randomly oriented papillae with fibrovascular cores associated with follicles.
  • Usually dense fibrosis.
  • Papillae lined by cuboidal cells.
  • Nuclei are overlapping with finely dispersed optically clear chromatin (also called ground-glass).
  • Orphan-Annie eye nuclei.
  • Macronucleoli, eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions (represent cytoplasmic invaginations) and nuclear longitudinal grooves (represent folding of the redundant nuclear membrane, but nonspecific).
  • Stromal elastosis in 66% - often lymphatic invasion.
  • Psammoma bodies.

Related Pearl: Gene alterations in thyroid cancer

Type of Thyroid Carcinoma  Mutations
Papillary Carcinoma

BRAF mutation

RET/PTC rearrangement

MET

NTRK1 fusion gene

GDNF - glial derived neurotropic factor

questions.text: What is false regarding the structure marked by the red arrow in the given image of the gluteal region?

choices.text: Causes lateral rotation of the thigh in extension
Causes abduction of the thigh in flexion
Sciatic nerve lies closely related to the muscle

questions.solution:
The structure marked is the piriformis muscle.

The muscle has its origin from the following structures.

  • The anterior surface of the sacrum
  • The posterior inferior iliac spine
  • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

It passes outside the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen.

It inserts into the greater trochanter of the femur. The muscle forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and it passes through the muscle fibers or above the muscle.

Action: Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension and abduction of the thigh in the flexed position.

Clinical note: Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle.

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramens

Structures passing through the greater sciatic foramen

The piriformis is the key muscle of this region. It emerges from the pelvis, and fills the foramen almost completely.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the lesser sciatic foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Related Pearl: Various muscles of the gluteal region and their innervation

Muscles

Innervation

questions.text: A 60-yr-old man was brought dead to the hospital. He was a known case of extremely aggressive brain tumour. He had a history of recent onset of headache, seizures, and mental status changes, and MRI had demonstrated an infiltrating neoplasm invading the cerebral hemispheres and crossing the midline, with areas of necrosis and abnormal blood vessels. The autopsy confirms the MRI findings and also demonstrates hemorrhage and a pseudo palisade arrangement of tumor cells. Which of the following is false about this tumour?

choices.text: IDH mutant type carries poor prognosis comparatively
Majority of the primary glioblastomas have PTEN mutation
The tumor falls under WHO grade IV
Temozolomide is the first-line drug in the management

questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests the diagnosis of Glioblastoma multiforme. IDH mutant type has a better prognosis.

Glioblastoma falls under WHO grade IV of brain tumors

According to the WHO Classification of CNS diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows:

Glioblastoma, IDH-wildtype:

  • About 90% of cases
  • Primary or de novo glioblastoma
  • Over 55 years of age
  • Mutations: EGFR, PTEN
  • Carries poor prognosis

Glioblastoma, IDH-mutant:

  • About 10% of cases
  • Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma
  • Arises in younger patients
  • Mutations:p53
  • Better prognosis

Glioblastoma, NOS, where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed.

Temozolomide is used as a first-line agent for the management of glioblastoma multiforme. It is used for newly diagnosed cases along with radiotherapy and also used for maintenance therapy.

The histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudopalisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, which is characteristic of glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme).

questions.text:
Match the following drugs and their common mechanism of resistance

Column A

  1. Lincosamide
  2. Chloramphenicol
  3. Nitrofurantoin
  4. Polymyxins

 

Column B

  1. Altered cell membrane charge with reduced drug binding
  2. Altered drug-activating enzymes
  3. Drug-modifying enzymes
  4. Methylation at ribosome binding site
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

 

  1. Lincosamide - Methylation at ribosome binding site
  2. Chloramphenicol - Drug-modifying enzymes
  3. Nitrofurantoin - Altered drug-activating enzymes
  4. Polymyxins - Altered cell membrane charge with reduced drug binding

     

 

 

Nitrofurantoin is a Nucleic acid synthesis inhibitor that produces reactive drug derivatives that damage DNA. The mechanism of resistance is by altered drug-activating enzymes

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient came to dermatology OPD with the clinical features shown in the image below. The likely diagnosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows bluish patchy skin lesions on the face in the region of the first and second branches of the trigeminal nerve and sclera which are suggestive of nevus of Ota.

Nevus of Ota is an extensive, bluish, patchy, dermal melanocytosis. A large number of elongated dendritic melanocytes can be seen scattered among collagen bundles mainly of the superficial dermis.

It affects the sclera and the skin adjacent to the eye. Distributed along with the first and the second branches of the trigeminal nerve.

Most lesions are present at birth or develop during the first year of life, increasing in size and number in subsequent years. Lesions are more common in females and in Asians.

Q‐switched laser systems are the first-line treatment, as they achieve higher rates of pigment clearing.

Other options:

Option A- Nevus of Ito appears as a  unilateral, blue‐greyish macular discoloration location in the area innervated by the posterior supraclavicular and lateral cutaneous brachial nerves- acromioclavicular region.

 

Option B- A compound nevus is an acquired melanocytic nevus. It is a slightly raised, oval, or round symmetrical papule. This nevus is also pigmented, with shades of brown according to the skin color of the patient.

 

Option D- Hypomelanosis of Ito refers to the skin abnormalities characterized by unusual unilateral or bilateral cutaneous macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches, corresponding to the lines of Blaschko. It is often associated with epilepsy and mental retardation.

questions.text: As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 2021, induction of MTP in a mentally ill or a rape victim is allowed until what age of gestation?
questions.solution:
As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act, 2021, the induction of MTP in a mentally ill woman or a rape victim is allowed until 24 weeks. 

Features of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act 2021:

  • Enhancing the upper gestation limit from 20 to 24 weeks for special categories of women, which includes survivors of rape, victims of incest, and other vulnerable women (like differently-abled women, minors).
  • Opinion of only one provider will be required up to 20 weeks of gestation and of two providers for termination of pregnancy of 20-24 weeks of gestation.
  • Upper gestation limit does not to apply in cases of substantial fetal abnormalities.
  • Name and other particulars of a woman whose pregnancy has been terminated shall not be revealed except to a person authorized in any law for the time being in force.
  • The ground of failure of contraceptives has been extended to women and their partners.

Note: The bill was passed by Rajya Sabha on 17th March 2021.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: You are an anesthetist who needs to administer general anesthesia to an obese patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Preoperatively, you assess the airway using the modified Mallampati classification and conclude that the patient falls under class III. How does her airway probably look?
questions.solution:
The patient’s airway was classified as Mallampati class III, so it probably looks like image 3. Here, the soft palate and base of the uvula are seen.

The Modified Mallampati classification is used to predict difficulty in tracheal intubation. It is based on the size of the base of the tongue. During the assessment, the patient has to be seated, with the head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruding, and no phonation. In this position, the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate is assessed and assigned a class from I-IV. 

The initial Mallampati classification included only classes I-III. It was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class IV. 

In addition to class I-IV, a fifth class also exists called class 0. In this, the epiglottis can be seen when the mouth is opened and tongue is protruded. However, it is still not proven by studies whether class 0 is a sign of easy intubation or not. 

Other options:

Option A: In Mallampati class IV, the soft palate is not visible at all.

Option B: In Mallampati class I, the soft palate, fauces, uvula, and tonsillar pillars are visible.

Option D: In Mallampati class II, the soft palate, fauces, and portion of uvula are visible.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

FA shows hyperfluorescent spots – ‘stars in the sky’ appearance

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic female presents with complaints of progressive pain in and around her left eye. It is associated with the development of multiple vesicles and pustules. These symptoms were preceded by an episode of influenza-like illness a week before. What is the pattern of inflammation seen in the given slit-lamp finding of her eye?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of herpes zoster ophthalmicus and the pattern of inflammation seen in the given slit lamp image is called nummular keratitis.

Nummular keratitis is the earliest finding of the corneal stromal involvement. It is characterised by multiple, fine, granular, coin-shaped infiltrates in the anterior stroma. This condition presents during the second week of the infection and may cause permanent scarring.

Ocular manifestations of herpes zoster:

 

Structure Clinical feature
Lids

●      Scarring

●      ectropion

●      entropion
Conjunctiva

●      Hyperemia

●      petechial hemorrhages

●      papillary or follicular reaction pseudomembrane (rarely)
Sclera Episcleritis and scleritis
Cornea

Lesions due to active viral infection:

●      Punctate epithelial keratitis

●      Pseudodendrite formation (typically smaller than the typical dendrites and lack the terminal end-bulb formation) Lesions due to immune-mediated inflammation:

●      Nummular keratitis

●      Disciform keratitis (deep stromal infiltrate that develops after 3 to 4 months; has a central disc-shaped affected area) Lesions due to chronic neurotrophic keratopathy:

●      Filamentary keratitis 
Uvea

●      Granulomatous or non granulomatous iridocyclitis with keratic precipitates    

●      Secondary angle-closure glaucoma
Posterior segment

●      Retinal perivasculitis

●      Ischemic optic neuropathy

●      ARN (acute retinal necrosis) in immunocompetent individuals

●      PORN (progressive outer retinal necrosis) in immunocompromised patients
Extraocular structures

●      Vasculitis within the orbital apex

●      Extraocular muscles paralysis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the following procedure carried out in a neonate?

choices.text: 0.5 mg Vitamin K1 is administered for babies weighing <1000g by this method
1 mg Vitamin K1 is administered for babies weighing >1000g by this method
0.5ml Hepatitis B vaccine is administered by this method
Administration should be done on anteromedial aspect of thigh

questions.solution:
The procedure shown is the IM injection which is being carried out in the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. It should not be done on the anteromedial aspect of the thigh.

Administration of Vit. K1 and Hepatitis B vaccination are carried out using this method in the newborn. 0.5 mg Vitamin K1 is administered for babies weighing <1000g and 1 mg Vitamin K1 is administered for babies weighing >1000g

questions.text: A 17-year-old student develops infectious mononucleosis. About 15 days later, he develops a high fever and his sore throat worsens. He has lost his ability to swallow and has severe neck and chest pain. Upon admission, he has signs of sepsis and respiratory distress. Which is the organism most likely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggest the diagnosis of Lemierre’s disease. Fusobacterium necrophorum is most likely to be involved in this condition.

Fusobacterium necrophorum is a Gram-negative anaerobic bacillus that is very pleomorphic. It is involved in very severe oropharyngeal infections that can progress to a complicated and life-threatening condition called Lemierre’s disease. It is most commonly caused by Fusobacterium necrophorum. However, species of Bacteroides, Eikenella, Streptococcus, and Peptostreptococcus may also be implicated.

Lemierre’s disease often occurs after infectious mononucleosis in older children and young adults. It is characterized by internal jugular vein septic thrombophlebitis. This progresses to abscesses of the lungs, mediastinum, pleural space, and liver with sepsis. It presents with pharyngitis that is not resolving, associated with rigors, neck pain, and swelling.

questions.text: A 25 year old woman presents at 12 weeks of gestation for a check up. Her obstetric score is G2P1L1. She had a spontaneous vaginal delivery in her previous pregnancy at 34 weeks. She had a history of gestational diabetes but her sugars have remained normal since delivery. In the past, she has been treated for primary syphilis. Ultrasound shows a singleton fetus corresponding to 12 weeks. Which of the following factors is the most significant risk factor for preterm labour in this pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The most significant risk factor for recurrent preterm in this pregnancy is a history of prior preterm. 

17-alpha-hydroxy progesterone caproate (17-OHP-C) is the first and only approved drug for the prevention of recurrent preterm birth.

Risk factors for preterm labour include:

  • Prior preterm
  • Short interval between pregnancies
  • Pregnancy following assisted reproductive technology
  • Uterine abnormalities
  • Asymptomatic bacteriuria/active genital and urinary tract infections
  • Presence of chronic disease like diabetes and hypertension. This woman has had normal sugars since her last delivery
  • Multifetal preganancies
  • Placental abnormalities: Infarction, thrombosis, abruption or placenta previa

questions.text: While reading the X-Ray of a 32-year-old female who has come for her annual health check,  you notice the unilateral elevation of the diaphragm. Which of the following conditions is it least likely to be?
questions.solution:
Poor inspiration would result in a bilaterally elevated diaphragm, not unilateral elevation.

Causes of Unilateral Elevation of the Diaphragm

 

  • Posture—lateral decubitus position (dependent side)
  • Gaseous distension of stomach or colon
  • Dorsal scoliosis
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Pulmonary collapse
  • Phrenic nerve palsy
  • Eventration
  • Pneumonia or pleurisy
  • Pulmonary thromboembolism
  • Rib fracture and other painful conditions
  • Subphrenic infection
  • Subphrenic mass

 

Causes of Bilateral Symmetrical

Elevation of the Diaphragm

 

  • Supine position
  • Poor inspiration
  • Obesity
  • Pregnancy
  • Abdominal distension 
  • Diffuse pulmonary fibrosis
  • Lymphangitis carcinomatosa
  • Disseminated lupus erythematosus
  • Bilateral basal pulmonary emboli
  • Pain after abdominal surgery
  • Bilateral diaphragmatic paralysis

questions.text: An antibacterial drug acts by binding to the terminal dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala of peptidoglycan and prevents its release. Which drug acts by this mechanism?
questions.solution:
Vancomycin acts by binding to the terminal dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala of peptidoglycan and preventing its release, so that assembly of the units at the cell membrane and their cross linking to form the cell wall cannot take place.

Penicillin, extended spectrum penicillins (Like ticarcillin) and cephalosporins inhibit cell wall synthesis but by a different mechanism. They inhibit transpeptidase, so that cross-linking does not take place. In essence, vancomycin acts one step earlier than penicillins.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about RB as the governor of cell cycle?

choices.text: The function of RB protein is to regulate at the G1-S checkpoint
Hypophosphorylated state of the RB promote cell cycle progression
Active RB binds and inhibits the E2F family of transcription factors preventing transcription of cyclin E

questions.solution:
Hyperphosphorylated state (inactive) of RB protein promotes cell cycle progression.

RB, called the Governor of Proliferation is a key negative regulator of the G1/S cell cycle transition and is directly or indirectly inactivated in most human cancers.

  • The normal RB gene is present on chromosome 13q14.
  • RB -  active hypophosphorylated state in quiescent cells and an inactive hyperphosphorylated state in cells passing through the G1/S cell cycle transition.
  • Cyclin D/CDK-4 phosphorylates RB inactivating the protein, and releases E2F to induce target genes such as cyclin E.
  • RB -  antiproliferative effects by binding and inhibiting E2F transcription factors, thereby preventing transcription of cyclin E, required for cells to pass through the G1-S phase cell cycle checkpoint.
  • The antiproliferative effect of RB is abrogated in cancers through a variety of mechanisms, including:
    • Loss-of-function mutations affecting RB
    • Gene amplification of CDK4 and cyclin D genes
    • Loss of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors (p16/INK4a)
    • Viral oncoproteins that bind and inhibit RB (E7 protein of HPV)

Loss-of-function mutations of the RB gene are associated with retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, a subset of glioblastomas, small-cell carcinomas of the lung, breast cancers, and bladder carcinomas.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man working in the smelting industry presents with lesions as seen in the following image. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a smelting industry worker presenting with raindrop pigmentation as shown in the image is suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning. 

There are several types of arsenic poisoning:

  • Fulminant - When massive doses are rapidly absorbed, death occurs in 1–3 hours due to shock and peripheral vascular failure.
  • Gastrointestinal - This is the most common form of acute poisoning and resembles bacterial food poisoning. There is a constriction in the throat and difficulty in swallowing. The stools are dark-colored, stinking, and bloody initially and later take a colorless odorless watery form similar to the rice-water stools of cholera.
  • Chronic poisoning - It occurs due to repeated daily exposure. The main features include finely mottled, raindrop pigmentation that appears on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and neck. In prolonged contact, hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles occurs along with the development of a transverse white line in the fingernails called the Aldrich-Mees lines.

Tests to detect arsenic poisoning:

  • 24-hour urinary excretion of arsenic
  • Detection of arsenic by atomic absorption spectroscopy
  • Marsh and Reinsch tests are now considered obsolete.

The preferred treatment option is freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide, which converts toxic arsenic to non-toxic ferric arsenite. DMSA (Succimer), British anti-Lewisite (BAL), and penicillamine can also be used.

questions.text: The mechanism of vancomycin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus is _____________
questions.solution:
The mechanism of vancomycin resistance in staphylococcus aureus is the acquisition of van-A genes which is transposon-mediated. Vancomycin-resistant staphylococcus aureus (VRSA) strains (MICs ≥ 16 μg/mL) is a major concern worldwide now. The vancomycin resistance gene (vanA) is likely derived from enterococci.

Note: Chromosome mediated mecA (SCCmecA-Staphylococcal Cassette Chromosome mecA)  gene confers methicillin, nafcillin resistance on MRSA.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought by parents to the casualty. On examination varying degrees of ecchymosis is seen all over the body. X-ray shows a spiral fracture of the femur. Which of the following is not a part of the  Minimum Required Views in the  Standard Skeletal Survey required for this baby?

choices.text: AP views of the entire skeleton
Lateral views of wrists, ankles, knees
Dedicated views of hands and feet
Lateral views of skull, and spine

questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is battered baby syndrome.  Lateral views of wrists, ankles, knees is usually considered optional.

The presence of spiral fracture femur along with varying degrees of ecchymosis all over the body in a child indicates that the injuries have happened over a span of time, which suggests a diagnosis of the battered baby syndrome.

As per the Standard Skeletal Survey for Suspected Child Abuse, the minimum X-ray views required in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of the axial skeleton—skull, and spine.

Imaging Also Suggested

  • Oblique views of ribs
  • Oblique views of hands and feet

Optional Useful Images

  • Lateral views of the joints—wrists, ankles, knees
  • Orthogonal views of any fractures found

questions.text:
Match the following surgical procedures with the corresponding conditions for which they are used

Column A

  1. Ramstedt's Procedure
  2. Nesbitt Procedure
  3. Heller's Operation
  4. Kasai Procedure

 

Column B

  1. Peyronie's Disease
  2. Biliary Atresia
  3. Infantile-hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
  4. Achalasia Cardia
questions.solution:
The correct match is

  1. Ramstedt's Procedure - Infantile-hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
  2. Nesbitt Procedure - Peyronie's Disease
  3. Heller's Operation - Achalasia Cardia
  4. Kasai Procedure - Biliary Atresia

Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy is performed by a laparoscopic or open supraumbilical incision for the treatment of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

Nesbitt procedure is the most commonly used procedure for the treatment of Peyronie's disease. It corrects the deformity by plicating the convex side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis.

Heller's Myotomy is done for achalasia cardiac. It is often combined with a partial anterior fundoplication, called Heller-Dor Procedure.

Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for all types of Extrahepatic biliary atresia in which radical excision of all bile duct tissues upto the liver capsule is performed. A Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for all of the following except________.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Boyle-Davis mouth gag and it is not used for surgery of the tongue.

It is used for opening the mouth and depressing tongue for doing surgery. Various tongue blades are used along with it according to the age of the patient. Various uses of Boyle Davis mouth gag are:

  • Pharyngoplasty
  • Tonsillectomy 
  • Surgery of soft palate
  • Adenoidectomy
  • Excision of angiofibroma

questions.text: A 6-month old infant presented with progressive macrocephaly, hypotonia, and delayed milestones. He had one episode of seizure in the previous week. MRI was done which showed diffuse white matter degeneration. MR spectroscopy finding is given below. What is the pathology associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of aspartoacylase leads to Canavan disease, a severe leukodystrophy, characterized by excessive excretion of N-acetylaspartic acid (NAA) and spongy degeneration of the white matter of the brain. MRS can show a high peak of N-acetylaspartic acid.

Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive disease that results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme arylsulfatase A.

Mutations in intermediate filament proteins such as GFAP cause Alexander disease

ABCD1 peroxisomal transporter mutation is involved in Adrenoleukodystrophy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female with depression is to be started on transcranial magnetic stimulation as a part of her treatment. Which of the following is the most common adverse event related to this treatment modality that she should be informed about?
questions.solution:
The most common adverse event related to treatment by transcranial magnetic stimulation is scalp Pain or discomfort.

 

Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) involves the use of very short pulses of magnetic energy to stimulate the neurons in the brain. It has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of major depressive disorder when one class of antidepressant has failed.

Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) produces focal secondary electrical stimulation of targeted cortical regions. It is nonconvulsive, requires no anesthesia, has a safe side effect profile, and is not associated with cognitive side effects. During the 40-minute outpatient procedure, the patients do not require anesthesia or sedation and remain awake and alert. The treatment is typically administered daily for 4 to 6 weeks. TMS therapy is contraindicated in patients with implanted metallic devices.

questions.text:
The correct order of removing Personal Protective Equipment (PPE):
  1. Gown
  2. Mask
  3. Face shield
  4. Gloves
questions.solution:
The type of PPE used will vary based on the level of precautions required, such as standard and contact, droplet or airborne infection isolation precautions. The procedure for putting on and removing PPE should be tailored to the specific type of PPE. 

Nevertheless, there are 2 sequences that are recommended by the CDC for the removal of PPE. 

Sequence 1 Sequence 2

GLOVES

 ↓

GOGGLES OR FACE SHIELD

 

↓

GOWN

 

↓

MASK OR RESPIRATOR

GOWN AND GLOVES  

 

↓

GOGGLES OR FACE SHIELD

 

↓

MASK OR RESPIRATOR

Elaborating further on this,

  1. GLOVES
    • Outside of gloves are contaminated!
    • If your hands get contaminated during glove removal, immediately wash your hands or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer
    • Using a gloved hand, grasp the palm area of the other gloved hand and peel off the first glove
    • Hold removed glove in the gloved hand
    • Slide fingers of ungloved hand under remaining glove at the wrist and peel off the second glove over the first glove
    • Discard gloves in a waste container
  2. GOGGLES OR FACE SHIELD
    • Outside of goggles or face shields are contaminated!
    • If your hands get contaminated during goggle or face shield removal, immediately wash your hands or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer
    • Remove goggles or face shield from the back by lifting headband or earpieces
    • If the item is reusable, place in the designated receptacle for reprocessing. Otherwise, discard in a waste container
  3. GOWN
    • Gown front and sleeves are contaminated!
    • If your hands get contaminated during gown removal, immediately wash your hands or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer
    • Unfasten gown ties, taking care that sleeves don’t contact your body when reaching for ties
    • Pull gown away from neck and shoulders, touching inside of gown only
    • Turn gown inside out
    • Fold or roll into a bundle and discard in a waste container
  4. MASK OR RESPIRATOR
    • Front of mask/respirator is contaminated — DO NOT TOUCH!
    • If your hands get contaminated during mask/respirator removal, immediately wash your hands or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer
    • Grasp bottom ties or elastics of the mask/respirator, then the ones at the top, and remove without touching the front
    • Discard in a waste container
  5. WASH HANDS OR USE AN ALCOHOL-BASED HAND SANITIZER IMMEDIATELY AFTER REMOVING ALL PPE

The other recommended sequence is 

  1.  GOWN AND GLOVES
    • Gown front and sleeves and the outside of gloves are contaminated!
    • If your hands get contaminated during gown or glove removal, immediately wash your hands or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer
    • Grasp the gown in the front and pull away from your body so that the ties break, touching outside of gown only with gloved hands
    • While removing the gown, fold or roll the gown inside-out into a bundle
    • As you are removing the gown, peel off your gloves at the same time, only touching the inside of the gloves and gown with your bare hands. Place the gown and gloves into a waste container 
  2. GOGGLES OR FACE SHIELD
    • Outside of goggles or face shield are contaminated!
    • If your hands get contaminated during goggle or face shield removal, immediately wash your hands or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer
    • Remove goggles or face shield from the back by lifting headband and without touching the front of the goggles or face shield
    • If the item is reusable, place in the designated receptacle for reprocessing. Otherwise, discard in a waste container
  3. MASK OR RESPIRATOR
    • Front of mask/respirator is contaminated — DO NOT TOUCH!
    • If your hands get contaminated during mask/respirator removal, immediately wash your hands or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer
    • Grasp bottom ties or elastics of the mask/respirator, then the ones at the top, and remove without touching the front
    • Discard in a waste container
  4. WASH HANDS OR USE AN ALCOHOL-BASED HAND SANITIZER IMMEDIATELY AFTER REMOVING ALL PPE

 

The recommended sequence for putting on PPE

  1. GOWN
    • Fully cover torso from neck to knees, arms to the end of wrists, and wrap around the back
    • Fasten in back of neck and waist
  2. MASK OR RESPIRATOR
    • Secure ties or elastic bands at the middle of the head and neck
    • Fit flexible band to the nose bridge
    • Fit snug to face and below the chin
    • Fit-check respirator
  3. GOGGLES OR FACE SHIELD
    • Place over face and eyes and adjust to fit
  4. GLOVES
    • Extend to cover wrist of isolation gown

questions.text: A 28-year-old school teacher suffers a road traffic accident that results in a head injury. She undergoes a decompressive craniectomy following which she recovers and is now able to function independently. She returns to work as a teacher, but acknowledges that her capacity is not as before. Her recovery would be given a score of _______ as per the Glasgow outcome score.
questions.solution:
Since she is independent and has returned to work, she would be given a score of 5, corresponding to a good recovery. Good recovery implies independence and the potential to return to work rather than a complete return to previous capacity.

The Glasgow outcome score is used to quantify the degree of recovery achieved after a head injury.

Functional status Score
Good recovery 5
Moderate disability 4
Severe disability 3
Persistent vegetative state 2
Dead 1

questions.text: A 29-year-old patient has the presence of subsyndromal symptoms of both anxiety and depression. He also complains of tremors, palpitations, and a sensation of churning stomach. A diagnosis of mixed anxiety-depressive disorder is made by the evaluating psychiatrist. Which of the following would be the drug of choice for the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Venlafaxine is considered the drug of choice for the treatment of mixed anxiety-depressive disorder.

Mixed anxiety-depressive disorder is diagnosed when the patient has the presence of subsyndromal symptoms of both anxiety and depression. Some autonomic symptoms, such as tremors, palpitations, the sensation of a churning stomach and dry mouth are often associated. 

Venlafaxine which has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder, as well as depression, is considered the drug of choice here although Alprazolam and Buspirone may be tried in the treatment.

questions.text: An offense registered under which of the following IPC sections dealing with sexual offenses is bailable?
questions.solution:
Section 376B dealing with sexual intercourse by the husband upon his wife, without her consent, during separation is cognizable (only on a complaint of the victim) and bailable.

Punishment is imprisonment for not less than 2 years, which may extend to 7 years and with a fine.

Other options:

Option A: 376D deals with a woman being raped by one or more people in a group with common intention and shall be punished for imprisonment not less than 20 years and can go for a lifetime. 

Option B: 376A deals with a person committing an offense of rape and inflicting injury which causes death or causes the woman to be in a persistent vegetative state.

Option D: 376C deals with sexual intercourse by a person in authority (police officer, public servant, member of armed forces, management or staff of a jail, remand home or other places of custody and management or staff of a hospital) induces or seduces any female inmate of such jail, remand home, place or institution to have sexual intercourse with him, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offense of rape.

Related Pearl: Sexual Offences

Punishment

Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 10 years which may extend to imprisonment for life.

65(2) The person committing an offense of rape on a woman under 12 years of age Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 20 years but which may extend to imprisonment for life with fine or with death 376AB

Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 5 years but which may extend to 10 years and with a fine. 376C
70(1) Gang Rape Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 20 years which may extend to imprisonment for life with fine 376D

As per the The Gazette of India, from the Ministry of Law and Justice, Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita Document 2023

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with complaints of blurring of vision and progressive discomfort in both his eyes for the past 1 week. There is an antecedent history of penetrating trauma to his right eye 6 weeks back. Slit lamp examination reveals mutton-fat keratic precipitates in the anterior chamber. Direct ophthalmoscopy shows discrete yellow-white nodules in the fundus. What is the main modality of initial management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis. Pulse intravenous methylprednisolone therapy is the main modality of the initial management of this condition.

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous pan-uveitis that usually occurs after penetrative trauma. It can also develop after intraocular surgery. Both the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye) develop panuveitis. Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.

It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. According to the allergic theory, the uveal pigment in the injured eye acts as an allergen that causes uveitis in the other eye. Dalen-Fuchs nodules (proliferation of pigment epithelium), exudative retinal detachment, and optic disc swelling can be seen on fundoscopy. A sunset glow appearance can persist due to residual chorioretinal scarring.

Dalen-Fuchs nodules are depicted in the image below.

The exciting eye shows features of low-grade uveitis such as ciliary congestion, lacrimation, and tenderness. The sympathizing eye is usually involved 4-8 weeks later. It has a prodromal stage with photophobia, ciliary congestion, and keratic precipitates. In the fully developed stage, symptoms of acute iridocyclitis supervene.

Management options for sympathetic ophthalmitis:

  • Pulse intravenous methylprednisolone (up to 1g daily for 3 days) followed by oral prednisolone (1.5 to 2 mg per kg) is required to suppress the inflammation
  • Immunosuppressive agents such as cyclosporin, azathioprine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and chlorambucil may be used in cases non-responsive to steroids or patients who have severe side effects due to corticosteroid use
  • Enucleation of the exciting eye can be done immediately after the injury if it is not salvageable.

questions.text:
Assertion: Serologic testing is the best method for evaluation of a transplant recipient for infections post-transplantation
Reason: Variant creutzfeld Jacob disease can be transmitted with transfused non-leukodepleted blood.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Serologic testing of the recipient may prove less reliable because of immune dysfunction resulting from chemotherapy or underlying chronic disease. So, it is not considered the best.

Variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease can be transmitted with transfused non-leukodepleted blood and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease can been transmitted through corneal transplants. 

 

So, The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text: In a primary health center, a nurse asks you about using a polio vaccine vial which has not crossed its expiry date. You look at the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) and tell her that it can be used. What did the VVM most likely show?

choices.text: Inner square white, outer circle blue
Inner square blue, outer circle white
Outer square white, inner circle blue
Outer square blue, inner circle white

questions.solution:
The vaccine vial monitor has most likely showed inner square white and outer circle blue.

The standard polio vaccine vial monitor has a colour monitor or labels on the vaccine bottles. The label has an inner white square and an outer blue circle.

It can be used if the inner square is lighter than the outer circle. When the colour of the inner square becomes that of the circle, it means that the vaccine has been exposed to a higher temperature and it cannot be used. 

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text:
Which of the following are considered risk factors for postoperative delirium?
  1. Sleep deprivation
  2. Age≥55 years
  3. Depression
  4. Early ambulation
  5. Hearing impairment
questions.solution:
Older age ≥70 years (not ≥55 years) and immobilization(not early ambulation) are considered risk factors.

 

Risk Factors for Postoperative Delirium

  • Cognitive and behavioral disorders
  • Cognitive impairment and dementia
  • Untreated or inadequately controlled pain
  • Depression
  • Alcohol use
  • Sleep deprivation
  • Disease or illness related
  • Severe illness or comorbidities
  • Renal insufficiency
  • Anemia
  • Hypoxia
  • Metabolic
  • Poor nutrition
  • Dehydration
  • Electrolyte abnormalities
  • Functional impairments
  • Poor functional status
  • Immobilization
  • Hearing or vision impairment
  • Older age (≥70 yr)
  • Polypharmacy and use of psychotropic medications (benzodiazepines, anticholinergic, and antihistamines)
  • Risk of urinary retention or constipation, presence of a urinary catheter

questions.text: The  Secretomotor fibers to the structure marked green in the image pass through which of the following ganglion?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the parotid gland and the secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland pass through the otic ganglion.

The secretomotor pathway of the parotid has 3 components :

  1. Preganglionic fibers: Originate in the inferior salivary nucleus ⇒ pass through the glossopharyngeal nerve ⇒ tympanic branch⇒ tympanic plexus ⇒ lesser petrosal nerve
  2. The lesser petrosal nerve relays in the otic ganglion.
  3. Postganglionic fibers: Pass through the auriculotemporal nerve to reach the gland.

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.
  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.

questions.text: During the ward rounds, you notice the notes on a patient file says dysdiadochokinesia present. To elicit this, which of the following would you ask the patient to perform?

choices.text: Stand with the feet close by and the eyes closed
Fix the eye on an object on one extreme of the room
Supination and pronation of the hand in quick succession
Walk heel to toe on a straight line without any support

questions.solution:
The patient should be asked to perform a rapid alternating movement like the supination and pronation of the hand in quick succession for eliciting dysdiadochokinesis.  Dysdiadochokinesia is the inability to perform rapid alternate movements.

It is a clinical manifestation of cerebellar dysfunction and is most evident when strength and sensation are intact. Focal lesions in the nervous system may produce highly asymmetric dysdiadochokinesia. 

Standing with the feet close by and the eyes closed is used to check for Romberg sign. Walking heel to toe on a straight line without any support is known as the tandem walking test.

 

The following movement is the method to check for dysdiadochokinesis. The patient is showing normal movement, with no dysdiadochokinesis. 

Related Pearl: Functional divisions of the cerebellum

  Dorsal Spinocerebellum Ventral Spinocerebellum Cerebrocerebellum (neocerebellum) Vestibulocerebellum (flocculonodular lobe) 
Constituents Vermis (except the nodulus) The adjacent medial portion of the hemisphere The lateral portion of hemispheres Nodulus and flocculus 
Afferent (input) Somatosensory from the trunk, visual, auditory, and vestibular Somatosensory input from the limbs From the cerebral motor cortex, premotor, and somatosensory cortex  Vestibular input, visual input, somatosensory from the neck
Efferent (output) Via Fastigial nucleus to the medial descending system Via interposed nucleus to lateral corticospinal and rubrospinal systems Via dentate nucleus to motor, premotor and prefrontal cortex  To vestibular nuclei in the brain stem (direct projection)
Functions    

Maintains posture and helps in the execution of gross movements

It controls the interplay between agonist and antagonist group of muscles

 Controls the  distal muscles of the limbs (smoothens and coordinates movements) Planning the sequence of voluntary movements    

 Participates in maintaining equilibrium and posture

 

Controls ocular movements

It is responsible for regulating the stability of the head and body in space

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are not used for SOFA score calculation?
questions.solution:
Urea levels are not used for the calculation of the SOFA score. For renal function assessment, Creatinine levels and urine output are assessed.

Here:

MAP = mean arterial pressure

PaO2 = partial pressure of oxygen

FiO2 = fraction of inspired oxygen

Catecholamine doses are given as µg/kg/min for at least 1 hour.

 

 

A higher SOFA score is associated with an increased probability of mortality.

 

Note:

Another scoring system, called qSOFA (quickSOFA) is intended to screen patients for ICU admission.

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for:

  • Low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg)
  • High respiratory rate (≥22 breaths per min)
  • Altered mentation (Glasgow coma scale, <15)

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt to identify infected patients outside the ICU who have potentially life-threatening sepsis.

questions.text: With respect to hormonal therapy for cancer, which pair is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is progestins - cervical cancer. Progestins are used in the management of endometrial carcinoma, not cervical.

 

Hormonal drugs used in cancer:

  • Glucocorticoids - Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Estrogens - Prostate carcinoma
  • GnRH agonists - Breast
  • Antiandrogen: Flutamide and bicalutamide antagonise androgen action on prostate carcinoma cells.
  • SERM, SERD, Aromatase inhibitors: Carcinoma breast

questions.text: A 54-year-old female patient came with complaints of neck and upper limb pain. She also gives a history of weakness, incoordination, and clumsiness of upper limbs. Her CT scan is as given below. The diagnosis is

choices.text: Ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament
Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament

questions.solution:
The CT scan shows an ossified posterior longitudinal ligament. 

Patients typically present with symptoms of neck and upper-limb pain, weakness, incoordination, clumsiness, muscle wasting, and bladder-bowel dysfunction, etc and are typically older than 50 years of age

It occurs mainly in the cervical spine, most commonly at the level of C5. It can result in spinal stenosis and cervical myelopathy causing pain and weakness in the limbs. X-ray shows dense ossification along the back of the vertebral bodies in the mid-cervical spine. Cervical spinal cord injury can be induced by minor cervical trauma in these patients.

Treatment is needed if the symptoms are progressive. Posterior decompression is the operation of choice.

questions.text: The cytosolic carbomyl phosphate synthetase II that functions in the biosynthesis of pyrimidine uses which of the following substances as Nitrogen donor?
questions.solution:
Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II uses glutamine as the nitrogen donor for its functions in pyrimidine biosynthesis. This is in contrast to carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I which uses ammonia along with CO2 and ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate within the mitochondria in urea cycle.

 

CPS II combines CO2 + Glutamine + ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate which is used in biosynthetic pathway for pyrimidine nucleotides.

questions.text:
Theme and focus: Hypertension
  1. Coarctation of aorta
  2. Pre-eclampsia
  3. Polycystic kidney disease
  4. Cushing syndrome
  5. Chronic glomerulonephritis
  6. Primary hyperaldosteronism
  7. Pheochromocytoma
  8. Acromegaly
questions.solution:
Case 1: Hypertension, with truncal obesity, proximal myopathy, and osteoporosis and elevated urinary free cortisol level are all suggestive of Cushing syndrome. Hypertension is caused by salt and water retention due to excess cortisol.

Case 2: Hypertension in arms, with normal blood pressure in the legs, the difference in blood pressure between both arms, and delayed femoral pulsations are suggestive of coarctation of aorta. The condition is usually seen in patients with Turner syndrome, which is consistent with the clinical history of a Short nulliparous woman with a webbed neck.

Case 3: Hypertension associated with headache, perspiration, palpitations, in a patient operated for Medullary Thyroid Cancer is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. It is usually associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndromes.

 

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Classical triad of symptoms:
    • Headaches – most common symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction
  • Polyuria and polydipsia 
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea

questions.text:
A 26-year-old patient with a history of suicidal attempts is brought to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and tinnitus. He was prescribed aspirin 1 week back for a headache. His lab values are as follows:

Na= 140 mEq/L
K=3.5 mEq/L
Cl=104 mEq/L
HCO3=16 mEq/L
glucose= 100 mg/dL
pH: 7.50
pCO2: 20 mmHg
P02: 125 mmHg

What is the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis
Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
Mixed high anion gap metabolic acidosis with respiratory alkalosis
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
This patient has a mixed high anion gap metabolic acidosis with additional respiratory alkalosis.

Step 1: pH in this patient is 7.50 which is an alkalemia.

Step 2: Bicarbonate levels in this patient are 16 mEq/L which is reduced. This signifies the loss of base. Hence a metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: PCO2 levels in this patient are 20 mmHg, which is less than normal. This signifies a respiratory alkalosis.

Step 4: Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

= 20.

Hence the patient has a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. In addition, respiratory alkalosis is also present, whether it is a mixed disorder or compensatory can be determined by assessing the extent of compensatory response.

Step 5: Assessing the compensatory response:

In metabolic acidosis, appropriate respiratory compensation is to decrease PCO2, by excretion of volatile acid by hyperventilation. Expected PCO2 is calculated by the Winters formula:

PCO2=  [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2

= [1.5 X 16] + 8 ± 2

=30-34

During metabolic acidosis, there is respiratory compensation by hyperventilation resulting in loss of volatile acid causing a reduction in PCO2 levels. The expected PCO2 levels are 30-34 mEq/L in this patient. However, since PCO2 is 20 mEq/l in this patient, there is an additional respiratory alkalosis independent of the compensatory response.

An elevated anion gap even in the setting of a normal pH or alkalemia always indicates metabolic acidosis.

This patient's history of suicidal tendencies, aspirin use, and tinnitus points to aspirin toxicity as a cause of the disease. Aspirin overdose results in initial hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis due to direct stimulation of respiratory centres. In addition, aspirin being a salicylate causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)

Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

questions.text: Which of the circuits has the fresh gas inlet near the patient and corrugated tubing, but no reservoir bag?
questions.solution:
Ayre’s T piece, a type of Mapleson E system has the fresh gas inlet near the patient and corrugated tubing, but no reservoir bag.

Other Options:

Option A: Bain’s circuit or Mapleson D has the fresh gas inlet near the patient, a reservoir bag and corrugated tubing.

Option C: Water’s to and fro circuit or Mapleson C has the fresh gas inlet near the patient and a reservoir bag but no corrugated tubing.

Option D: Magill’s circuit or Mapleson A has the fresh gas inlet near the bag. It has a reservoir bag and corrugated tubing.

questions.text: A nurse in a village visits a family. She counsels the couple who have recently had their 1st child about proper spacing between childbirths. She also sensitizes them about the importance of vaccinating their baby. She takes a sputum sample from the old lady in the house, who has had a cough for 4 weeks and also takes a Pap smear from her. The man’s unmarried 21 yr old brother also lives with them. He is sexually active and the nurse educates him about safe sex practices. With his consent, she also collects a blood sample to screen for HIV. Which of the actions done by the nurse does not come under the modern concept of family planning?
questions.solution:
Sputum sample collection does not come under the purview of family planning.

It is considered that family planning has under its purview:

  • Proper spacing and limitation of birth
  • Advice on sterility
  • Education for parenthood
  • Sex education
  • Screening for pathological conditions related to the reproductive system (e.g. Cervical cancer)
  • Genetic counseling
  • Premarital consultation and examination
  • Pregnancy tests
  • Marriage counseling
  • Preparation of couples for first child
  • Providing services to unmarried mothers
  • Teaching home economics and nutrition
  • Providing adoption services

questions.text: During the attempted intubation of a patient, the senior resident complains that the glottis is too anterior and asks the junior resident to perform a maneuver so that the senior resident would be able to visualize the glottis better as shown below. Identify the correct sequence of steps that the junior resident would have performed for obtaining such a result.
questions.solution:
The maneuver that the junior resident would have performed is the BURP maneuver, where a Backwards->Upwards->Rightwards pressure is applied externally so as to move an anteriorly positioned glottis posterior for getting better visualization.

You can visualize the step-by-step result of the maneuver in the video below.

Note:

BURP maneuver should not be confused with Sellick's maneuver (cricoid pressure), which involves the application of pressure to the cricoid cartilage, thus occluding the esophagus. This technique is used in rapid-sequence induction to reduce the risk of aspiration.

questions.text: While trying to assess the function of the Eustachian tube, the person is asked to pinch his nose and swallow. The above method is described as_____________
questions.solution:
The method described is the Toynbee test

In Toynbee’s test, the person is asked to pinch the nostrils and swallow repeatedly. By doing so, the air from the middle ear is drawn into the nasopharynx causing a retraction of the tympanic membrane. The retracted tympanic membrane can be visualized by an otoscopic examination.
Other tests to assess the function of the eustachian tube:

  • Valsalva test 
    • The principle of this test is to build positive pressure in the nasopharynx so that, air enters the Eustachian tube. 
    • This is accomplished by asking the person to pinch the nostrils, take a deep breath and close the mouth, and then blow out, which pushes air into the eustachian tube
    • This makes the tympanic membrane to bulge out and can be seen with an otoscope
  • Politzer test
    • The principle is the same as that of the Valsalva test and performed in those who cannot do the Valsalva test, as in children
    • A Politzer’s bag is compressed to look for the tubal function on the desired site at the same time the child swallows.
  • Catheterization (it combines the use of a catheter and Politzer bag)
  • The saccharine test is for measuring the mucociliary clearance

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with myopia at 10 years of age came for an opinion on LASIK surgery. On routine preoperative assessment, the estimated residual stromal bed was calculated to be 200 μm, and surgery was deferred. Which of the following anticipated complications made the surgeon take such a decision?
questions.solution:
LASIK, when performed in this patient, would predispose him to ectasia of the cornea (keratectasia) because of the inadequate residual stromal bed thickness.

Because LASIK is a procedure involving the ablation of stroma, a preoperative calculation of the residual stromal bed thickness can aid the eye surgeon to predict the postoperative risk for corneal ectasia.

The residual stromal bed thickness can be calculated by subtracting the anticipated flap thickness and maximum ablation depth from the central corneal thickness. A residual stromal bed thickness of 250 to 300 μm is generally recognized as a minimum requirement before LASIK surgery. Hence, the calculation of central corneal thickness is an important element of preoperative evaluation.

Patient selection is of utmost importance in refractive eye surgeries. The following factors must be considered before taking up a patient for refractive eye surgery.

  • Minimum age of 21 years
  • Stable refraction for at least 1 year
  • Measurement of the central corneal thickness ( to calculate the residual stromal bed thickness)
  • A detailed review of ocular and systemic conditions

Limitations and contraindications of LASIK: The following group of patients poses a high risk for laser vision correction, and when done are associated with adverse surgical outcomes.

  • Collagen vascular disease
  • Autoimmune and immunodeficiency diseases
  • Pregnant and nursing mothers
  • Keratoconus
  • Chronic intake of isotretinoin and amiodarone
  • Fuchs corneal dystrophy
  • Ophthalmic herpes simplex and herpes zoster

Other options:

Option A- Punctate epithelial dystrophy (dry eye) is the most frequent complication of LASIK surgery, and the same can be managed with frequent lubrication using artificial tears.

Option B- Flap displacement usually occurs within 24 hours after surgery. Once diagnosed, the flap should be lifted and repositioned as soon as possible.

Option D- The corneal epithelium grows in the interface between the flap and stromal bed. This is termed epithelial ingrowth. If it causes vision disturbances, Nd:YAG laser application is warranted to treat the condition.

Related Pearl: Surgical correction of Myopia

Cornea-based procedures Lens-based procedures

Laser-based:

Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK)

Laser in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK)(Most common)

Refractive lens exchange

Refractive lenticule extraction (ReLEx) (or)

Small incision lenticule extraction (SMILE)

Phakic intraocular lens
Intracorneal ring segment (ICRS) implantation

Clear lens extraction
Orthokeratology  
Radial keratotomy (obsolete)

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with a history of accidental rupture of her partner's condom during intercourse. She is concerned about getting pregnant and wants to avoid it as she already has 2 kids. Which of the following contraceptives is the most effective to prevent unwanted pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The most effective method of emergency contraception(post-coital contraceptive/ interceptive) is a copper IUCD. The failure rate is 0.1%.

The advantages of Copper T as an emergency contraceptive are as follows

  • It can be inserted as late as 5 days after the unprotected intercourse
  • It is cheap
  • The failure rate is 0.1%
  • It can remain as an ongoing contraceptive.

Other Options:

Option B: Ulipristal tablet has a 2% chance of pregnancy with its use.

Option C: Levonorgestrel tablet has a failure rate of 1.1%.

Option D: Mifepristone has a failure rate of 0.9%.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year Contraceptive
First tier  < 2 % IUCD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal - oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

questions.text: A 30-year old patient comes to the hospital with complaints of blood-tinged nasal discharge. The anterior rhinoscopy shows a pink polypoidal mass in the right nose and the same is biopsied. The image given below is the histological slide of the specimen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathology showing several sporangia is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Patients clinically present with blood-tinged nasal discharge, and pink polypoidal mass in the nose.

Histopathology shows several sporangia, oval, or round in shape and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its chitinous wall.

It is treated by completely excising the mass with a diathermy knife followed by cauterization of the base.

Other options :

Option A: Rhinophyma is a slow-growing benign tumor due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of the tip of the nose, often seen in cases of long-standing acne rosacea. It is also called a potato tumor.

The image below shows rhinophyma.

Option C: Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). Histopathology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells. There are also homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies consisting of the immunoglobulins in the plasma cells called the Russell bodies.

The image given below shows non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose in rhinoscleroma. The histology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells.

Option D: Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in patients who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers, iron- and goldsmiths. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia with atrophy of the seromucous glands.

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

questions.text:
Identify the condition in which the given findings are seen.

Platelet counts-Normal

BT-Increased

PT and aPTT- Normal

Flow cytometry - Decreased CD41 and CD61
questions.solution:
The given findings of increased BT and normal PT, aPTT is suggestive of Platelet aggregation disorders. Decreased CD41 and CD61 (Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa) is suggestive of Glanzmann Thrombasthenia.

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive disease which occurs due to inherited deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa. There is normal platelet morphology and normal platelet count, prolonged bleeding time, absent or decreased clot retraction, and normal platelet aggregation in the presence of ristocetin. Platelet aggregation is absent in the presence of epinephrine, collagen, arachidonic acid, ADP. Under flow-cytometric analysis, CD41 and CD61 levels are markedly decreased or absent.

Acquired GT is seen with platelet transfusions, immune thrombocytopenic purpura, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, multiple myeloma, myelodysplastic syndrome, hairy cell leukaemia, and acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.

Related Pearl: Platelet disorders

Finding

Bernard–Soulier syndrome

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia

von Willebrand Disease
 Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

 Most common (type 1): Autosomal dominant
 Defect
