questions.text: A middle-aged woman who has regular periods and is sexually active comes with a history of new onset post-coital bleeding. She mentions that her last period was much heavier than usual. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a pap smear in the OPD

questions.solution:
In this patient with a history of new-onset post-coital bleeding and menorrhagia, cervical cancer can be suspected in the patient, and a pap smear would be the next step in management to rule it out.

Papanicolaou test or pap test is a screening test routinely employed in gynaecological practice. 

 The screening guidelines include the following

  • Time for initiation: 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
  • Cytology alone is done in women aged 21-29 years, every 3 years. 
  • In women who are aged 30-65 years, for every 5 years, FDA-approved primary hrHPV testing and co-testing (hrHPV testing and cytology) are done and cytology alone, is done every 3 years
  • Women can stop cervical cancer screening if previous negative results after the age of 65 years or hysterectomy along with cervix removal are done.

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol and stained with Pap stain.

The instruments used for pap smear are summarized in the image below.

Pap smear should be obtained prior to the vaginal examination (Option A), because the fingers may remove the desquamated cervical cells and give a false-negative report, the lubricant may prevent detection of organisms, and any vaginal bleeding during the examination may preclude proper visualization of the cervix.

The laboratory investigations and transvaginal ultrasound can be ordered after taking a Pap smear and doing a per-vaginal examination. (Options C and D). A transvaginal ultrasound should be taken to assess the endometrial thickness and rule out any fibroids. Hemoglobin levels should be estimated to assess the need for iron supplementation since heavy blood loss can cause anemia.

questions.text:
Assertion: Loperamide should not be administered to children with acute diarrhea
Reason: Loperamide is a synthetic opiate that causes reduction of gut motility

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Loperamide should not be administered to children with acute diarrhea because it is a synthetic opiate that causes a reduction of gut motility. Inhibition of gut motility/ intestinal peristalsis results in more time for harmful bacterial multiplication within the gut. Also, synthetic opiates may result in distension of abdomen, paralytic ileus, bacterial overgrowth and sepsis when used in children with acute diarrhea and may even prove fatal in infants. 

So,

Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who has been extensively smoking for the past 5 years, presents to the ED with a sudden onset of fever with hemoptysis and hematuria. On examination, he is dyspneic and pale. A panel of blood investigations done on him shows anemia with deranged renal function. The nephrologist suspects him to have antibodies against α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV and proceeds to perform an urgent renal biopsy. Which of the following histological pattern is expected to be present in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical features, lab investigations, and suspicion of having antibodies against the α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV narrows down the diagnosis to Goodpasture’s syndrome. The expected histologic pattern in this patient is the presence of crescents in the glomeruli, as seen in image B.

Patients who develop antibodies against glomerular basement antigens frequently develop glomerulonephritis termed anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease. When glomerulonephritis is combined with lung haemorrhage, as seen in our case, it is termed Goodpasture’s syndrome.

Certain features of the anti-GBM disease

  • The autoantibodies are directed against the α3 NC1 domain of collagen IV and predominantly belong to the IgG group.
  • The clinical presentation can occur in two groups
    •  Younger men in their late twenties
      • They present in an explosive manner with hemoptysis, a sudden fall in hemoglobin, fever, dyspnoea, and hematuria
      • Lung haemorrhage is a usual presentation in smokers, but surprisingly they do better than the other group
    • Older men and women in their sixties and seventies
      • These geriatric populations run a prolonged, asymptomatic course and end up with chronic renal failure with oliguria, and the prognosis is usually worse.

Characteristic histological pattern progresses as given below

  • Focal or segmental necrosis
  • Crescent formation (due to the destruction of capillaries by excessive cellular proliferation)
  • Interstitial nephritis with fibrosis and tubular atrophy

Immunofluorescent staining shows a linear pattern for IgG.

Other images

Image A shows a normal glomerulus

Image C shows segmental sclerosis of the glomeruli

Image D shows diffuse thickening of the basement membrane

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

questions.text: Which of the following mucopolysaccharidosis does not show leukocyte inclusions?
questions.solution:
Morquio disease does not show leukocyte inclusions.

Morquio disease is different from other mucopolysaccharidoses as it presents as spondyloepiphyseal skeletal dysplasia.

Mucopolysaccharidoses are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans.

  • Most common MPS: Sanfilippo > Hurler’s and Hunter’s
  • MPS with no mental retardation: Scheie’s disease, Morquio syndrome, and Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome.
  • MPS with no corneal clouding: Hunter’s disease and Sanfilippo syndrome
  • MPS with XLR inheritance: Hunter’s disease
  • MPS with no visceromegaly: Morquio’s disease
  • Skeletal deformity associated with all MPS: Dysostosis multiplex
  • MPS with no leucocyte inclusions: Morquio’s disease

questions.text: A diet consisting of excessive amounts of which of the following can lead to iron deficiency?
questions.solution:
Tannates inhibit inorganic iron absorption. Hence, a diet consisting of excessive tannates (found in tea) could potentially lead to iron deficiency.

Citric acid, ascorbic acid, amino acids and sugars in the diet (when increased amounts of meat, lemon juice and sugar are consumed), increase inorganic iron absorption.

 

Note: Dietary influences in absorption is predominantly for inorganic/non-heme iron. Heme iron is readily absorbed.

 

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

Enhancers:

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions show "Pop corn calcification"?
  1. Fibroadenoma
  2. Fibrous dysplasia
  3. Duct ectasia
  4. Pulmonary hamartoma
  5. Calcified uterine fibroid
questions.solution:
The calcification in duct ectasia has a broken needle appearance. All the other conditions are associated with pop-corn calcification.

Amorphous calcifications with rings and arcs which resemble popped corn kernels in appearance are known as pop-corn calcification. 

It may be seen in 

  • Chondroid lesions like chondrosarcoma
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Pulmonary hamartomas
  • Fibroadenoma breast
  • Calcified uterine fibroid
  • Metaphyses and epiphyses of long bones of children with osteogenesis imperfecta.

Image showing popcorn calcification in involuted fibroadenoma of the breast is given below:

Note: 

Duct ectasia is associated with coarse rod and branching calcification due to calcification of the debris within the dilated ducts. This is responsible for the broken-needle appearance.

questions.text: A 3-year-old mentally retarded boy presented to the OPD with abdominal mass and hematuria. His BP is 130/80. On further examination, the appearance of the kid’s eye is as given below. What is the possible mutation which has occurred in this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the image showing aniridia is suggestive of WAGR syndrome. It is associated with PAX6 deletion.

Wilms tumor:

It is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood.

Clinical feature: Most common clinical finding is asymptomatic abdominal mass. Hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture causing acute abdomen are other presentations of the disease. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is lungs.

Microscopy: The classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable.

Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

 

MYCN amplification and Gain of function ALK mutations are associated with Neuroblastoma.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is false regarding the modality that is considered the investigation of choice for diagnosis of osteoporosis?

BMD- Bone mineral density

choices.text: T-score of < -1 in the total hip is considered osteoporosis
T-score of < -2.5 in the femoral neck is considered osteoporosis
Bone spurs may cause increased BMD values
Small thin people tend to have less than average BMD

questions.solution:
T-score of < -1 in the total hip is considered osteoporosis is false. 

The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is DEXA (dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry). A T-score <–2.5 in the lumbar spine, femoral neck, or total hip has been defined as osteoporosis.

DEXA measures the bone mineral density of an individual. In the DEXA technique, two X-ray energies are used to estimate the area of mineralized tissue, and the mineral content is divided by bone area, which partially corrects for body and bone size. However, as this is a two-dimensional method, the correction is not adequate and small slim people tend to have lower BMD as compared to the average.

Also, bone spurs, tend to falsely increase bone density, and are a particular problem in measuring spine BMD in older individuals.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient, with complaints of cough and high-grade fever, was diagnosed to have pneumonia. He was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics, but his pneumonia did not resolve. In due course of treatment, he also developed painful sores in the mouth, associated with lymphadenopathy. He had been in South America, a few years back.  Culture from the lesion shows the appearance given in the image.  What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The history of travel to South America and the involvement of the reticuloendothelial system suggests the diagnosis of paracoccidioidomycosis. The condition is also called South Amerian Blastomycosis.

The above image shows the characteristic Pilot wheel appearance on culture seen with Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It causes Paracoccidioidomycosis, a chronic granulomatous disease affecting lungs, skin, mucosa, lymph nodes. 

On culture at 37 °C, large oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cell are seen This is known as Mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A Forensic Examiner receives the following skull of a victim of mob violence. Which of the following conclusions he makes is correct:

choices.text: The victim could have suffered blunt force trauma
It is not possible to determine the sequence of injuries from fracture pattern
The victim could only have suffered from a gun-shot wound as indicated by Puppe’s rule
Fracture pattern in skull injuries are random and offer no clue upon examination

questions.solution:
Puppe’s Rule is true for all blunt injuries to the skull, and it is of particular importance in Gunshot wounds. But the rule is not limited to gunshots.

Puppe’s rule:

A new fracture Line does not cross an existing fracture line which can be used to determine the sequence of injuries.

In this scenario, the sufferer has been a victim of mob violence and the sequence of injuries would be as mentioned below.

  •  Correct sequence of the injuries in this would be 1->2->3

Note - Puppe's rule is applicable to any multiple blunt force trauma causing skull fractures.
